Díky dvojímu občanství {{!}} Chytré portfolio|date=2014-11-04|website=Lidovky.cz|language=cs|access-date=2018-02-13}} |net_worth = [[United States dollar|US$]]4.04 billion {{small|(in 2017)}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/billionaires/profiles/andrej-babis|title=Bloomberg Billionaires Index|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|accessdate=1 October 2017}} |spouse = Beata Adamovičová {{small|(divorced)}}
Monika Babišová {{small|(2017–present)}} |children = 4 |alma_mater = [[University of Economics in Bratislava|University of Economics, Bratislava]] |residence = [[Kramář's Villa]] }} '''Andrej Babiš''' ({{IPA-cs|ˈandrɛj ˈbabɪʃ}}; born 2 September 1954) is a [[Czech Republic|Czech]] politician of [[Slovak people|Slovak]] origin who has been the [[Prime Minister of the Czech Republic]] since December 2017, and previously served as [[Finance Minister of the Czech Republic|Minister of Finance]] and Deputy Prime Minister for the Economy from January 2013 to May 2017. Before entering politics, he was a businessman and entrepreneur. Babiš was born in [[Bratislava]] in present-day [[Slovakia]], and moved to the Czech Republic following the [[Velvet Revolution]]. The [[List of Czechs by net worth|second richest man in the Czech Republic]] with an estimated net worth of about $4.04 billion according to [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]], he is a former CEO and sole owner of the [[Agrofert]] group, which owns two of the largest Czech newspapers, ''[[Mladá fronta DNES]]'' and ''[[Lidové noviny]]''.{{cite web|url=http://byznys.ihned.cz/zpravodajstvi/c1-61586990-andrej-babis-konci-ve-vedei-firmy-agrofert|title=Končím ve vedení Agrofertu, tvrdí Babiš. Majitelem ale zůstává, sám si podepsal výpověď|date=20 January 2014|work=[[Hospodářské noviny]]|language=Czech|accessdate=21 January 2014}} Babiš has led ANO 2011 since founding it in 2012 as a protest movement against [[The Establishment|established politics]]. He has been a member of the [[Chamber of Deputies of the Czech Republic|Chamber of Deputies]] (MP) since 2013. Babiš was sacked from the [[Bohuslav Sobotka's Cabinet|government]] by Prime Minister [[Bohuslav Sobotka]] on 24 May 2017 after a month-long [[2017 Czech government crisis|coalition crisis]] triggered by allegations that Babiš avoided paying taxes as CEO of [[Agrofert]] in 2012. Following the [[Czech legislative election, 2017|2017 legislative election]], which resulted in a [[hung parliament]] with no possible coalitions, Babiš was appointed Prime Minister on 6 December 2017 and a week later formed a [[Andrej Babiš' First Cabinet|minority government]] composed of [[ANO 2011|ANO]] party members and [[Independent politician|independents]]. He became the [[List of Prime Ministers of the Czech Republic#Statistics|oldest]] and wealthiest person ever to assume the [[Prime Minister of the Czech Republic|premiership]], as well as the first Prime Minister in the history of the Czech Republic to be from a different party than [[Civic Democratic Party (Czech Republic)|ODS]] or [[Czech Social Democratic Party|ČSSD]]. On 16 January 2018, his government lost [[Motion of no confidence|motion of confidence]] vote (78 MPs for while 117 against) in the [[Chamber of Deputies of the Czech Republic|Chamber of Deputies]] and he resigned the following day. His [[Andrej Babiš' Second Cabinet|second cabinet]], confirmed by the Chamber of Deputies on 12 July 2018, is the first government since the [[Velvet Revolution|fall of Communism in 1989]] to rely on [[confidence and supply|support]] from the [[Communist Party of Bohemia and Moravia|Communist Party]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jul/12/czech-communists-return-to-government-as-power-brokers|title=Czech communists return to government as power brokers|last=Tait|first=Robert|date=2018-07-12|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-07-12}} Babiš had been under investigation by both [[Police of the Czech Republic|Czech Police]] and [[European Anti-fraud Office|OLAF]] from 2015 to 2017 amid allegations that an anonymous company he controlled unlawfully received €2m [[European Regional Development Fund|subsidy]] from the [[European Union]]. In September 2017, he was stripped his [[parliamentary immunity]] after a police request in connection with the case and Babiš was formally charged on 9 October 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.eu/article/czech-election-front-runner-charged-with-subsidy-fraud/|title=Czech election front-runner charged with subsidy fraud|date=9 October 2017|work=POLITICO|access-date=9 October 2017|language=en-US}} [[European Anti-Fraud Office|OLAF]] concluded its investigation in December 2017 stating it has found irregularities and endorsed the steps taken by the [[Police of the Czech Republic|Czech Police]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/05/eu-antifraud-office-finds-irregularities-in-payments-allegedly-obtained-by-czech-pm|title=EU antifraud office finds 'irregularities' in payments allegedly obtained by Czech PM|last=Rankin|first=Jennifer|date=2018-01-05|work=The Guardian|access-date=2018-01-06|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} Due to his re-election in the [[Czech legislative election, 2017|2017 election]] he regained his parliamentary immunity and the Chamber of Deputies voted again to lift it on 19 January 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-czech-politics/czech-lower-house-votes-to-lift-immunity-of-prime-minister-idUSKBN1F81EH|title=Czech lawmakers lift PM Babis's immunity amid fraud allegations|date=19 January 2018|work=Reuters|access-date=2018-01-19}} As well as alleged fraud, Babiš is the subject of sustained criticism from political opponents and the media regarding a number of issues, including conflict of interest, his past role in the [[StB|communist secret police]], and allegations of intimidation of opponents. Despite this, Babiš remains one of the most popular politicians in the [[Czech Republic]].{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/05/29/uk-czech-politics-spying-idUKKBN0OE17820150529?feedType=RSS&feedName=worldNews|title=Czech court clears ex-PM's aide in scandal that toppled government|date=30 May 2015|agency=Reuters|accessdate=31 May 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2017/10/21/czech-donald-trump-set-becoming-next-prime-minister/787285001/|title='Czech Donald Trump' set on becoming next prime minister}}{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.eu/article/czech-voters-hand-euroskeptic-babis-big-victory/|title='Czech Trump' Babiš claims big victory|date=21 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/czech-trump-adrej-babis-poised-to-deliver-latest-blow-to-eu-order-20171017-gz2y27.html|title='Czech Trump' Andrej Babis poised to deliver latest blow to EU order|first=Nick|last=Miller|date=18 October 2017|work=The Sydney Morning Herald}} ==Early life and career == Babiš was born on 2 September 1954 to a [[Slovaks|Slovak]] family in [[Bratislava]], [[Czechoslovakia]] (present-day [[Slovakia]]). His father, a diplomat and member of the [[Communist Party of Czechoslovakia]], represented [[Czechoslovakia]] during the negotiation of the [[General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade]] (GATT) in [[Geneva]] and as a consultant at the United Nations.{{cite web|url=http://www.financninoviny.cz/zpravy/e15-cz-miliardar-babis-koupil-ringier-za-ctyri-miliardy-korun/955114|title=E15.cz: Miliardář Babiš koupil Ringier za čtyři miliardy korun|date=24 June 2013|publisher=e15.cz – Finanční noviny (originally [[ČTK]])|language=Czech|accessdate=29 August 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cas.sk/clanok/155805/rebricek-miliardarov-babis-je-medzi-najbohatsimi-ludmi-sveta.html|title=Rebríček miliardárov: Babiš je medzi najbohatšími ľuďmi sveta! |date=12 March 2010|publisher=[[Nový čas]]|language=Slovak|accessdate=29 August 2013}} He is nephew of Ervin and [[Viera Scheibner]].{{cite web|url=http://www.anobudelip.cz/cs/o-nas/blogy/12512/muj-podrobny-zivotopis|title=Můj příběh|last=Babiš|first=Andrej|publisher=[[Action of Dissatisfied Citizens|ANO 2011]]|language=Czech|accessdate=21 January 2014}}Miroslav Slavkay, Michal Kaličiak: Významní slovenskí geológovia. Bratislava : Veda, 2000, p. 399. {{ISBN|80-224-0639-2}} Babiš spent part of his childhood abroad, and was educated in Paris and [[Geneva]]. Later, he studied at a [[Gymnasium (school)|gymnasium]] in Bratislava and continued to the [[University of Economics in Bratislava|University of Economics]], where he studied [[international trade]]. In 1978, after graduating, he joined the Slovak communist controlled international trade company, ''Chemapol Bratislava'', which later became ''Petrimex''. In 1985 he was appointed as the organisation's representative in [[Morocco]].{{cite web|url=http://nazory.euro.e15.cz/profily/zemedelstvi-andrej-babis-ovladl-s-nekolika-akciemi-ovladne-politiku-s-par-tisici-podporovatelu-722171|title=Zemědělství Andrej Babiš ovládl s několika akciemi. Ovládne politiku s pár tisíci podporovatelů? |date=1 December 2011|publisher=e15.cz|language=Czech|accessdate=29 August 2013}} He joined the Communist Party in 1980. He has been accused of being a "powerful agent" for the [[Czechoslovakia|Czechoslovak]] secret state security service, [[StB]], during the 1980s,{{cn|date=April 2018}} as well as being a [[KGB]] officer.[https://archive.is/20150415020914/http://www.kralovehradeckenovinky.cz/zpravy/zpravy/hucin-mel-jsem-v-rukou-dokumenty-o-babisove-spolupraci-s-stb/ ] == Business career == [[File:Chodovec, Klíčova a Pyšelská, Agrofert.jpg|thumb|Headquarters of Agrofert in [[Chodov (Prague)|Chodov]], Prague.]] Babiš returned from Morocco to Czechoslovakia in 1991, after the [[Velvet Revolution]], and settled in the [[Czech Republic]] after the [[dissolution of Czechoslovakia]]. In January 1993, Babiš became managing director of a newly established Petrimex subsidiary operating in the Czech Republic, [[Agrofert]].{{cite web|url=http://www.reflex.cz/clanek/zpravy/52406/legenda-o-svatem-andrejovi-reflex-odhaluje-zapomenute-informace-o-babisove-zbohatnuti.html|title=Legenda o svatém Andrejovi. Reflex odhaluje zapomenuté informace o Babišově zbohatnutí|last=Kaiser|first=Daniel |date=25 October 2013|work=[[Reflex (magazine)|Reflex]]|language=Czech|accessdate=8 October 2014}}Commercial register at justice.cz, identification number (IČ) 48117072, Agrofert, spol. s r.o. He had suggested establishing Agrofert while he was a director at Petrimex, during which time Agrofert was recapitalised by OFI, a company of unknown ownership based in [[Baar, Switzerland|Baar]], [[Switzerland]], which took control of Agrofert from Petrimex. Petrimex later fired Babiš and sued him, unsuccessfully, for allowing the firm's stake in Agrofert to be diluted. Soon thereafter, Babiš emerged as the 100% owner of Agrofert.{{cite web|url=http://www.bne.eu/content/story/comment-why-next-czech-pm-surrounding-himself-police-and-spooks |title=Why is the next Czech PM surrounding himself with police and spooks? |website=Bne.eu |date=14 November 2014 |accessdate=23 February 2017}} The source of the initial financing for Babiš's takeover of Agrofert from Petrimex was still undisclosed as of the start of 2016, although Babiš has said that the money came from his Swiss former schoolmates.{{cite web |url=https://www.newstatesman.com/culture/observations/2017/10/czech-trump-shoots-power-rise-and-rise-andrej-babi |title=The Czech Trump shoots for power: the rise and rise of Andrej Babiš |last=Anderson |first= Robert|date=21 October 2017 |website=[[New Statesman]] |access-date=21 October 2017}} Babiš gradually developed Agrofert into one of the largest companies in the country,{{cite web|url=http://www.respekt.cz/respekt-in-english/the-richest-czech-keeps-a-secret|first=Jaroslav|last=Spurný|title=The richest Czech keeps a secret|date=13 May 2002|publisher=respekt.cz|accessdate=29 August 2015}} starting as a wholesale and trading firm, but later acquiring various agricultural, [[food processing]], and [[Chemical industry|chemical]] companies. In 2011 Agrofert Holding consisted of more than 230 companies,[https://web.archive.org/web/20131004233127/http://www.agrofert.cz/f/?2124%2Fvyrocni-zprava-2011 ] mainly in the Czech Republic, [[Slovakia]], and [[Germany]]. It is the [[List of companies of the Czech Republic#Largest by revenue|fourth largest]] company in the Czech Republic by revenue, exceeding [[CZK]] 117 billion. The history of Agrofert, detailed in a book by the journalist [[Tomáš Pergler]], is closely linked to its control of the Czech petrochemicals industry. One reviewer of the book said the account "captures much of what has led Czechs to the conviction that they live in a corrupted, clientist country – and (paradoxically) then to vote for the ANO movement." When Babiš entered politics he resigned as [[Chief executive officer|CEO]], but remained sole owner until February 2017, when he was legally obliged to put his companies in [[Trust law|trust]] in order to remain as [[Finance Minister of the Czech Republic|Minister of Finance]]. While Babiš's business activities initially focused mainly on agriculture, he later acquired a large empire of media companies. In 2013, Agrofert purchased the company [[MAFRA]], publisher of two of the biggest Czech newspapers, ''[[Lidové noviny]]'' and ''[[Mladá fronta DNES]]'', and operator of the [[Óčko]] television company.{{cite web|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/ekonomika/232763-babis-koupil-mafru-do-obsahu-novin-zasahovat-nebude-rika-jeho-mluvci/|title=Babiš koupil Mafru. Do obsahu novin zasahovat nebude, říká jeho mluvčí|last=Kejlová|first=Tamara |date=26 June 2013|publisher=[[Czech Television]]|language=Czech|accessdate=29 August 2013}} Agrofert also owns [[Radio Impuls (Czech Republic)|Radio Impuls]], the most listened to radio station in the Czech Republic (as of late 2014).{{cite web|url=http://mam.ihned.cz/c1-63068780-nejposlouchanejsi-stanici-zustava-radio-impuls-potvrdil-pruzkum|title=Nejposlouchanější stanicí zůstává rádio Impuls, potvrdil průzkum|date=6 November 2014|work=Hospodářské noviny|publisher=[[Hospodářské noviny]] (originally [[ČTK]])|language=Czech|accessdate=3 March 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://ekonomika.idnes.cz/babisuv-agrofert-muze-prevzit-radio-impuls-rozhodl-antimonopolni-urad-1ny-/ekoakcie.aspx?c=A140122_104721_ekoakcie_spi|title=Babiš může převzít Rádio Impuls, rozhodl antimonopolní úřad|date=22 January 2014|work=Mladá fronta DNES|accessdate=3 March 2015}} These acquisitions have led critics to question Babis's political motives, amid accusations that he was amassing too much power, and that the media outlets he controls publish sympathetic coverage of him.{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2015/04/10/now-the-czechs-have-an-oligarch-problem-too-andrej-babis/# |title=Now the Czechs Have an Oligarch Problem, Too |work=Foreign Policy |date=10 April 2015 |accessdate=23 February 2017}} == Political career == [[File:Andrej Babis Sebastian Kurz 2015 (16330390570).jpg|thumb|Babiš with Austrian Foreign Minister [[Sebastian Kurz]] in February 2015]] In 2011, Babiš founded his party, [[ANO 2011]], "to fight corruption and other ills in the country's political system".{{cite web|url=http://www.praguepost.com/business/16648-babiss-purchase-of-mafra-raises-questions-of-motives.html|title=Babiš's purchase of Mafra raises questions of motives|last=Bardsley|first=Daniel |date=3 July 2013|publisher=Prague Monitor|accessdate=29 August 2013}} The party contested the [[Czech legislative election, 2013|legislative elections in October 2013]] and emerged as the second largest party, with 47 seats (of 200) in the [[Chamber of Deputies of the Parliament of the Czech Republic|Chamber of Deputies]]. The American political consulting firm, [[Penn Schoen Berland]], was credited with the party's successful result.{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20140409005938/en/PSB%E2%80%99s-Alex-Braun-Awarded-2014-Campaign-Excellence#.VS3E0_nF8RN |title=PSB's Alex Braun Awarded the 2014 Campaign Excellence Award for International Campaign Consultant of the Year |publisher=Business Wire |date=9 April 2014 |accessdate=23 February 2017}}{{cite web|author=Lenka Zlámalová |url=http://archiv.ihned.cz/c1-22742060-obamuv-vzestup-se-podoba-zelenym |title=Alexander Braun: Obamův vzestup se podobá zeleným | |website=Hospodářské noviny |date=11 January 2008 |accessdate=23 February 2017}} In the subsequent [[Bohuslav Sobotka's Cabinet|coalition government]], formed of the [[Czech Social Democratic Party|Social Democrats]], ANO, and the [[Christian and Democratic Union – Czechoslovak People's Party|Christian Democrats]], Babiš served as the [[Finance Minister of the Czech Republic|Minister of Finance]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/domaci/255713-ministerstvo-financi-bude-nakonec-ridit-babis/|title=Ministerstvo financí bude nakonec řídit Babiš|last=Matyášová|first=Veronika |date=22 December 2013|publisher=[[Czech Television]]|language=Czech|accessdate=21 January 2014}} During his tenure in this role, Babiš introduced controversial policies such as electronic registration of sales, known as EET, proposed reverse charging of [[value-added tax]], and VAT control statement for companies. His critics claimed he was tightening regulations on [[small and medium-sized enterprises]] and [[sole proprietorship]] while turning a blind eye to big corporations, to the benefit of his own [[Agrofert]] holding.{{Cite news|url=https://www.respekt.cz/komentare/tri-miliardy-od-babise-pro-babise|title=Tři miliardy od Babiše pro Babiše|last=Spurný|first=Jaroslav|work=[[Respekt]]|language=Czech|access-date=3 August 2017}} During this time he stated many times that he would like to be the next [[Prime Minister of the Czech Republic]] if ANO 2011 led the government.{{cite news|url=http://domaci.ihned.cz/c1-64253570-andrej-babis-chce-byt-pristim-premierem-a-proto-se-cini-je-stale-vice-videt-v-zahranici|title=Andrej Babiš chce být příštím premiérem, a proto se činí. Je stále více vidět v zahraničí|date=2 July 2015|work=Hospodářské noviny|language=Czech|accessdate=2 July 2015}} In May 2015, after the government's decision to extend reduced taxation of biofuels (a segment of the fuel market controlled significantly by companies in the Agrofert portfolio), the opposition initiated a [[motion of no confidence|vote of no confidence]] against the cabinet.{{cite web|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/domaci/312308-opozicni-top-09-ods-a-usvit-navrhnou-vysloveni-neduvery-vlade/|title=Opoziční TOP 09, ODS a Úsvit navrhnou vyslovení nedůvěry vládě|date=21 May 2015|publisher=Czech Television|language=Czech|accessdate=21 May 2015}} On 26 May 2015 while speaking to the [[Chamber of Deputies of the Czech Republic|Chamber of Deputies]], Babiš said that he was forced to enter politics because of "corrupted opposition" (referring to the [[Civic Democratic Party (Czech Republic)|ODS]]) that "created him".{{cite web |url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/domaci/312823-babis-kalouskovi-ja-si-neznicim-jmeno-pro-nejake-drobne/ |title=Babiš Kalouskovi: "Já si nezničím jméno pro nějaké drobné" |date=26 May 2015 |publisher=Czech Television |language=Czech |accessdate=26 May 2015 |quote=Vy jste zapomněli, že jste mě stvořili – vy, zkorumpovaná pravice. Vždyť já jsem byl volič ODS. }} In November 2016, Babiš criticized alleged links among [[CEFC China Energy]], the [[Czech Social Democratic Party]], and Czech Prime Minister [[Bohuslav Sobotka]],{{cite news|url=http://byznys.lidovky.cz/cefc-je-zvlastni-investor-jestli-nam-chce-cina-pomoc-at-koupi-okd-rekl-babis-1uu-/firmy-trhy.aspx?c=A161106_131932_firmy-trhy_jko|title=CEFC je zvláštní investor. Jestli nám chce Čína pomoct, ať koupí OKD, řekl Babiš|language=Czech|work=Lidovky|date=6 November 2016}} saying that CEFC's focus on private Czech companies "brings no yield to the Czech Republic.""[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-cefc-china/chinas-cefc-has-big-ambitions-but-little-known-about-ownership-funding-idUSKBN14X0B5 China’s CEFC has big ambitions, but little known about ownership, funding]". Reuters. 13 January 2017. === European migrant crisis === In September 2015, deputy prime minister Babiš called for [[NATO]] intervention against human trafficking in the Mediterranean.{{cite news|url=http://www.radio.cz/en/section/news/finance-minister-andrej-babis-calls-on-nato-to-destroy-human-smugglers-ships|title=Finance Minister Andrej Babiš calls on NATO to destroy human smugglers’ ships|website=Radio Prague|date=9 September 2015}} After talks on the migrant crisis with NATO Secretary General [[Jens Stoltenberg]], Babiš said that "NATO is not interested in refugees, although Turkey, a NATO member, is their entrance gate to Europe and smugglers operate on Turkish territory"."[http://www.ceskenoviny.cz/news/zpravy/czech-minister-babis-criticises-nato-s-stance-on-refugees/1256815 Czech minister Babis criticises NATO´s stance on refugees]". CeskeNoviny.cz. 10 September 2015. Babiš rejected the European Union's [[European migrant crisis#European Union|refugee quotas]],{{cite news|url=http://praguemonitor.com/2016/08/04/pr%C3%A1vo-babi%C5%A1-would-reject-refugee-quotas-despite-sanctions|title=Právo: Babiš would reject refugee quotas despite sanctions|website=Prague Monitor|date=4 August 2016}} saying: "I will not accept refugee quotas [for the Czech Republic]. ... We must react to the needs and fears of the citizens of our country. We must guarantee the security of Czech citizens. Even if we are punished by sanctions."{{cite news|url=http://blog.praguemorning.cz/babis-reject-eu-refugee-quotas/|title=Babiš: “I reject the EU refugee quotas”|website=Prague Monitor|date=4 August 2016}} After the [[2016 Berlin attack]] he said that "unfortunately... [Angela Merkel's open-door migration] policy is responsible for this dreadful act. It was she who let migrants enter Germany and the whole of Europe in uncontrolled waves, without papers, therefore without knowing who they really are."{{cite news|url=https://uk.news.yahoo.com/czech-finance-minister-says-no-place-migrants-europe-164357785.html |title=Czech finance minister says 'no place' for migrants in Europe |agency=Reuters |website=[[Yahoo! News]] |date=20 December 2016}}"[http://www.euronews.com/2016/12/20/berlin-police-investigating-probable-terrorist-attack Berlin market attack: ISIL claims responsibility, prosecutors release main suspect, perpetrator potentially still at large]". [[Euronews]]. 20 December 2016. ===2017 government crisis=== Andrej Babiš was sacked from the [[Bohuslav Sobotka's Cabinet|government]] by Prime Minister [[Bohuslav Sobotka]] on 24 May 2017 after a month-long [[2017 Czech government crisis|coalition crisis]] triggered by allegations that Babiš avoided paying taxes as CEO of [[Agrofert]] in 2012. === Prime Minister (2017–present) === {{See also|Andrej Babiš' First Cabinet|Andrej Babiš' Second Cabinet}} [[File:V4 leaders Dec17.jpg|thumb|Andrej Babiš during his first full day in office with [[Visegrád Group|Visegrad Group]] leaders on 14 December 2017 at the [[European Council]].]] Following the [[Czech legislative election, 2017|2017 election]] to the [[Chamber of Deputies of the Czech Republic|Chamber of Deputies]], in which [[ANO 2011]] won with 29% of the vote, and won 78 out of 200 seats, President [[Miloš Zeman]] asked Babiš to form a government. The [[Civic Democratic Party (Czech Republic)|Civic Democratic Party]] and other parties refused to join a coalition government with Babis, citing the ongoing criminal investigation into alleged EU subsidy fraud and, as a result, on 27 October 2017 Babiš announced that he would try to form a [[minority government]]. [[Freedom and Direct Democracy]] (SPD) and the [[Communist Party of Bohemia and Moravia|Communist Party]] voiced their willingness to join the government, but were refused by Babiš.{{Cite web|url=https://zpravy.idnes.cz/babis-nova-vlada-mensinova-ano-odbornici-zeman-f4y-/domaci.aspx?c=A171027_111406_domaci_kop|title=Babiš navrhne menšinovou vládu ANO doplněnou o nestranické odborníky|date=2017-10-27|website=iDNES.cz|access-date=2017-12-08}} On 6 December 2017, Babiš was appointed the [[Prime Minister of the Czech Republic]]. He assumed the office on 13 December 2017, when his government took full control of the [[Government of the Czech Republic|executive government]]. He is the only incumbent head of government to be charged with a crime by the [[Police of the Czech Republic|Czech police]] and prosecutor, as well as both the oldest and the wealthiest Prime Minister in the country's history, and the first Prime Minister from a party other than [[Civic Democratic Party (Czech Republic)|ODS]] and [[Czech Social Democratic Party|ČSSD]]. During his first days in office, he attended the [[European Council]] summit dealing with fiscal responsibilities, [[Brexit]] and [[European migrant crisis|migration]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/premier-babis-discussed-the-future-of-the-euro-area-and-brexit-progress-with-european-statesmen-162296/|title=Premier Babiš discussed the future of the Euro Area and Brexit progress with European statesmen {{!}} Government of the Czech Republic|website=www.vlada.cz|language=en|access-date=2018-01-03}} and spoke on the phone with new Polish Prime Minister [[Mateusz Morawiecki]] regarding the [[Polish Constitutional Court crisis, 2015|invocation of the Article 7]] by the [[European Commission]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/premier-babis-spoke-on-the-phone-with-the-polish-prime-minister-morawiecki-162424/|title=Premier Babiš spoke on the phone with the Polish Prime Minister Morawiecki {{!}} Government of the Czech Republic|website=www.vlada.cz|language=en|access-date=2018-01-03}} His government carried out personnel changes at the ministries, [[České dráhy|Czech Railways]] and the [[Správa železniční dopravní cesty|Railway Infrastructure Administration]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.novinky.cz/ekonomika/458692-babisova-vlada-bez-duvery-vymenila-vetsinu-ridiciho-vyboru-ceskych-drah.html|title=Babišova vláda bez důvěry vyměnila většinu řídicího výboru Českých drah|work=Novinky.cz|access-date=2018-01-03|language=cs-CZ}} On 16 January 2018, Babiš's cabinet lost a [[Motion of no confidence|vote of no confidence]] by 117 votes to 78.{{cite web|last1=Muller|first1=Robert|title=Czech PM Babis battles fraud charges as cabinet loses confidence vote|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-czech-government-confidence/czech-pm-babis-battles-fraud-charges-as-cabinet-loses-confidence-vote-idUSKBN1F42QF?il=0|website=Reuters|accessdate=17 January 2018}} In February 2018, his cabinet approved the [[European Fiscal Compact]] and sent it to the Chamber of Deputies for further approval.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/ekonomika/2390659-vlada-po-sesti-letech-schvalila-pristoupeni-k-fiskalnimu-paktu-eu-hlasi-se-k|title=Vláda po šesti letech schválila přistoupení k fiskálnímu paktu EU. Hlásí se k vyrovnaným rozpočtům|work=[[ČT24]]|access-date=2018-02-23|language=cs}} They also proposed changes to the Civil Service Act, which has been the subject of controversy since it was passed in 2015 by [[Bohuslav Sobotka's Cabinet|Bohuslav Sobotka's government]], in which Babiš served as Minister of Finance.{{Cite web|url=https://zpravy.idnes.cz/vlada-zakon-o-statni-sluzbe-dft-/domaci.aspx?c=A180221_105134_domaci_kop|title=Vláda v demisi je pod palbou kritiky kvůli změně služebního zákona|date=2018-02-21|website=iDNES.cz|access-date=2018-02-23}} [[File:Informal dinner of EU heads of state or government (40347583080).jpg|thumb|Babiš with Bulgarian Prime Minister [[Boyko Borisov]], 16 May 2018]] After losing the confidence vote, Babiš's administration continued to carry out personnel changes, meeting with criticism from the opposition. Minister of Health [[Adam Vojtěch]] fired [[Svatopluk Němeček]], a former Minister and head of the University Hospital in [[Ostrava]], as well as the director of the [[Bulovka Hospital]]. Minister of Industry and Trade [[Tomáš Hüner]] and Minister of Interior [[Lubomír Metnar]] fired the heads of [[CzechInvest]] and [[Česká pošta|Czech Post]], respectively.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/domaci/2400022-personalni-zmeny-bez-duvery-vlada-ma-na-uctu-uz-nekolik-vysokych-hlav|title=Personální změny bez důvěry. Vláda má na účtu už několik vysokých hlav|work=[[ČT24]]|access-date=2018-02-23|language=cs}} In March 2018, Babiš ordered three [[Russia]]n diplomats to leave the country in a show of solidarity with the [[United Kingdom]] after a former Russian double agent [[Poisoning of Sergei and Yulia Skripal|Sergei Skripal was poisoned]] in [[Salisbury]].{{cite news |title=Czech Republic expels three Russian diplomats |url=http://www.radio.cz/en/section/news/czech-republic-expels-three-russian-diplomats |work=Radio Prague |date=26 March 2018}} In June 2018, German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] said that there had been "no moral or political justification" for the post-war [[Flight and expulsion of Germans (1944–50)|expulsion of ethnic Germans]] from Czechoslovakia. Babiš responded: "I reject this characterisation – especially when we recall the horrors of [[Reinhard Heydrich|Heydrich]], [[Lidice]], [[Ležáky]] and the killing of our paratroopers. I have the feeling that there is some internal political struggle in Germany now, and it is very unfortunate that old wounds are opening because of it."{{cite news |title=Merkel calls Sudeten German expulsion “immoral”, drawing Czech ire |url=http://www.radio.cz/en/section/curraffrs/merkel-calls-sudeten-german-expulsion-immoral-drawing-czech-ire |work=Czech Radio |date=21 June 2018}} In the summer of 2018, Babiš reached a coalition agreement with the [[Czech Social Democratic Party|Social Democrats]]. The new cabinet took office after winning a confidence vote on 12 July 2018, with support from the [[Communist Party of Bohemia and Moravia|Communist Party]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/1337401/world|title=Czech government wins confidence vote backed by Communists|date=12 July 2018|work=Arab News|access-date=21 August 2018}} == Controversies == === State Security Police (StB) agent === According to the documents of the [[National Memory Institute (Slovakia)|National Memory Institute]] in Slovakia, Babiš collaborated with the State Security Police ([[StB]]) of [[Czechoslovak Socialist Republic|communist Czechoslovakia]], under the [[code name]] agent Bureš. He denies the accusations, and in 2012 sued the institute for [[defamation]]. In January 2018, the Bratislava regional court ruled definitively that Babiš was an StB agent. This final court case may not be appealed.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/svet/2389540-babis-definitivne-prohral-soud-se-slovenskymi-historiky-zda-byl-ve-svazcich-stb|title=Babiš definitivně prohrál soud se slovenskými historiky, zda byl ve svazcích StB oprávněně|work=ČT24|access-date=2018-02-13|language=cs}}{{Cite news|url=https://domov.sme.sk/c/20759872/babis-definitivne-prehral-sud-s-upn-o-tom-ci-ho-moze-evidovat-v-zvazkoch-stb.html|title=Babiš definitívne prehral súd, ÚPN ho eviduje vo zväzkoch ŠTB oprávnene|last=a.s.|first=Petit Press|work=domov.sme.sk|access-date=2018-02-13|language=sk}} Twelve unrelated cases investigated by StB from 1982 to 1985 were associated with the code name Bureš, according to the Slovak National Memory Institute.{{cite web|url=http://echo24.cz/a/iuFqu/babisuv-soud-kvuli-stb---agent-bures-figuruje-ve-12-spisech|title=Babišův soud kvůli StB – agent Bureš figuruje ve 12 spisech|date=15 May 2014|publisher=Echo24.cz|language=Czech|accessdate=23 July 2014}} Babiš appeared once at the court during the process.{{cite web|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/domaci/260344-babis-se-pry-s-stb-nespolcil-vedome-soud-odrocen-na-duben/|title=Babiš se prý s StB nespolčil vědomě, soud odročen na duben|date=30 January 2014|publisher=CT24.cz|language=Czech|accessdate=23 July 2014}} The District Court in [[Bratislava]] issued a ruling on 26 June 2014 that there was insufficient evidence to put Andrej Babiš on a list of intentional cooperators with [[StB]].{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/slovak-court-says-andrej-babis-wrongly-labeled-communist-agent-1403787683|title=Court Says Andrej Babis Wrongly Labeled Communist Agent|date=26 June 2014|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=23 July 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.praguepost.com/eu-news/39817-slovak-press-criticizes-babis-court-decision|title=Slovak press criticizes Babiš court decision Slovak|date=27 June 2014|work=The Prague Post|accessdate=23 July 2014}} The decision was criticised in the Slovak press, and the National Memory Institute announced it would appeal to a higher court.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/06/26/slovak-court-czech-finance-minister-andrej-babis-was-not-communist-era-secret/|title=Slovak court: Czech Finance Minister Andrej Babiš was not a communist-era secret police agent|date=26 June 2014|publisher=Fox News Channel|accessdate=23 July 2014}} On 30 June 2015, Bratislava's County Court upheld the verdict,{{cite news|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/domaci/316219-potvrzeno-babis-ve-svazcich-stb-byt-nema/|title=Potvrzeno: Babiš ve svazcích StB být nemá|date=30 June 2015|publisher=[[ČT24]]|language=Czech|accessdate=30 June 2015}} but in October 2017 the Slovak Constitutional Court upheld the National Memorial Institute's appeal, annulling the earlier court decisions and finding that Babiš had been an agent of the former communist secret police.{{cite news|url=http://www.radio.cz/en/section/news/slovak-court-annuls-rulings-that-andrej-babis-wrongly-appeared-as-stb-agent|title=Slovak court annuls rulings that Andrej Babiš wrongly appeared as StB agent|date=12 October 2017|publisher=[[Czech Radio]]|language=English|accessdate=23 November 2017}} Babiš has also been accused of using his StB background and Communist Party connections to enrich himself.{{cn|date=April 2018}} Babiš has denied that he was a StB collaborator, but his close associates include Czech lawyer Libor Široký, now chairman of Agrofert's supervisory board, who is reportedly also a former member of one of the StB units most closely linked to the Soviet KGB.{{cite web|last=Drda |first=Adam |url=http://www.politico.eu/article/andrej-babis-czech-oligarch/ |title=Andrej Babiš – Czech oligarch – Politico |website=[[politico.eu]] |date=25 January 2016 |accessdate=21 October 2017}} Critics{{who|date=April 2018}} who accuse him of KGB connections also point When a Lebanese arms dealer with alleged Russian connections was released by Czech authorities instead of being extradited to the United States, and it was revealed that every official involved in the |url=http://dailycaller.com/2016/02/10/czech-prime-minister-defends-release-of-hezbollah-terror-suspect/ |title=Czech Prime Minister Defends Release of Hezbollah Terror Suspect |work=The Daily Caller |date=1 December 2015 |accessdate=23 February 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.ceskenoviny.cz/zpravy/1585445|title=Politiky rozhodnutí soudu o Babišovi a StB nepřekvapilo {{!}} Politici na verdikt o Babišovi reagují dost drsně {{!}} EuroZprávy.cz|last=EuroZprávy.cz|access-date=2018-02-13|language=en}} Opposition MP [[Miroslav Kalousek]] said that it no longer mattered what information the Slovak National Memory Institute had about Babiš, because his behaviour as a politician had proven his StB training.{{cite web|url=http://www.novinky.cz/domaci/372677-babis-vyvolal-v-politice-poprask-potvrdil-vycvik-u-stb-rekl-kalousek.html|title=Babiš vyvolal v politice poprask: Potvrdil výcvik u StB, řekl Kalousek|work=novinky.cz|accessdate=24 October 2015}} In March 2015, Babiš condemned Russia's [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexation of Crimea]]."[https://www.novinky.cz/domaci/363482-rozdeleni-ukrajiny-by-bylo-jako-obetovani-ceskoslovenska-z-roku-1938-mini-babis.html Rozdělení Ukrajiny by bylo jako obětování Československa z roku 1938, míní Babiš]" (in Czech). Novinky. 6 March 2015. In October 2015 [[Anne Applebaum]], a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist specializing in Russian and Eastern European affairs, listed Babiš among several Eastern European leaders who she considered to be agents of influence for Putin's Russia. Writing in ''[[The Washington Post]]'', she suggested that old labels from Soviet Communist days, such as "useful idiots" and "fellow travelers", were no longer adequate to describe Babis and the other figures she had named. To illustrate her point, she listed several quotes from each leader that sounded very similar to each other and to the arguments broadcast at the same time by official Russian news sources.{{cite web|last=Applebaum |first=Anne |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/neither-agents-of-influence-nor-useful-idiots/2015/10/16/73fdc478-7423-11e5-8248-98e0f5a2e830_story.html |title=Russia's new kind of friends |work=The Washington Post |date=16 October 2015 |accessdate=23 February 2017}} Babiš responded to Applebaum with a letter to ''[[The Washington Post]]'' stating that he had no friends in Russia and was an American ally. US journalist [[Gabriel Meyr]] challenged those claims by citing three examples of actions Babiš has taken that have furthered Russian policy goals,{{cite web|author=Gabriel Meyr |url=http://dailycaller.com/2015/12/01/putin-hiding-under-a-czech-candle/ |title=Putin Hiding Under A Czech Candle |work=The Daily Caller |date=1 December 2015 |accessdate=23 February 2017}} such as a [[Wenceslas Square]] to protest that Babiš was advancing an agenda that would infringe Czech freedoms, described by leaders of the protest as a quiet revolution, happening in gradual steps.{{cite web|url=http://www.praguemonitor.com/2016/02/26/finmins-opponents-warn-his-creeping-freedom-restriction |title=FinMin's opponents warn of his creeping freedom restriction |publisher=Prague Monitor |date=26 February 2016 |accessdate=23 February 2017}} === EU subsidies fraud === [[File:Semtín, pohled na Čapí hnízdo.jpg|thumb|The farm, owned by one of Babiš' companies, which according to [[Police of the Czech Republic|police]] and [[European Anti-Fraud Office|OLAF]] received illegal subsidy from the European Union.]] [[File:Čapí hnízdo - Olbramovice. (06).jpg|thumb|An [[equestrian facility]] of the farm resembles [[stork]]'s [[nest]].]] Babiš was accused of illegally obtaining €2 million in EU subsidies designated for small businesses by concealing his ownership of a farm and a convention center called "Storks Nest".{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-czech-politics-babis/czech-police-ask-parliament-to-allow-prosecution-of-pm-candidate-babis-idUSKBN1AQ208|title=Czech police ask parliament to allow prosecution of PM candidate Babis|date=10 August 2017|work=Reuters|access-date=22 November 2017}} Czech police requested that the Lower House lift his parliamentary immunity on two occasions, in September and November 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/andrej-babis-czech-police-seek-to-prosecute-prospective-pm-for-alleged-fraud/a-41467109|title=Andrej Babis: Czech police seek to prosecute prospective PM for alleged fraud|date=21 November 2017|website=Deutsche Welle|language=en|access-date=16 April 2018}} In both cases the Lower House lifted the immunity and the police have initiated criminal proceedings.{{cite news|url=https://zpravy.aktualne.cz/domaci/online-snemovna/r~332899d2fa1311e7b6830cc47ab5f122/?_ga=2.210628245.1686128042.1516031095-1459700410.1511207770|title=Živě: Poslanci vydali Babiše a Faltýnka policii. Absolutní nesmysl, brání se místopředseda ANO|website=Aktuálně.cz|date=16 January 2018}} He is accused of the crime of alleged fraud (§212,Criminal Code, 2009) and of wilful damage to the financial interests of the [[European Union]] (§ 260, Criminal Code, 2009) in the criminal conspiracy (§ 89, Art.17, Crime Code (the Czechoslovakian Criminal Code, 1961).{{cite news|url=https://zpravy.aktualne.cz/domaci/policie-znovu-zada-o-vydani-poslancu-babise-a-faltynka-chtej/r~8b0c4e5ace9911e79704ac1f6b220ee8/?_ga=2.166510014.123805066.1511207770-1459700410.1511207770/|title=Policie znovu žádá o vydání Babiše a Faltýnka. Systém se mě urputně snaží dostat, říká šéf ANO|trans-title=Czech police again seek to prosecute Babiš and Faltýnek|language=cs}} This case was investigated by the [[European Anti-Fraud Office]] (OLAF). OLAF's final report was delivered to the Czech officers of the Ministry of Finance on 27 December 2017.{{cite news|url=https://www.byznysnoviny.cz/2018/01/03/kalousek-zpravu-olaf-cetl-urad-potvrdil-podvod-babis-se-snazi-utajit-zlodejnu/|title=Kalousek: Zprávu OLAF jsem četl. Úřad potvrdil podvod, Babiš se snaží utajit zlodějnu|trans-title=Kalousek: I read the OLAF report. The office confirmed the fraud, Babis is trying to hide the theft|language=cs|date=3 January 2018|work=Byznys Noviny}}[http://test2.praguemonitor.com/2018/01/02/meps-demand-olaf-report-case-related-pm-babi%C5%A1]{{deadlink|date=April 2018}} (in English) Journalist Sabina Slonková published a report of the results on the website Neovlivni.cz on 3 January 2018, concluding that OLAF's final report confirmed the results of the investigation by the Czech Police and prosecutors that the fraud was planned from the beginning.{{cite news|url=http://neovlivni.cz/co-stoji-ve-zprave-olaf-o-premierove-capim-hnizde/|title=Co Stojí Ve Zprávě Olaf o Premiérovĕ Čapím Hnízdĕ|language=cs|first=Sabina|last=Slonková|date=3 January 2018|website=neovlivni.cz}} The complete text of the final report translated into Czech was published on the website aktualne.cz on 11 January 2018, with a commentary by Vladimir Piskacek, one of the directors of the Economia AS media company, which publishes ''[[Hospodářské noviny]]'', defending the right to publish information openly.{{cite news|url=https://zpravy.aktualne.cz/domaci/zprava-olaf-capi-hnizdo-kompletni-andrej-babis/r~e4e4d5c8f62111e7984d0cc47ab5f122/|title=Zveřejňujeme kompletní znění závěrečné zprávy OLAF o vyšetřování dotace na Farmu Čapí hnízdo|date=11 January 2018|website=aktualne.cz|language=Czech}} === Alleged son kidnapping === In November 2018, Seznam News television aired an interview with Babiš' son Andrej Babiš Junior (born 1982) in which he alleged he was kidnapped by his father's associate in order to thwart corruption inquiry regarding [[Andrej Babiš#EU subsidies fraud|Stork's Nest Farm]].{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/czech-pm-andrej-babis-accused-of-kidnapping-son-to-avert-corruption-inquiry-60jtxs63v|title=Czech PM Andrej Babis accused of kidnapping son to thwart corruption inquiry|website=thetimes.co.uk}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/nov/13/czech-pm-andrej-babis-future-hangs-in-balance-after-sons-kidnap-claims|title=Czech PM's future hangs in balance after son's kidnap claims|website=theguardian.com}} Babiš Junior was quoted as saying he had been held in [[Crimea]], [[Kaliningrad]], [[Moscow]] and [[Kryvyi Rih]] in Ukraine to stop him from giving statement to the police about his involvement in the case. Prime Minister Babiš denied the kidnapping but admitted that his son entered Crimea, among others, while saying that his son suffers from [[schizophrenia]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-46194329|title=Andrej Babis: Czech PM denies son was kidnapped|website=bbc.com}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.seznamzpravy.cz/clanek/prulomove-svedectvi-v-kauze-capi-hnizdo-slonkova-a-kubik-vypatrali-zmizeleho-babisova-syna-60198?utm_source=Seznamzpravy_static&utm_medium=babisuv-syn-doporucene-clanky&utm_campaign=doporucene-clanky-special|title=Průlomové svědectví v kauze Čapí hnízdo. Slonková a Kubík vypátrali zmizelého Babišova syna - Seznam Zprávy|website=www.seznamzpravy.cz|access-date=2018-11-16}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.novinky.cz/domaci/489178-protopopov-babise-jr-jsem-neunesl-staral-jsem-se-o-nej-jako-o-bratra.html|title=Protopopov: Babiše jr. jsem neunesl, staral jsem se o něj jako o bratra|work=Novinky.cz|access-date=2018-11-16|language=cs-CZ}} ===Partnership with Zeman=== Babiš has been linked closely to President [[Miloš Zeman]] since at least 2001, when Zeman was [[Prime Minister of the Czech Republic|Prime Minister]], and his business interests are alleged to have benefited from the association. In 2001, Zeman oversaw the sale of [[Unipetrol]], a state-owned chemical company, to Babiš. Babiš pulled out of the sale, but later oversaw the sale of the firm to a Polish company. According to Polish reports, the sale was accompanied by substantial bribery, although Babis denies any bribes were paid.{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304192124/http://www.wprost.pl/ar/76068/Unipetrol-bez-lapowki-aktl/|title=Unipetrol bez łapówki? aktl. – WPROST|date=4 March 2016}} The Unipetrol deal is cited often as evidence of a strong partnership between Babiš and Zeman that persists.{{cite web|trans-title=Zeman and Babiš have bad news for Sobotka. He won't like it.|title=Zeman a Babiš mají pro Sobotku špatnou zprávu. Toto se mu nebude líbit|url=http://domaci.eurozpravy.cz/politika/90569-zeman-a-babis-maji-pro-sobotku-spatnou-zpravu-toto-se-mu-nebude-libit/|website=Domaci.eurozpravy.cz|accessdate=23 February 2017}} === Conflicts of interest === [[File:Ing Andrej Babis.png|thumbnail|right|Connections between companies in the AGROFERT portfolio]] Babis has been criticized by media and opposition politicians for his alleged [[conflict of interest]],{{cite web|url=http://www.novinky.cz/domaci/325603-kalousek-babis-nebude-na-ministerstvu-ve-stretu-zajmu-jen-na-zachode.html|title=Kalousek: Babiš nebude na ministerstvu ve střetu zájmů jen na záchodě|date=25 January 2014|publisher=[[novinky.cz]]|language=Czech|accessdate=27 March 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/porady/1126672097-otazky-vaclava-moravce/215411030501004/|title=Otázky Václava Moravce|work=Česká televize|accessdate=24 October 2015}} as the Minister of Finance and the owner of companies subsidized by EU funding programmes. During a visit to the Czech Republic in March 2014, the German [[Member of the European Parliament]] [[Ingeborg Gräßle]] expressed concern that someone with such a personal financial interest simultaneously being a leading representative of a state, could not guarantee to the EU that its resources are properly distributed.{{cite web|url=http://zpravy.idnes.cz/europoslankyne-kritizuje-babisuv-stret-zajmu-flg-/domaci.aspx?c=A140327_141015_domaci_jav|title=Europoslankyně: Babiš je ve vážném střetu zájmů, měl by se vzdát firem|date=27 March 2014|work=[[Mladá fronta DNES]]|accessdate=27 March 2014}} A 2014 article in the political newspaper ''[[Politico]]'' commented that "the Czech Republic is now a paradox: a society disgusted with corruption has given huge power to a man whose business interests amount to the biggest conflict of interest in the country’s post-1989 history." In May 2015, Babis's alleged financial irregularities and accusations from the public and the opposition that he had promoted his companies in [[Government procurement in the European Union|government procurements]] triggered a [[Czech Republic Government Vote of No Confidence, 2015|vote of no confidence against the Bohuslav Sobotka's government]], called by the opposition parties [[Civic Democratic Party (Czech Republic)|ODS]], [[TOP 09]], and [[Dawn of Direct Democracy|Dawn]]. The motion was defeated by 47-105.{{cite news|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/domaci/312883-opozice-s-vyslovenim-neduvery-sobotkove-vlade-neuspela/|title=Opozice s vyslovením nedůvěry Sobotkově vládě neuspěla|date=26 June 2014|publisher=[[ČT24]]|accessdate=17 June 2015}} On 5 June 2015, a retired senior American intelligence officer published an opinion article using Babiš as an example of a corrupt politician with conflicts of interest and probable ties to Russia. In the article, he speculated whether United States government investigations into bribery and corruption in FIFA may herald more aggressive investigation of other corrupt practices. The article mentioned that several investigations had been launched by a team of police and prosecutor, which were questionable cases that did not hold up in court.{{cite web|url=http://dailycaller.com/2015/06/05/do-fifa-arrests-presage-further-investigations-in-europe/2/|title=Do FIFA Arrests Presage Further Investigations in Europe?|work=The Daily Caller|accessdate=24 October 2015}} === Intimidation === Babiš has a reputation for surrounding himself with senior police officers, security agents, and former Communist informers. In June 2015, Babiš provoked controversy when a member of parliament, Ladislav Šincl of the [[Czech Social Democratic Party|Social Democrats]] (ČSSD), criticised a change in policy from the Finance Ministry on a bill reducing commissions for life insurance mediators in the Chamber of Deputies, and alleged that the benefits to Babiš's business interests may be the cause of the change.{{cite web|url=http://www.ceskenoviny.cz/news/zpravy/czech-cssd-wants-finmin-babis-to-apologise-for-stb-like-conduct/1228928|title=Czech CSSD wants FinMin Babis to apologise for "StB-like" conduct|author=ČTK|work=ceskenoviny.cz|accessdate=24 October 2015}} On 17 June 2015, Babiš met with Šincl and accused him of corruption and taking bribes from businessman and senator [[Ivo Valenta]], owner of the Synot gambling group. According to witnesses, Babiš brought to the meeting a folder marked with a yellow note labelled ''Šincl'', and started shouting at Šincl that he knew Šincl took bribes from Valenta and was corrupt. He later moved onto his family and Šincl's former jobs.{{cite web|url=http://m.ihned.cz/c1-64188810-babisovy-metody-pripominaji-stb-stezuje-si-cssd-babis-neomluvim-se-sincl-lze|title=Babiš po jednání koaliční rady: Se Šinclem se sejdu, omlouvat se ale nebudu|work=Hospodářské noviny|accessdate=24 October 2015}} On 18 June 2015, Babiš admitted he had a folder with Šincl's name, but denied intimidation, saying, "It's not the materials. It's articles from the media. Do the media write lies? I just showed what the media writes, I think they do their job well. When I go to a meeting, I prepare myself so I know who I am dealing with". Babiš's coalition partners [[Czech Social Democratic Party|ČSSD]] (Šincl's party) and [[Christian and Democratic Union – Czechoslovak People's Party|KDU-ČSL]] demanded an apology, but Babiš refused, saying that Šincl had lied about him in the [[Chamber of Deputies of the Parliament of the Czech Republic|Parliament]]. Prime Minister [[Bohuslav Sobotka]], also the chairman of ČSSD, called a coalition meeting on the same day.{{cite news |url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/domaci/315035-babis-sinclovi-se-neomluvim-informace-o-nem-jsem-cerpal-z-medii/ |title=Babiš: Šinclovi se neomluvím, informace o něm jsem čerpal z médií |date=18 June 2015 |publisher=[[ČT24]] |accessdate=18 June 2015 |quote=Nejsou to materiály. Jsou to články médií. Píšou média lži?... Vytáhl jsem si, co média píšou, předpokládám, že dělají svou práci dobře... Když jdu na nějaké jednání, tak se připravím, abych věděl, s kým jdu jednat.}} Šincl described Babiš' tactic, of reading potentially damaging facts about him from a file marked with his name, was reminiscent of StB tactics. [[Miroslav Kalousek]], the first deputy chairman of the opposition party [[TOP09]], also accused Babiš of using StB practices, which Babiš denied.{{cite news|url=http://radio.cz/en/section/news/finance-minister-babis-under-fire-for-sincl-incident|title=Finance Minister Babiš under fire for Šincl incident|date=18 June 2015|publisher=[[Czech Radio]]|accessdate=18 June 2015}} === MF Dnes leaked tapes === On 1 May 2017, Twitter account @skupinasuman posted a tape of Babiš's private conversations with an unknown number of people, in which he labelled Minister of Foreign Affairs [[Lubomír Zaorálek]] as an "idiot" and attacked investigative journalist Sabina Slonková, among others. On 3 May 2017, a video on YouTube alleged that Andrej Babiš had interfered with the editorial independence of ''[[Mladá fronta DNES]]'', the nation's largest quality newspaper by circulation, owned by Babis's trust. In conversation with MF Dnes journalist [[Marek Přibil]] he discusses the date of publication of damaging stories about Minister of Interior [[Milan Chovanec]] and Minister of Health [[Miloslav Ludvík]]. On the tape, Babiš is recorded instructing Přibil to tell František Nachtigall, the director of strategic development, about when and how to publish the stories. === Comments about Lety concentration camp === On 1 September 2016, while visiting [[Varnsdorf]], a city with large [[Romani people in the Czech Republic|Romani population]], Babiš said: "What those idiots [journalists] write in newspapers, that the [[Lety concentration camp|camp in Lety]] was a concentration camp, that is a lie, it was a [[labor camp]], people who didn't work ended up there".{{cite news |url=http://zpravy.aktualne.cz/domaci/babis-na-romech-parazituje-pritom-se-o-ne-nikdy-nezajimal-re/r~5e1850de711511e6888a0025900fea04/ |title=Sobotka: Babiš se o Romy nikdy nezajímal, teď na nich parazituje. Překročil hranici náckovství |date=2 September 2016 |language=Czech |quote=To, co píší v novinách ti blbečci, že tábor v Letech byl koncentrák, to je lež, byl to pracovní tábor. Kdo nepracoval, šup a byl tam. }} Babiš's comments were heavily criticized by both coalition partners and opposition MPs calling on him to resign. Prime Minister [[Bohuslav Sobotka]] condemned the remarks on Facebook, saying that "between [[populism]] and extremism there is a thin line and Babiš crossed it" and asked him to "properly apologize and visit Lety to learn about history of our state."{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} Minister for Human Rights and Equal Opportunities [[Jiří Dienstbier Jr.|Jiří Dienstbier]] called for Babiš to step down as Finance Minister and First Deputy Prime Minister.{{cite news|url=http://radio.cz/en/section/news/finance-minister-apologises-for-comments-about-romanies-and-lety-camp|title=Finance Minister apologises for comments about Romanies and Lety camp|date=2 September 2016|publisher=[[Czech Radio]]}} The leaders of both opposition parties, [[Petr Fiala]] from [[Civic Democratic Party (Czech Republic)|ODS]] and [[Miroslav Kalousek]] from [[TOP 09]] also called for Babiš to step down.{{cite news|url=http://echo24.cz/a/iuQ75/musi-odejit-zadaji-politici-hlavu-babise-za-zpochybnovani-holocaustu|title=Musí odejít, žádají politici hlavu Babiše za zpochybňování holocaustu |date=2 September 2016|publisher=Echo24}} ==Media criticism== ''[[Foreign Policy]]'' magazine gave Babis the nickname ''Babisconi'', a portmaneau of his surname and the surname of former Italian Prime Minister [[Silvio Berlusconi]], the subject of numerous political and financial scandals.{{cite news|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2015/04/10/now-the-czechs-have-an-oligarch-problem-too-andrej-babis/|title=Now the Czechs Have an Oligarch Problem, Too|date=10 April 2015|work=[[Foreign Policy]]|accessdate=17 June 2015}} In response, Babiš threatened to sue the magazine, but has never done so.{{cite news|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/svet/308183-babis-jde-do-boje-s-americkym-listem-snuska-lzi-na-objednavku-z-ceska/|title=Babiš jde do boje s americkým listem: Snůška lží na objednávku z Česka|date=17 April 2015|publisher=[[ČT24]]|accessdate=17 June 2015}} In August 2015, the Swiss weekly ''[[L'Hebdo]]'' published an article entitled: "Why do Czech Oligarchs Buy Unprofitable Media Outlets?" examining the purchase of media companies by several Czech business people, and also their connections with Francophone Switzerland. The article focused much of its attention on Babiš, and his purchase of media outlets in the Czech Republic. The author pointed out that Babiš had claimed to invest in ''[[Mladá fronta DNES]]'' only for profit, but had given no answer when told it was an unprofitable investment, and went on to accuse journalists at Babis's newspapers of doing his work.{{cite web|url=http://www.hebdo.ch/hebdo/cadrages/detail/oligarques-tch%C3%A8ques-pourquoi-ils-aiment-la-presse-et-la-suisse-romande|title=Oligarques tchèques: pourquoi ils aiment la presse... et la Suisse romande|work=hebdo.ch|accessdate=24 October 2015}} Writing in ''Politico'', Adam Drda expressed the view that Andrej Babis is associated with the decline of Czech democracy more than any other single person. [[File:Monika Babišová a Andrej Babiš 2015.JPG|thumb|Andrej Babiš with his then-partner (now wife) Monika in 2015]] Andrej Babiš was a winner of the Green Pearl prize for the anti-ecological comment of the year 2013: "We all gave a shit about democracy once. How to explain that regarding the construction of a new highway, (someone has the right to talk about) a badger, an ecological terrorist and that each mayor wants an exit (to his town)."https://zpravy.aktualne.cz/domaci/ropakem-roku-je-milos-zeman/r~043c4414cbed11e399e0002590604f2e/ Winners of the anti-ecologic prizes (in Czech) == Personal life == Babiš' first wife was physician Beata (later Beatrice) Adamičová, a schoolmate, who he married in the 1970s.{{Cite book|url=|title=Babiš : příběh oligarchy|last=Pergler|first=Tomáš|publisher=Mladá fronta|year=2014|isbn=9788020434456|edition=První vydání|location=Praha|pages=|language=Czech|oclc=899728531}} They had two children, Adriana (born 1979) and Andrej (born 1982), both of whom were involved in the [[Andrej Babiš#EU subsidies fraud|Stork's Nest case]].{{Cite news|url=https://hlidacipes.org/babisovy-deti-jako-bili-kone-sveho-otce/|title=Babišovy děti jako bílí koně svého otce? Kvůli Čapímu hnízdu je vystavil zájmu policie i možnému trestnímu stíhání — HlídacíPes.org|date=2017-08-15|work=HlídacíPes.org|access-date=2018-07-13|language=cs-CZ}} Since 2007 Adriana has been married to Agrofert manager Martin Bobek. Since the 1990s Babiš has lived with his former secretary Monika Herodesová (born 1974), with whom he has two children, Vivien and Frederik.{{cite news|url=http://ona.idnes.cz/monika-babisova-rozhovor-0hy-/spolecnost.aspx?c=A140520_182325_spolecnost_jup|title=Monika Babišová: S Andrejem jsem 20 let, přitom se prý k sobě nehodíme|date=26 May 2014|publisher=[[MAFRA]]|accessdate=11 July 2015}} Both Monika and her brother Martin Herodes were also involved in the Stork's Nest case. In 2013 Monika changed her surname to Babišová, and they married in 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://www.praguemonitor.com/2017/07/31/ano-leader-babi%C5%A1-marries-his-long-term-partner-monika|title=ANO [[Albany Law School]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) |website = {{url|governor.ny.gov|Government website}} }} '''Andrew Mark Cuomo''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|w|oʊ|m|oʊ}}; born December 6, 1957) is an American politician, author and lawyer serving as the [[List of Governors of New York|56th]] and current [[Governor of New York]] since 2011. A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], he was elected to the same position his father, [[Mario Cuomo]], held for three terms. Born in [[New York City]], Cuomo is a graduate of [[Fordham University]] and [[Albany Law School]] of [[Union University (New York)|Union University, New York]]. He began his career working as the campaign manager for his father, then as an assistant district attorney in New York City before entering private law practice. He founded Housing Enterprise for the Less Privileged (HELP USA) and was appointed chair of the New York City Homeless Commission, a position he held from 1990 to 1993. In 1993, Cuomo joined the [[Presidency of Bill Clinton|Clinton Administration]] as Assistant Secretary for Community Planning and Development in the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development]]. From 1997 to 2001, he served as the [[United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development|U.S. Secretary of Housing and Urban Development]]. In 2006, Cuomo was elected [[New York State Attorney General|Attorney General of New York]]. In May 2010, Cuomo announced he was running for governor in the [[New York gubernatorial election, 2010|2010 election]], and he won with 63 percent of the vote. Cuomo has emerged as one of the United States' most [[progressivism in the United States|progressive]] governors; during his first term, New York legalized [[Same-sex marriage in New York|same-sex marriage]] and enacted [[gun control]] legislation. In 2014, he was [[New York gubernatorial election, 2014|elected to a second term]] with 54 percent of the vote. In 2018, he was elected for a [[New York gubernatorial election, 2018|third term]] with 58% of the vote. {{toclimit|3}} == Early life and education == Cuomo was born in the [[Queens]] borough of [[New York City]],{{cite web| url = http://www.biography.com/people/andrew-cuomo-21024931 | title=Andrew Cuomo Biography: Government Official, Lawyer (1957–)| publisher= [[Biography.com]] ([[FYI (TV channel)|FYI]] / [[A&E Networks]]) | accessdate= May 25, 2015}} the elder son born to lawyer and later governor of New York, [[Mario Cuomo]] and Matilda (née Raffa).{{cite news|first=Peter|last=Blauner|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=--cCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA35|title=All Star Family Feud: The Governor's In-Laws Battle Over a Father's Legacy|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|date=February 13, 1989|accessdate=December 6, 2010}} His parents were both of [[Italian-American|Italian]] descent; his paternal grandparents were from [[Nocera Inferiore]] and [[Tramonti, Campania|Tramonti]] in South Italy, while his maternal grandparents were both from [[Sicily]] (his grandfather from [[Messina]]).{{cite news| first =Michael| last =Arena | author2 =Marianne Arneberg |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/newsday/access/104068528.html?dids=104068528:104068528&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+20%2C+1988&author=By+Michael+Arena+and+Marianne+Arneberg&pub=Newsday+(Combined+editions)&desc=Cuomo's+Father-in-Law+Dies&pqatl=google|title=Cuomo's Father-in-Law Dies|work=[[Newsday]]|date=October 20, 1988|accessdate=November 24, 2012}} His younger brother, [[Chris Cuomo]], is a [[CNN]] journalist.{{cite news|first=Michael|last=Barbaro|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/24/nyregion/24sexiest.html|title=All That Time Serving the Public? Very Sexy|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 23, 2010|accessdate=December 6, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101125130807/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/24/nyregion/24sexiest.html| archivedate= November 25, 2010 | deadurl= no}} He graduated from St. Gerard Majella's School in 1971Campanile, Carl. "[https://nypost.com/2015/05/13/cuomo-and-cardinal-dolan-tout-parochial-school-tax-break/ Cuomo and Cardinal Dolan tout parochial school tax break]," ''New York Post'', May 13, 2015. and [[Archbishop Molloy High School]] in 1975. He received a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] from [[Fordham University]] in 1979, and a [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] from [[Albany Law School]] in 1982. == Early career == During his father's [[New York gubernatorial election, 1982|1982 campaign for Governor]], Cuomo was campaign manager, and then joined the Governor's staff as one of his father's top policy advisors and sometime-Albany roommate,Smith, Chris. "[http://nymag.com/news/features/andrew-cuomo-2013-4/ The Albany Machiavelli]," New York, April 14, 2013. earning $1 a year.{{cite news |first=Patrice|last=O'Shaughnessy|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/2009/09/27/2009-09-27_andrew_cuomo_from_horror_on_the_hudson_to_democrats_chosen_son.html |title=Andrew Cuomo: From Horror on the Hudson to Democrats' chosen son|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|location=New York |date=September 27, 2009|accessdate=December 6, 2010}} From 1984 to 1985, Cuomo was a New York assistant district attorney, and briefly worked at the law firm of Blutrich, Falcone & Miller. He founded Housing Enterprise for the Less Privileged (HELP) in 1986 and left his law firm to run HELP full-time in 1988.{{cite web|url=http://www.theithacajournal.com/article/20101023/NEWS01/10230393/Andrew-Cuomo-bio-box |title=Andrew Cuomo bio box |work=[[The Ithaca Journal]] |date=October 23, 2010 |accessdate=November 13, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} From 1990 to 1993, during the administration of [[Mayor of New York City|New York City mayor]], [[David Dinkins]], Cuomo was chair of the New York City Homeless Commission, which was charged with developing policies to address the homeless issue in the city and developing more housing options.{{cite book |last=Romano |first=Anne |title=Italian Americans In Law Enforcement |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OB0wOgBbHHkC&pg=PA61&lpg=PA61&dq=Cuomo+served+as+Chairman+of+the+New+York+City+Homeless+Commission,#v=onepage&q=Cuomo%20served%20as%20Chairman%20of%20the%20New%20York%20City%20Homeless%20Commission%2C |accessdate=May 12, 2013 |year=2010 |publisher=Xlibris, Corp. |location=Bloomington, IN |isbn=1-4535-5880-2 |page=61}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}} == Secretary of HUD == [[File:HUD Secretary Andrew Cuomo.jpg|thumb|left|220px|Cuomo as HUD Secretary]] Andrew Cuomo was appointed to the [[Department of Housing and Urban Development]] as Assistant Secretary for Community Planning and Development in 1993, a member of President [[Bill Clinton]]'s administration. After the departure of Secretary [[Henry Cisneros]] at the end of Clinton's first term under the cloud of an FBI investigation,{{cite news | last =Evans | first =Judith | title =HUD's Cisneros to Leave a Legacy of Public Housing Reform | work =[[The Washington Post]] | page =E01 | date =November 30, 1996 | url =https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/cisneros/stories/cis113096.htm | accessdate =January 12, 2011 }} Cuomo was unanimously confirmed by the [[United States Senate]] to succeed him as [[Secretary of HUD]]. Cuomo served as Secretary from January 1997 until the Clinton administration ended in 2001. In 2000, Cuomo led HUD efforts to negotiate an agreement with the United States' largest handgun manufacturer, [[Smith & Wesson]], that required Smith & Wesson to change the design, distribution and marketing of guns to make them safer and to help keep them out of the hands of children and criminals.{{cite web|url=http://archives.hud.gov/secretaries/cuomobio.cfm |title=Andrew M. Cuomo |publisher=Archives, U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development |accessdate=May 20, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100527090837/http://archives.hud.gov/secretaries/cuomobio.cfm| archivedate= May 27, 2010 | deadurl= no}} Budgets enacted during his term contained initiatives to increase the supply of affordable housing and home ownership, and to create jobs and economic development. These included new rental assistance subsidies, reforms to integrate public housing, higher limits on mortgages insured by the [[Federal Housing Administration]], a crackdown on housing discrimination, expanded programs to help homeless people get housing and jobs, and creation of new [[Empowerment Zone]]s. [[File:CuomoSummers.jpg|thumb|upright|Cuomo as HUD Secretary holding a press conference with then Treasury Secretary [[Larry Summers]]]] During Cuomo's tenure as HUD Secretary, he called for an increase in home ownership.{{cite web|url=http://www.buffalonews.com/city/article50994.ece |title=Cuomo's HUD career under scrutiny |work=[[The Buffalo News]] |date=August 21, 2010|accessdate=September 17, 2010|first=Phil|last=Fairbanks| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100825154017/http://www.buffalonews.com/city/article50994.ece| archivedate= August 25, 2010 | deadurl= no}} He also pushed government-sponsored lenders [[Fannie Mae]] and [[Freddie Mac]] to buy more home loans issued to poor homeowners, in an attempt to end discrimination against minorities.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/24/nyregion/24hud.html |title=As HUD Chief, Cuomo Earns a Mixed Score |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 23, 2010 |author1=David M. Halbfinger |author2=Michael Powell |accessdate=September 17, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140127034455/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/24/nyregion/24hud.html |archivedate=January 27, 2014 |deadurl=no }} Some believe that this helped lead to the recent [[subprime mortgage crisis]].{{cite web|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2008-08-05/news/how-andrew-cuomo-gave-birth-to-the-crisis-at-fannie-mae-and-freddie-mac/ |title=Andrew Cuomo and Fannie and Freddie |work=[[The Village Voice]] |date=August 5, 2008 |accessdate=September 17, 2010 |first=Wayne |last=Barrett |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722145449/http://www.villagevoice.com/2008-08-05/news/how-andrew-cuomo-gave-birth-to-the-crisis-at-fannie-mae-and-freddie-mac/ |archivedate=July 22, 2010 }} Edward J. Pinto, former chief credit officer at Fannie Mae, said "they should have known the risks were large. Cuomo was pushing mortgage bankers to make loans and basically saying you have to offer a loan to everybody." But others disagree with the assessment that Cuomo caused the crisis. [[Dean Baker]], co-director of the [[Center for Economic and Policy Research]], said Cuomo "was a contributor in terms of him being a cheerleader, but I don't think we can pin too much blame on him." According to libertarian author and critic [[James Bovard]], Cuomo was obsessed with changing HUD's image, as Cuomo declared, "The PR is the important thing I do ... Eighty percent of the battle is communications." He championed a new program called Community Builders, created without appropriation by Congress, for 800 new HUD employees with computers to be paid as much as $100,000. In a June 16, 1999, speech, Cuomo declared that one purpose of the program was to fight against HUD's abolition. In August 1999, Community Builders distributed a letter to community groups to fight against proposed tax cuts. One HUD official declared that Community Builders were seen as "Democratic [[ward heeler]]s who act as a pipeline between Democratic city officials, party leaders, and the administration and the [[Democratic National Committee]]." In 1998, Clinton-appointed HUD Inspector General Susan Gaffney testified to a Senate committee that she was the victim of "'escalating' attacks on her office by Cuomo and 'his key aides,' including cooked-up charges of racism, insubordination, malfeasance, and general dirty-dealing." In 1999, Gaffney's office concluded that "most (15 out of 19) Community Builders' goals were activities rather than actual accomplishments." and that Cuomo's initiatives "had a crippling effect on many of HUD's ongoing operations."{{cite book | first=James | last=Bovard | authorlink=James Bovard | year= 2000 | title= Feeling Your Pain: The Explosion and Abuse Of Government Power in the Clinton-Gore Years | publisher= St. Martin's Press | location= New York | id=0-312-23082-6 | pages= 182–184}} == 2002 New York gubernatorial election == {{see also|New York gubernatorial election, 2002}} Cuomo first ran for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New York in 2002. He was initially the favorite for nomination and led in fund-raising and polls, but his campaign took serious damage after a [[gaffe]] when Cuomo said (in reference to the aftermath of the [[September 11 attacks]]) "[[George Pataki|Pataki]] stood behind the leader. He held the leader's coat. He was a great assistant to the leader. But he was not a leader. Cream rises to the top, and [[Rudy Giuliani]] rose to the top." His remarks were widely derided; even his father, former Governor [[Mario Cuomo]], later admitted it was a blunder.{{cite news|first=Rod|last=Dreher |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/dreher/dreher090402.asp|title=Where the Son Doesn't Follow|work=[[National Review]]|date=September 4, 2002|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020910104631/http://www.nationalreview.com/dreher/dreher090402.asp|archivedate=September 10, 2002}} On the eve of the state convention, Cuomo withdrew from consideration after concluding that he had little chance of support as opposed to the favored party candidate, [[New York State Comptroller|State Comptroller]] [[Carl McCall]].{{cite news| first=Bill| last=Schneider| url=http://archives.cnn.com/2002/ALLPOLITICS/09/06/ip.pol.umbrella/index.html|title=Let a political connection be your umbrella?|work=Inside Politics|publisher=CNN|date=September 6, 2002|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050319094326/http://archives.cnn.com/2002/ALLPOLITICS/09/06/ip.pol.umbrella/index.html|archivedate=March 19, 2005}} McCall went on to lose the general election to [[George Pataki]]. == New York Attorney General == === Election === {{main|New York attorney general election, 2006}} Cuomo declared his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for [[New York State Attorney General]] in 2006, and on May 30, 2006, captured the Democratic Party's endorsement, receiving 65% of the delegates. Though Cuomo won the endorsement, former [[New York City Public Advocate]] [[Mark J. Green]], two-time candidate for [[Lieutenant Governor of New York|lieutenant governor]] [[Charlie King (politician)|Charlie King]], also earned places on the Democratic [[primary election|ballot]].{{cite news|first=Jonathan P.|last=Hicks|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/05/31/nyregion/31ag.html|title=Cuomo Wins Democrats' Backing in Primary Race for Attorney General|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 31, 2006|accessdate=July 23, 2007}} King dropped out of the race before the primary and endorsed Cuomo.{{cite news|first=Elizabeth|last=Benjamin|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/blogs/dailypolitics/2010/02/sharpton-praises-paterson-wont.html|title=Sharpton Praises Paterson, Won't Endorse Cuomo Today | location=New York |work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|date=February 26, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100303002407/http://www.nydailynews.com/blogs/dailypolitics/2010/02/sharpton-praises-paterson-wont.html|archivedate=March 3, 2010}} Cuomo won the primary with a majority of the vote, defeating his nearest opponent by over 20%. Clinching the Democratic party nomination was considered a significant rebound following his unsuccessful and unpopular 2002 gubernatorial campaign and at the nominating convention, June O'Neill, the Democratic chairwoman of [[St. Lawrence County]], called him "New York's own Comeback Kid." He won the [[general election]] against the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nominee, former [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]] [[District attorney]] [[Jeanine Pirro]] on November 7, 2006, winning 58% of the vote. === Tenure === ==== Police surveillance, 2007 ==== {{main|Eliot Spitzer political surveillance controversy}} On July 23, 2007, Cuomo's office admonished the [[Eliot Spitzer|Spitzer administration]] for ordering the State Police to keep special records of then-Senate majority leader [[Joseph Bruno]]'s whereabouts when he traveled with police escorts in New York City.{{cite news|first=Danny|last=Hakim|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/23/nyregion/23cnd-spitzer.html|title=Spitzer's Staff Misused Police, Report Finds|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 23, 2007|accessdate=July 24, 2007}} At the discretion of top officials of the Spitzer administration, the [[New York State Police]] created documents meant to cause political damage to Bruno.{{cite news|first=Cara |last=Matthews |url=http://www.theithacajournal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070723/NEWS01/70723006/1002 |title=Cuomo: Spitzer aides used state police to try to damage Bruno |work=[[The Ithaca Journal]] |date=July 23, 2007 |accessdate=July 24, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://m.lohud.com/detail.jsp?key=62289&full=1 |archivedate=March 17, 2008 }} Spitzer responded by accepting responsibility and issuing an apology to Bruno.{{cite news |first=Sally |last=Goldenberg |url=http://blog.silive.com/advanceupdate/2007/07/report_governor_office_compil.html|title=Report: Governor's office compiled, leaked data on Bruno |work=[[Staten Island Advance]] |date=July 23, 2007 |accessdate=July 24, 2007}}{{dead link|date=February 2013}} ==== Student loan inquiry, 2007 ==== In 2007, Cuomo was active in a high-profile investigation into lending practices and anti-competitive relationships between student lenders and universities. Specifically, many universities steered student borrowers to a "preferred lender," which resulted in the borrowers' incurring higher interest rates. This led to changes in lending policy at many major American universities. Many universities also rebated millions of dollars in fees back to affected borrowers.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/industries/banking/2007-04-10-cuomo-student-loan-probe_N.htm |title=Cuomo: School loan corruption widespread|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=April 8, 2008| date=April 10, 2007}}{{cite news|first=Doug|last=Lederman|url=http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2007/05/15/texas|title=The First Casualty|publisher=Inside Higher Education|date=May 15, 2007|accessdate=April 8, 2008}} [[File:CuomoAckerman.jpg|thumb|240px|Cuomo with Representative [[Gary Ackerman]]]] ==== Usenet, 2008 ==== On June 10, 2008, Cuomo announced that three major Internet service providers ([[Verizon Communications]], [[Time Warner Cable]], and [[Sprint Nextel|Sprint]]) would "shut down major sources of online [[child pornography]]" by no longer hosting many [[Usenet]] groups. Time Warner Cable ceased offering Usenet altogether, Sprint ended access to the 18,408 newsgroups in the [[alt.* hierarchy]], and Verizon limited its Usenet offerings to the approximately 3,000 [[Big 8 (Usenet)|Big 8]] newsgroups. The move came after Cuomo's office located 88 different newsgroups to which child pornography had been posted.Rosencrance, Lisa.
