Cuomo received criticism from some for his use of the phrase. [[Roland S. Martin|Roland Martin]] of [[CNN]] said that "'[[shuckin' and jivin']]' have long been words used as a negative assessment of African Americans, along the lines of a 'foot-shufflin' [[Negro]].'"[http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2008/01/11/martin-shucking-and-jiving-and-the-campaign-trail/ "Martin: 'Shucking and jiving' and the campaign trail"], CNN Political Ticker – CNN.com Blogs, January 11, 2008. ==== Corruption and fraud investigations, 2009 ==== Cuomo investigated a corruption scandal, "fraudulent scheme to extract kickbacks", which involved New York investigators, the [[Securities and Exchange Commission]], and [[state attorney general|attorneys general]] in dozens of states.[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/15/business/15leuschen.html Go-Between Tied Funds to Carlyle]. New York Times, May 14, 2009 Also in 2009, Cuomo launched a suit against the [[United Homeless Organization]], a New York charity. He charged that the majority of the group's income was not used to provide services to the homeless, but was diverted to the founders for unrelated personal expenses.{{citation | title=Homeless beggar jars a sham: AG | publisher=[[New York Post]] | date=2009-11-24 | url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/suit_put_cork_in_it_jugheads_GvF3qaHCib8Xh5AY86i68O?offset=16#comments#ixzz0Xmpl4OA1 | accessdate=2009-11-24 | first1=Melissa | last1=Klein | first2=Kevin | last2=Fasick | first3=Chuck | last3=Bennett}} In 2010, Judge [[Barbara R. Kapnick]] granted the judgement and forced the group to disband.{{cite news| url= http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/judge_rules_hucksters_permanently_ahPPxEVrVEHlimCcLjlQ4I| title=Judge rules to permanently shut down faux homeless charity, but hucksters still out in force|last=Bennett|first=Chuck|date=|work=New York Post|access-date=|via=}} === U.S. Senate === {{See also|United States Senate special election in New York, 2010#Potential candidates|l1=Possible appointment choices for the New York Senate seat}} After [[Hillary Clinton]] became President Obama's choice for [[U.S. Secretary of State]], then-New York governor [[David Paterson]] was charged with appointing a temporary replacement until a [[United States Senate special election in New York, 2010|special election]]. Cuomo was seen as a leading contender for this appointment.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/22/us/politics/22hillary.html|title=If Clinton Should Win, Who Would Take Her most likely appointees.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/04/us/politics/04senateseat.html|title=Wishing and Hoping for Clinton's Seat|accessdate=November 23, 2008|date=October 4, |publisher=CNN | date=January 23, 2009 | accessdate=January 12, 2011}} == Governor of New York == === Elections === ==== 2010 ==== {{main|New York gubernatorial election, 2010}} On September 18, 2009, advisors to President Barack Obama informed Governor [[David Paterson]] that the President believed he should withdraw his 2010 gubernatorial candidacy, stepping aside for "popular Attorney General Andrew Cuomo."{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/news/region-state/obama-cordial-but-cool-to-gov-paterson-1.1465587 |title=Obama cordial but cool to Gov. David Paterson |work=Newsday |date=September 21, 2009 |accessdate=May 16, 2010}} On January 23, 2010, the New York ''Daily News'' reported that Cuomo would announce plans for a gubernatorial campaign at the end of March.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2010/01/23/2010-01-23_source_says_andrew_cuomo_will_announce_plans_to_run_for_new_york_governor_in_mar.html| title=Source says Andrew Cuomo will announce plans to run for New York Governor in March|date=January 23, 2010|accessdate=January 24, 2010|author=Molloy, Joanna|newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]| location=New York | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100127181447/http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2010/01/23/2010-01-23_source_says_andrew_cuomo_will_announce_plans_to_run_for_new_york_governor_in_mar.html| archivedate= January 27, 2010 | deadurl= no}} Later reports indicated Cuomo would announce his gubernatorial campaign coinciding with the state Democratic Convention in late May.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=ao6UppVoMprA |title=Cuomo Said to Wait for N.Y. Convention to Declare Governor Run |publisher=Bloomberg |date=May 30, 2005 |accessdate=May 16, 2010 |first=Henry |last=Goldman}} On May 22, 2010, Cuomo announced his run for governor in a video posted to his campaign website. Cuomo announced his choice for lieutenant governor on May 26, 2010: Mayor of [[Rochester, New York|Rochester]], [[Robert Duffy (politician)|Robert Duffy]].{{cite news|url=http://rochester.ynn.com/content/top_stories/505988/cuomo-names-mayor-duffy-as-running-mate/|title=Cuomo Names Mayor Duffy as Running Mate|work=Your News Now (YNN) Rochester|date=May 26, 2010|accessdate=February 18, 2012}} In the November 2, 2010, general election, Cuomo faced Republican [[Carl Paladino]], a [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]]-based businessman who had been heavily supported by the [[Tea Party movement]]. Cuomo won the election for governor by a landslide, winning 62.6% of the vote. The [[Independence Party of New York|Independence Party]] and [[Working Families Party of New York|Working Families Party]] cross-endorsed Andrew Cuomo, while the [[Conservative Party of New York|Conservative Party]] and [[Taxpayers Party of New York|Taxpayers Party]] cross-endorsed Carl Paladino. The Independence Party line received 146,648 votes (5.0% of Cuomo's total, and 3.2% of the statewide total) and the Working Families line received 154,853 votes (5.3% and 3.4%), with the Democratic line receiving the remaining 2,610,220 votes (89.6% and 56.5%). The Conservative line received 232,281 votes (15.0% of Paladino's total, and 5.0% of the statewide total) and the Taxpayers line received 25,821 votes (1.5% and 0.6%), with the Republican line receiving the remaining 1,290,082 votes (83.3% and 27.1%). ==== 2014 ==== {{see also|New York gubernatorial election, 2014}} Cuomo sought reelection in 2014, with former U.S. Representative Kathy Hochul as his new running mate. She criticized him as having failed to fix the [[New York City subway]], protect undocumented immigrants, legalize recreational marijuana,{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/tv/news/cynthia-nixon-andrew-cuomo-debate-new-york-governor-1202921172/|title=Cynthia Nixon and Andrew Cuomo Spar Over Subway Woes, Legalizing Pot in Gubernatorial Debate|first=Cynthia|last=Littleton|date=August 30, 2018|publisher=|accessdate=September 10, 2018}} or create a Single Payer healthcare system "http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/ny-pol-nixon-cuomo-single-payer-health-care-20180724-story.html# When debating Nixon, Cuomo countered her argument on the subways by pointing out that the system is owned by New York City, though past administrations agree it is the governor's role.{{cite web|url=http://theweek.com/speedreads/793250/andrew-cuomo-cynthia-nixon-gubernatorial-debate-gets-heated-stop-lying|title=Andrew Cuomo, Cynthia Nixon gubernatorial debate gets heated: 'Can you stop lying?'|date=August 29, 2018|publisher=|accessdate=September 10, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2018/08/31/cuomo-continues-his-ping-pong-approach-to-subway-ownership-588765|title=Cuomo continues his ping-pong approach to subway ownership|publisher=|accessdate=September 10, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://gothamist.com/2018/08/30/cuomo_corruption_questions.php|title=Some Questions For Cuomo After Wednesday's Debate|publisher=|accessdate=September 10, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180831110014/http://gothamist.com/2018/08/30/cuomo_corruption_questions.php|archive-date=August 31, 2018|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} An analysis conducted by New York City Comptroller Scott Stringer revealed that New York City pays for 70 percent of subway repair costs. In the primary, with 93% of precincts reporting, Cuomo gained 65% of the vote to Nixon's 35%.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-45518685|title=Actress Cynthia Nixon loses New York Democratic primary|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=14 September 2018}} === Tenure === {{split section|Governorship of Andrew Cuomo|date=March 2018}} Cuomo took the gubernatorial oath of office at 12:01 a.m. on January 1, 2011, succeeding David Paterson.{{cite news| first=Danny| last=Hakim| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/01/nyregion/01swearing.html |title=Cuomo Is Sworn In as New York's Governor|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 31, 2010|accessdate=January 1, 2011}}{{cite news|first=Jacob|last=Gershman|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704543604576054750661022820|title=Cuomo Takes Office, Calls New York State's Reputation a 'National Joke'|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=January 2, 2011|accessdate=January 11, 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110126110737/http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704543604576054750661022820.html| archivedate= January 26, 2011 | deadurl= no}} During his first year as governor, Cuomo worked to pass an on-time budget{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/31/nyregion/31nybudget-albany.html | newspaper=The New York Times | first=Thomas | last=Kaplan | title=Albany Approves Budget, With Time to Spare | date=March 31, 2011}}{{cite news| url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/amazing_state_pols_ok_budget_on_9YH2yhLjFuFxF0ATtTcSII | work=New York Post | first1=Brendan | last1=Scott | first2=Fredric U. | last2=Dicker | title=Amazing! State pols OK budget on time | date=March 31, 2011}} that cut spending without raising taxes,{{cite news| url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2011-03-27/local/29375758_1_new-york-state-budget-cuomo-spending-cuts | location=New York | work=Daily News | first1=Kenneth | last1=Lovett | first2=Glenn | last2=Blain | title=Cuomo, lawmakers reach New York State budget deal, agreeing on 2% cut in spending and no new taxes | date=March 27, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.capitaltonight.com/2011/03/cuomo-victory-lap/ |title=Cuomo Praises Lawmakers In Video Victory Lap |publisher=Capitaltonight.com |date=March 31, 2011 |accessdate=April 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110412073005/http://www.capitaltonight.com/2011/03/cuomo-victory-lap/ |archivedate=April 12, 2011 }} made a new deal with a large state-employee union,{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/04/nyregion/public-employees-union-accepts-cuomos-contract-deal-to-avert-layoffs.html | newspaper=The New York Times | first=Thomas | last=Kaplan | title=Public Employees Union Accepts Cuomo's Contract Deal to Avert Layoffs | date=November 3, 2011}} signed ethics reform legislation,{{cite web|last=Hamilton |first=Colby |url=http://empire.wnyc.org/2011/08/cuomo-signs-ethics-reform-into-law/ |title=Cuomo signs ethics reform into law – WNYC |publisher=Empire.wnyc.org |accessdate=April 5, 2012}} passed a property tax cap,{{cite web|url=http://www.governor.ny.gov/press/6302011HistoricPropertyTaxCap |title=Governor Cuomo Signs Historic Property Tax Cap Legislation In Nassau County | Governor Andrew M. Cuomo |publisher=Governor.ny.gov |date=June 30, 2011 |accessdate=April 5, 2012}} worked to enact a same-sex marriage bill with bipartisan support,{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jun/25/nation/la-na-gay-new-york-20110626 | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Geraldine | last=Baum | title=Gay marriage fight shows N.Y. Gov. Andrew Cuomo is no rookie | date=June 25, 2011}}{{cite web|last=Smith |first=Chris |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2011/06/gay_marriage_bill_all_goes_acc.html |title=Gay Marriage All Goes According to Andrew Cuomo's Plan – Daily Intel |work=New York |accessdate=April 5, 2012}} and restructured New York's tax code.{{cite news| url=http://www.nydailynews.com/blogs/dailypolitics/2011/12/assembly-finally-passes-tax-package | location=New York | work=Daily News | title=Assembly (Finally) Passes Tax Package}}{{cite news| url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2011-12-06/news/30483620_1_tax-rate-tax-surcharge-tax-code | location=New York | work=Daily News | first=Kenneth | last=Lovett | title=Cuomo announces sweeping tax deal | date=December 6, 2011}} There was media speculation about a 2016 presidential run.{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0611/57765.html |title=Andrew Cuomo 2016 speculation heating up – Edward-Isaac Dovere and Maggie Haberman |publisher=Politico.Com |accessdate=April 5, 2012}}{{cite news |title=Cuomo jumpstarts 2016 speculation |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/national/politico/article/Cuomo-jumpstarts-2016-speculation-1440448.php |date=June 25, 2011 |work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer }} His approach was described by the press as "muscular". [[Tom Libous]], the Republican State Senate deputy majority leader, said, in 2013, "When I share something he doesn't like, he gets very quiet. He stares at you." For his 2018 re-election bid, Cuomo accepted being on top of the ballot line for the Independence Party, a list that featured numerous Republicans, including ardent Trump supporters. Cuomo's presence on the top of the ballot line may boost the vote shares of the Republicans on the list.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/01/nyregion/cuomo-independence-line-ballot-governor-election.html|title=Third-Party Line Will Feature Governor Cuomo, and a Slew of Republicans|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en}} In an August 15, 2018, anti-sex trafficking bill-signing event, Cuomo said: "We're not gonna make America great again. It was never that great. We have not reached greatness. We will reach greatness when every American is fully engaged." {{cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/cuomo-america-was-never-that-great/ar-BBLYIOW?OCID=ansmsnnews11|title=Cuomo: America 'was never that great'|website=www.msn.com|accessdate=August 31, 2018}} The assembled audience of Cuomo's supporters booed.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-media-keep-falling-into-the-trump-trap-1534892905|title=Opinion - The Media Keep Falling Into the Trump Trap|first=Jason L.|last=Riley|date=August 21, 2018|publisher=|accessdate=August 31, 2018|via=www.wsj.com}} ==== Criminal justice ==== In September 2016, a former aide and close friend of Cuomo, Joseph Percoco, was indicted as part of a bribery investigation into the [[Buffalo Billion]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/nyregion/cuomo-former-aides-charges.html|title=Ex-Cuomo Aides Charged in Federal Corruption Inquiry|last=Yee|first=William K. Rashbaum, Vivian|date=September 23, 2016|last2=Weiser|first2=Benjamin|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=September 22, 2016|page=A1}}{{Cite web|url=http://observer.com/2016/09/all-the-governors-men-federal-charges-against-top-cuomo-aide-donor-and-suny-head/|title=All the Governor's Men—Federal Charges Against Top Cuomo Aide, Donor and SUNY Head|date=September 22, 2016|language=en-US|access-date=September 22, 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://blog.timesunion.com/capitol/archives/267664/who-is-joe-percoco-former-cuomo-aide-charged-by-bharara-thursday/|title=Who is Joe Percoco, former Cuomo aide charged by Bharara Thursday?|date=September 22, 2016|language=en-US|access-date=September 22, 2016}} Todd Howe, a lobbyist and former Cuomo aide was also indicted, along with several developers who were major donors to Cuomo and other state politicians. Cuomo was not accused of wrongdoing. In March 2018, a federal jury in Manhattan convicted Percoco on felony charges of solicitation of bribes and [[honest services fraud]] for over $315,000 in bribes he took from two people seeking official favors on behalf of an energy company, Competitive Power Ventures Inc. He faces 50 years in prison. Prosecutors framed Percoco as Cuomo's "right-hand man."{{Cite news|url=https://www.eenews.net/energywire/2018/03/14/stories/1060076267|title=Jury finds former Cuomo aide guilty of gas deal corruption|last=Rahim|first=Saqib|date=2018-03-14|work=Energy Wire|access-date=2018-04-10}}{{cite news|last1=Wang|first1=Vivian|last2=Weiser|first2=Benjamin|title=Joseph Percoco, Ex-Cuomo Aide, Found Guilty in Corruption Trial|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/13/nyregion/percoco-corruption-bribery-trial-cuomo-guilty.html|accessdate=15 March 2018|work=The New York Times|date=14 March 2018|page=A1}}{{cite news|last1=Press Release|title=Joseph Percoco, Former Executive Aide And Campaign Manager To N.Y. Governor, Convicted Of Accepting More Than $300,000 In Bribes|url=https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/joseph-percoco-former-executive-aide-and-campaign-manager-ny-governor-convicted|accessdate=15 March 2018|work=13 March 2018|agency=[[United States Department of Justice]]|issue=180-74|language=en}} Following Percoco's conviction, however, Cuomo released a statement where declared that he would respect the jury's verdict and that "there is no tolerance for any violation of the public trust."{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/13/nyregion/percoco-corruption-bribery-trial-cuomo-guilty.html|title=Joseph Percoco, Ex-Cuomo Aide, Found Guilty in Corruption Verdict|website=www.nystateofpolitics.com|accessdate=August 31, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.newsday.com/news/region-state/percoco-conviction-hurts-cuomo-1.17372930|title=Percoco conviction hurts Cuomo, observers say|publisher=|accessdate=August 31, 2018}} In 2014, Politico reported that Cuomo had been actively involved in the formation of the [[Independent Democratic Conference]] three years earlier, which gave control of the State Senate to Republicans.{{cite able to.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/09/nyregion/cuomo-stewart-cousins-new-york-senate-democrats.html|title=Tensions Flare as Cuomo Confronts Democratic Rift|last1=Goldmacher|first1=Shane|date=9 August 2017|website=The New York Times|accessdate=22 August 2017}} In July 2014, it was reported that the [[Moreland Commission to Investigate Public Corruption|Moreland Commission]], a committee established by Cuomo to root out corruption in politics, was directed away from investigations that could be politically damaging.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/23/nyregion/governor-andrew-cuomo-and-the-short-life-of-the-moreland-commission.html|title=Cuomo's Office Hobbled Ethics Inquiries by Moreland Commission|last=Craig|first=Susanne|date=July 24, 2014|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=September 16, 2014}} Cuomo later abruptly and controversially disbanded the Commission. Federal prosecutors in Manhattan launched an inquiry into Cuomo's dealings with the anticorruption panel and concluded that "after a thorough investigation," there was "insufficient evidence to prove a federal crime."{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/12/nyregion/in-moreland-commission-inquiry-insufficient-evidence-to-prove-a-crime.html|title=Cuomo Won't Face Federal Charges Over Moreland Ethics Panel|last=Weiser|first=Benjamin|date=2016|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-02-23|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} In January 2014, Cuomo announced {{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/05/nyregion/new-york-state-is-set-to-loosen-marijuana-laws.html|title=New York State Is Set to Loosen Marijuana Laws|last=Craig|first=Susanne|date=January 4, 2014|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=September 14, 2015}} the introduction of restrictive measures to make [[medical marijuana]] available to 20 designated hospitals for the treatment of cancer and glaucoma. Later in July, New York became the 23rd state {{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/07/07/health/new-york-medical-marijuana/|title=New York legalizes medical marijuana|last=Ferrigno|first=Lorenzo|date=September 11, 2014|work=[[CNN ]]|accessdate=September 14, 2015}} to allow the medical use of marijuana, as the Governor signed the Compassionate Care Act, not without drawing the criticism of legalization activists, though.{{cite web|url=http://marijuanareform.org/marijuana-legalization-in-new-york/|title=Marijuana Legalization in the New York|date=September 28, 2014|work=[[Marijuana Reform Party|New York]]|accessdate=September 14, 2015}} In August 2017, the Cuomo administration awarded more than $7 million - financed with money from large bank settlements - in grants to New York colleges to offer courses to New York prisoners.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/06/nyregion/cuomo-to-give-colleges-7-million-for-courses-in-prisons.html|title=Cuomo to Give Colleges $7 Million for Courses in Prisons|last=McKinley|first=Jesse|date=2017-08-06|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-09|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} In January 2018, Cuomo proposed reforms that would "reduce delays during trials, ban asset seizures in cases where there has been no conviction and make it easier for former convicts to get a job after leaving prison."{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/02/nyregion/cuomo-ending-cash-bail-state-of-the-state.html|title=Cuomo, in Bid to Help Poor, Proposes Ending Cash Bail for Minor Crimes|last=Jr|first=James C. McKinley|date=2018|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-08|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} He also called for an end to cash bail for minor crimes. Under Cuomo's tenure, he granted commutations to fewer prisoners than many previous Republican and Democratic New York governors.{{Cite news|url=https://theappeal.org/cuomo-the-merciless/|title=Cuomo the Merciless|work=The Appeal|access-date=2018-07-09|language=en}} Cuomo commuted a total of nine sentences. Cuomo pardoned 140 adults who were convicted of nonviolent felonies as 16- and 17-year-olds, but had served their sentences. He pardoned 18 others who had served their sentences for nonviolent felonies but were exposed to deportation due to their criminal record. [[File:Andrew Cuomo at March For Our Lives rally.jpg|thumb|Cuomo leading the 2018 New York City [[March For Our Lives]] rally]] ==== Gun control ==== On January 15, 2013, Cuomo signed into law the first state [[gun control]] bill to pass after the December 14, 2012, [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting]] in neighboring Connecticut.{{cite news |last=Glaser |first=Howard |date=January 15, 2013 |title=Cuomo Gun Safety Legislation Passes NY State Senate With Bipartisan Support, Assembly Action Today |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/howard-glaser/cuomo-gun-safety-legislation_b_2476419.html |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |accessdate=January 25, 2013}} The [[NY SAFE Act]] was described as the toughest gun control law in the United States.{{cite news |last=Walshe |first=Shushannah |date=January 15, 2013 |title=New York Passes Nation's Toughest Gun-Control Law |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/york-state-passes-toughest-gun-control-law-nation/story?id=18224091 |accessdate=January 16, 2013 |publisher=[[ABC News]] }} The act came under criticism, and the [[National Rifle Association]] called it draconian. The New York State Sheriffs' Association issued a statement supporting tougher penalties for illegal use of firearms, but criticizing several aspects of the legislation, including a magazine limit of seven rounds and a "too broad" definition of assault weapons.{{cite news|title=Sheriff's response to NY SAFE Act |url=http://www.nysheriffs.org/articles/sheriffs%E2%80%99-response-ny-safe-act |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130129224050/http://www.nysheriffs.org/articles/sheriffs%E2%80%99-response-ny-safe-act |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-29 |publisher=New York State Sheriff's Association }} On July 5, 2013, Cuomo signed an amendment to the NY SAFE Act that exempts retired police officers from some of the act's ownership restrictions.{{cite news |last=Weaver |first=Teri |date=July 15, 2013 |title=Gov. Andrew Cuomo signs amendment to NY Safe Act allowing exceptions for retired police |url=http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2013/07/gov_andrew_cuomo_signs_amendment_to_ny_safe_act_allowing_exceptions_for_retired.html |newspaper=The Post-Standard |location=Syracuse, New York |accessdate=July 8, 2013 }} ==== Hurricane Sandy ==== After [[Hurricane Sandy]] in October 2012, Cuomo allowed New York voters, via a specific provision aimed at accommodating those displaced, to cast provisional ballots for the 2012 election anywhere in New York state.{{cite news |author1=David Halbfinger |author2=Thomas Kaplan |author3=Wendy Ruderman |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/06/nyregion/after-hurricane-sandy-efforts-to-help-the-displaced-vote.html |title=Officials Rush to Find Ways for the Storm-Tossed to Vote |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 5, 2012 |accessdate=January 22, 2013}} He also appointed a [[Moreland Commission|commission]] to examine the responses of New York utilities to damage caused by the storm.{{cite news |title=Suffering on Long Island as Power Agency Shows Its Flaws |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/14/nyregion/long-island-power-authoritys-flaws-hindered-recovery-efforts.html |work=The New York Times |date=November 13, 2012 |accessdate=June 23, 2013}} Controversy ensued when the Cuomo administration used $140 million, including $40 million of federal disaster relief funds, to pay for the broadcast of national TV ads promoting "New New York" slogans outside New York in an attempt to attract new business investment to the state.{{cite news|last=Hakim|first=Danny|title=Ad Effort Selling State as a Business Haven Is Criticized|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/04/nyregion/new-york-states-ads-to-attract-business-also-draw-complaints.html|accessdate= June 4, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times}}{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Eliana|title=Andrew Cuomo Launches Ad Campaign to Lure Businesses to N.Y.|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/347489/andrew-cuomo-launches-ad-campaign-lure-businesses-ny|accessdate= June 4, 2013|newspaper=The National Review|date=May 6, 2013}} Many have been critical of the effort, including former New York governor [[Eliot Spitzer]], who called the ads "fluff" and "a waste of taxpayer money". ==== Hydraulic fracturing ==== In June 2012, the Cuomo administration said it was considering lifting a state ban on the practice of [[hydraulic fracturing]] (also known as "fracking"){{cite news|url=http://nymag.com/news/intelligencer/topic/fracking-2012-9/|title=Fracklash|work=New York|date=September 10, 2012}} to stimulate the economy in [[upstate New York]]. But critics said that fracking in Upstate New York could contaminate the water supply of New York City, New Jersey and parts of Pennsylvania.{{cite web|url=http://nofracking.com/|title=Stop fracking, and save our water, land, and air!|date=September 16, 2014|publisher=nofracking.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/local/2014/02/18/hearing-on-ny-energy-plan-attracts-fracking-critics/5589917/|title=Hearing on NY energy plan attracts fracking critics|date=February 18, 2014|publisher=Democrat & Chronicle|author=Campbell, J.}} Following a long-awaited study started years earlier, New York State health officials cited "significant public health risks" associated with fracking, and on December 17, 2014, the Cuomo administration announced a ban of hydraulic fracturing in New York State.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/18/nyregion/cuomo-to-ban-fracking-in-new-york-state-citing-health-risks.html|title=Citing Health Risks, Cuomo Bans Fracking in New York State|date=December 17, 2014|work=The New York Times|author= Kaplan, Thomas.}} ==== New York City Subway ==== In June 2017, after a series of subway disasters, Cuomo declared a "state of emergency" for the [[New York City Subway]] system.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/18/nyregion/new-york-subway-system-failure-delays.html|title=How Politics and Bad Decisions Starved New York's Subways|last=Rosenthal|first=Brian M.|date=2017-11-18|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-12-29|last2=Fitzsimmons|first2=Emma G.|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|last3=LaForgia|first3=Michael}} According to ''The New York Times'', a series of New York City mayors and New York governors, including Cuomo, were partly at fault for the worsening quality of the subway system and inflated construction costs. Under the Cuomo administration, the [[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]] repeatedly diverted tax revenues earmarked for the subways, paid for services that there was no need for and spent on subway projects that did not boost service or reliability. As a result, the MTA was saddled with debt and could not undertake investments into overhauling outdated and inefficient subway infrastructure. Cuomo also directed the MTA to spend on projects that the heads of the MTA did not consider to be priorities. One reason why the New York City subway system is so expensive is due to exorbitant labor costs; according to several M.T.A. officials who were involved in negotiating labor contracts, Cuomo pressured the MTA to accept labor union contracts that were extremely favorable to workers. ''The New York Times'' noted that Cuomo was closely aligned with the union in question and had received $165,000 in campaign contributions from the union. ''The New York Times'' reported, "Cuomo had steered clear of the M.T.A. during his first years in office, but in his second term he took an intense interest. He placed aides within the organization and, in an unusual move, made some report directly to him. He badgered transit leaders about the construction of the [[Second Avenue Subway|Second Avenue subway]] on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. And over the objections of some board members, he canceled several M.T.A. capital projects to make room for his own priorities. According to high-ranking current and former M.T.A. officials, the moves interfered with the authority's plans to address the rising delays." ==== Public college and university tuition ==== On April 18, 2017, Cuomo signed the New York State 2018 fiscal year budget. It included the [[Excelsior Scholarship]], a provision that families making less than $125,000 in 2019 could have free tuition at all [[State University of New York|SUNY]] and [[City University of New York|CUNY]] universities,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/11/nyregion/new-yorks-free-tuition-program-will-help-traditional-but-not-typical-students.html|title=New York's Free-Tuition Program Will Help Traditional, but Not Typical, Students|last=Chen|first=David W.|date=2017-04-11|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-04-13|issn=0362-4331}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.ny.gov/programs/tuition-free-degree-program-excelsior-scholarship|title=Tuition-Free Degree Program: The Excelsior Scholarship|date=2016-12-27|work=Welcome to the State of New York|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}} though some education experts including [[Sara Goldrick-Rab]] say it won't help the poorest students and that the requirement that recipients live and work in New York after graduating is counter-productive.{{Cite news|url=http://shakingnews.com/blog/2017/04/13/free-college-whats-catch-excelsior-scholarship/|title=Free College? What's the Catch with the Excelsior Scholarship? - ShakingNews|date=2017-04-13|work=ShakingNews|access-date=2017-04-25|language=en-US}} ==== Public employees ==== On July 16, 2011, Cuomo finalized a With Money From Thankful Gay Donors | date=December 1, 2011}}{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/28/nyregion/gov-andrew-m-cuomo-calls-for-same-sex-marriage-in-all-states.html | New York State Senate, 98 A.D.3d 285, 297, 948 N.Y.S.2d 787, 797 leave to appeal denied, 19 N.Y.3d 814, 979 N.E.2d 813 (2012) ==== START-UP NY ==== In July 2016, the Empire State Development Corporation, a state agency, released a report indicating that the state's flagship business tax incentive program, called START-UP NY, had generated 408 jobs since its inception in 2014. Ads promoting the program have cost at least $53 million.{{Cite web|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/local/2015/04/07/watchdog-start-ny-ads-cost-taxpayers/25429449/|title=Watchdog: Start-Up NY ads cost taxpayers $53M|access-date=September 11, 2016}} The START-UP NY annual report was delayed three months in 2016, leading some lawmakers, such as Assemblyman Schimminger, to call the delays "curious".{{Cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2016/08/cuomos-economic-development-chief-defiantly-faces-down-start-up-ny-questions-104467|title=Cuomo economic development chief responds defiantly to Start-Up NY questions|access-date=September 11, 2016}} ==== Taxes ==== Cuomo was praised for his 2011 restructuring of the New York State tax code.{{cite web|url=http://blog.timesunion.com/capitol/archives/93839/tax-code-agreement-react-o-mat/ |title=Capitol Confidential » Tax code agreement React-O-Mat |publisher=Blog.timesunion.com |date=December 6, 2011 |accessdate=April 5, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.norwoodnews.org/id=5056&story=bronx-pols-get-behind-cuomos-tax-plan/ |title=Bronx Pols Get Behind Cuomo's Tax Plan |publisher=Norwood News |date=December 7, 2011 |accessdate=April 5, 2012}}{{cite web|agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.silive.com/news/index.ssf/2011/12/governor_andrew_cuomo_hears_ho.html |title=Governor Andrew Cuomo hears hosannas for New York deal on tax reform |publisher=SILive.com |accessdate=April 5, 2012}} He was also criticized for including tax increases for high earners,{{cite news| url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/opinion/opedcolumnists/andrew_lip_service_yJpWH4ySvPeGnFzqRDGNTL | work=New York Post | first=E.J. | last=McMahon | title=Andrew's lip service | date=December 5, 2011}} and for allegedly requesting a unanimous Assembly vote in favor of the proposal and threatening to campaign against Assembly members who voted "no"{{cite web|author=JIMMY VIELKIND, Capitol bureau |url=http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/Governor-to-Assembly-GOP-Vote-for-tax-code-2391075.php |title=Governor to Assembly GOP: Vote for tax code unanimously or risk seats |publisher=Times Union |date=December 8, 2011 |accessdate=April 5, 2012}} – a charge he denied. Cuomo also received criticism from voices on the left who felt that the tax reform was insufficient.{{cite news |first=Thomas |last=Kaplan |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/07/nyregion/cuomo-and-legislative-leaders-agree-on-tax-deal.html |title=Albany Tax Deal to Raise Rate for Highest Earners |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 6, 2011 |accessdate=February 22, 2012}} ==== Corporate incentives ==== Cuomo has been a long support of providing tax and other incentives to attract business to locate in New York State.{{cite web| url=https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-launches-new-york-open-business-marketing-initiative| title=Governor Cuomo Launches "New York Open for Business" Marketing Initiative| accessdate=13 November 2018}}{{cite web| url=https://www.bizjournals.com/albany/morning_call/2015/08/cuomo-says-ny-tax-incentives-are-a-necessity.html| title=Cuomo says New York tax incentives are a necessity for attracting businesses| accessdate=13 November 2018}} {{anchor|Amazon Cuomo}} He even joked in 2018 that he would be willing to change his name to "Amazon Cuomo" if [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]] located their "[[Amazon HQ2]]" in the state.{{cite web| url=https://www.businessinsider.com/new-york-governor-jokes-amazon-cuomo-name-change-hq2-2018-11| title=New York's governor jokes he'll change his name to 'Amazon Cuomo' to win the HQ2 bid hours before a report that New York City will be home to one of the company's new headquarters| accessdate=13 November 2018}} His strong position on this has received criticism saying that the costs to the state are not worth the possible benefits.{{cite web| url=http://www.governing.com/gov-institute/voices/col-tax-incentives-hidden-costs-business-friendly-policies.html| title=Tax Incentives’ Bipartisan Folly| accessdate=13 November 2018}}{{cite web| url=https://nypost.com/2018/10/31/cuomos-amazon-offer-is-a-sick-joke-on-new-york/| title=Cuomo’s Amazon offer is a sick joke on New York| accessdate=13 November 2018}} Amazon decided on two "major corporate outposts" in New York City and [[Arlington County, Virginia|Arlington, Virginia]]—instead of a single second headquarters.{{cite web| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/13/technology/amazon-hq2-headquarters.html| title=Amazon Announces New York and Virginia as HQ2 Picks| accessdate=13 November 2018}} ==== Women's issues ==== In 2013, Cuomo called for the passage of a Women's Equality Act.{{cite web|url=https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/transcript-governor-andrew-m-cuomos-2013-state-state-address | title=Transcript of Governor Andrew M. Cuomo's 2013 State of the State Address | accessdate=January 6, 2018}} The Women's Equality Act included 10 component bills affecting issues such as domestic violence, human trafficking, and pregnancy discrimination. The tenth bill of the Women's Equality Act was the Reproductive Health Act,{{cite web|url=https://www.nysenate.gov/legislation/bills/2013/s438 | title=Reproductive Health Act | accessdate=January 6, 2018}} which would have "enshrine[d] in state law existing federal protections for abortion rights," "shift[ed] the state's abortion law from the criminal code to the health care laws," and "[made] it clearer that licensed health care practitioners as well as physicians could perform abortions."{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/20/opinion/strengthening-reproductive-rights-in-new-york.html | work=New York Times | title=Reproductive Rights in New York | date=February 19, 2013 | accessdate= January 6, 2018}} During his 2013 State of the State address, Cuomo said, "Enact a Reproductive Health Act because it is her body, it is her choice. Because it's her body, it's her choice. Because it's her body, it's her choice." The New York State Assembly passed the Women's Equality Act on June 20, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://assembly.state.ny.us/Press/20130620d/|title=Refusing to Shatter Women's Equality into Parts,Assembly Approves All 10 Points of Women's Equality Act|date=June 20, 2013|accessdate=January 6, 2018}}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The Republican leadership of the New York State Senate expressed support for the nine non-abortion-related planks of the Women's Equality Act, but objected to the Reproductive Health Act and expressed unwillingness to allow a vote on it.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/blogs/dailypolitics/officially-gov-cuomo-ny-senate-gop-dig-heels-women-equality-act-blog-entry-1.1695125 | title=Officially, Gov. Cuomo, NY Senate GOP Dig In Their Heels On Women's Equality Act |last=Katz |first=Celeste | date=June 19, 2013 |accessdate=January 6, 2018}} On the final day of the 2013 legislative session, following the Senate Republican Conference's continued refusal to vote on the full Women's Equality Act, Senator Jeff Klein, leader of the Independent Democratic Conference (IDC), offered the abortion plank of the Act as a hostile amendment to another bill.{{cite news|url=http://www.nystateofpolitics.com/2013/06/klein-offers-hostile-abortion-amendment-fails/| title=Klein Offers Hostile Abortion Amendment, Fails (Updatedx2)|work = State of Politics | date=June 21, 2013 |accessdate=January 6, 2018}} The amendment was defeated by a narrow margin of 32-31; all 30 Senate Republicans voted against the abortion amendment, as did Democratic Sens. Ruben Diaz and Simcha Felder. The Senate proceeded to pass the nine non-abortion-related planks of the Women's Equality Act as separate bills, and the 2013 legislative session came to an end without any portion of the WEA becoming law.{{cite web|url=https://www.nysenate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/senate-approves-women-equality-agenda|title=Senate Approves Women Equality Agenda|date=June 21, 2013|accessdate=January 6, 2018}}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} "[After] the 2014 election season was over, with Cuomo victorious, the governor and his lieutenant governor Kathy Hochul both declared the abortion plank of the act officially dormant, if not dead."{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2015/06/quietly-most-of-womens-equality-act-becomes-law-023451| title=Quietly, most of Women's Equality Act becomes law |last=Nahmias |first=Laura | date=June 30, 2015 |accessdate=January 6, 2018}} In 2015, the non-abortion-related Women's Equality Act bills passed both houses of the State Legislature. In October 2015, Cuomo signed eight of the 10 Women's Equality Act bills into law; the abortion rights bill was not among them.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/Cuomo-signs-women-s-equality-bills-6583054.php| title=Cuomo signs women's equality bills |last=Hamilton |first=Matthew | work = Times Union | date=October 21, 2015 |accessdate=January 6, 2018}} ==== Voting rights ==== In April 2018, Cuomo announced that he would restore the voting rights of parolees through an executive order.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/18/nyregion/felons-pardon-voting-rights-cuomo.html|title=Cuomo Plans to Restore Voting Rights to Paroled Felons|last=Wang|first=Vivian|date=2018-04-18|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Cuomo said that he would consider restoring the voting rights of all parolees (more than 35,000), and would also enfranchise new parolees throughout his term. ==== Public Housing ==== In the winter of 2018, Cuomo responded to a class-action lawsuit brought against the [[New York City Housing Authority]] by attorney [[Jim Walden (lawyer)|Jim Walden]] on behalf of a group of public housing tenants. The suit was the first of its kind and called upon NYCHA to immediately address decrepit and unhealthy conditions in public housing units across New York City.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/27/nyregion/nycha-lawsuit-nyc-housing.html|title=Tenants Sue New York City Housing Authority: 'We Have Let Other People Speak for Us for Too Long'|last=Mays|first=Jeffery C.|date=2018-02-27|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-04-10|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} At the invitation of Walden, Cuomo toured a public housing project in March.{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2018/03/11/cuomo-to-meet-nycha-tenants-after-declaring-emergency/|title=Cuomo to meet NYCHA tenants after declaring emergency|date=2018-03-11|work=New York Post|access-date=2018-04-10|language=en-US}} By early April, Cuomo appointed an independent monitor to oversee NYCHA on an emergency basis.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/02/nyregion/cuomo-nycha-state-of-emergency.html|title=Cuomo Creates Monitor to Oversee Repairs to City's Public Housing|last=Ferré-Sadurní|first=Luis|date=2018-04-02|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-04-10|last2=Goodman|first2=J. David|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The move broadened the ever-widening rift between NYC Mayor [[Bill de Blasio|Bill DeBlasio]] and Cuomo.{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2018/03/21/de-blasio-blasts-cuomo-over-visit-to-nycha-building/|title=De Blasio blasts Cuomo over visit to NYCHA building|date=2018-03-21|work=New York Post|access-date=2018-04-10|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2018/04/05/de-blasio-cuomo-is-no-white-knight-for-nycha/|title=De Blasio: Cuomo is no 'white knight' for NYCHA|date=2018-04-05|work=New York Post|access-date=2018-04-10|language=en-US}} === Appointee donations controversy === On his first day in office, Cuomo renewed an executive order signed by Eliott Spitzer which prohibited Governors of New York from receiving donations from gubernatorial appointees.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/24/nyregion/cuomo-fund-raising-ethics-appointees.html|title=In Spite of Executive Order, Cuomo Takes Campaign Money From State Appointees|last=Goldmacher|first=Shane|date=2018-02-24|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-02-24|last2=Rosenthal|first2=Brian M.|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|last3=Armendariz|first3=Agustin}} A February 2018 investigation by ''The New York Times'', however, revealed that the Cuomo administration had quietly reinterpreted the order, and that Cuomo had collected $890,000 from 24 of his appointees, as well as $1.3 million from the spouses, children and businesses of appointees. Some donations were made to Cuomo just days after the donor was appointed. In March 2018, ''The New York Times'' reported that Cuomo had rewritten the disclaimer language on his campaign website for the executive order barring donations from appointees.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/29/nyregion/cuomo-appointee-donations-campaign-finance.html|title=Cuomo, in Writing, Reinterprets Fund-Raising Ban on Appointees|last=Goldmacher|first=Shane|date=2018-03-29|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-03-30|last2=Rosenthal|first2=Brian M.|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The website added two caveats whereby some gubernatorial appointees are allowed to donate to the Governor, which ''The Times'' said could potentially lead to more donations from appointees to the Governor. The Cuomo campaign returned $2,500 donation from one appointee who was in violation of the new disclaimer, but still retains the approximately $890,000 raised from other appointees. === Remarks about conservatives === In a January 17, 2014, interview with Susan Arbetter on [[WCNY-FM|WCNY]]'s ''The Capital Pressroom'', Cuomo stated: {{quote|[New York Republicans] are searching to define their soul, that's what's going on. Is the Republican party in this state a moderate party or is it an extreme conservative party? ... The Republican Party candidates are running against the SAFE Act — it was voted for by moderate Republicans who run the Senate! Their problem is not me and the Democrats; their problem is themselves. Who are they? Are they these extreme conservatives who are right-to-life, pro-assault-weapon, anti-gay? Is that who they are? Because if that's who they are and they're the extreme conservatives, they have no place in the state of New York, because that's not who New Yorkers are. If they're moderate Republicans like in the Senate right now, who control the Senate — moderate Republicans have a place in their state. George Pataki was governor of this state as a moderate Republican, but not what you're hearing from them on the far right.{{cite web|url=http://blog.timesunion.com/capitol/archives/203801/cuomo-extreme-conservatives-have-no-place-in-the-state-of-new-york/|title=Cuomo: 'Extreme conservatives … have no place in the state of New York'|work=Capitol Confidential}}}} This remark received a major reaction in the conservative media. Radio host [[Glenn Beck]] wrote a letter to the governor regarding the remarks from the interview.{{cite web|url=http://www.theblaze.com/contributions/gov-cuomo-are-we-welcome-in-new-york/|title=Glenn Beck's Open Letter to Gov. Cuomo: Are We Welcome in New York?|first=Glenn|last=Beck|work=The Blaze}} [[Fox News]] contributor and radio/TV show host, [[Sean Hannity]] mentioned emigrating along with all of his assets from the state if the governor does not apologize from the remarks.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/on-air/on-the-record/2014/01/22/sean-hannity-really-leaving-new-york-after-gov-cuomos-anti-conservative-comments|title=Is Sean Hannity really leaving New York after Gov. Cuomo's anti-conservative comments? – OTR Interviews – On the Record|publisher=Fox News Channel|access-date=November 29, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160701084404/http://www.foxnews.com/on-air/on-the-record/2014/01/22/sean-hannity-really-leaving-new-york-after-gov-cuomos-anti-conservative-comments|archive-date=July 1, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Cardinal [[Timothy M. Dolan]], the [[Archbishop of New York]], said during a radio broadcast that the governor's remarks were "most unfortunate at best. Are there pro-lifers who are extremist? Yes, there are. But I think they are a distinct minority."{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/23/nyregion/cuomo-comment-elicits-retort-from-republicans.html|title=Comment by Cuomo outrages Republicans|date=January 22, 2014|author=McKinley, J.|work=The New York Times}} The [[New York State Democratic Committee]], which is headed by Cuomo, supported his remarks and reiterated them in a May 2014 statement responding to a speech by [[Rob Astorino]], who was running against him in the [[New York gubernatorial election, 2014|2014 gubernatorial election]]: "Tea Party Republicans have done enough damage in Washington, today's speech made it abundantly clear that we don't need them here in New York."Reisman, Nick (May 15, 2014). [http://www.nystateofpolitics.com/2014/05/democrats-blast-astorino-speech/ Democrats blast Astorino speech]. ''Time Warner Cable News''. Retrieved May 15, 2014. == Personal life == Cuomo married [[Kerry Kennedy]], the seventh child of [[Robert F. Kennedy]] and [[Ethel Skakel Kennedy]], on June 9, 1990. They have three daughters: twins, Cara Ethel Kennedy-Cuomo and Mariah Matilda Kennedy-Cuomo (born January 11, 1995), and Michaela Andrea Kennedy-Cuomo (born August 26, 1997). They separated in 2003, and divorced in 2005. In 2011, he began living with [[Food Network]] host [[Sandra Lee (chef)|Sandra Lee]]. The two reside in [[Westchester County, New York]].{{cite news |first=David |last=Gibson |url=http://www.politicsdaily.com/2011/01/07/andrew-cuomo-takes-communion-and-revives-the-good-catholic-deb/ |title=Andrew Cuomo Takes Communion and Revives the 'Good Catholic' Debate |work=[[Politics Daily]] |date=January 7, 2011 |accessdate=April 15, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120121023630/http://www.politicsdaily.com/2011/01/07/andrew-cuomo-takes-communion-and-revives-the-good-catholic-deb |archivedate=January 21, 2012}}{{cite news |first=Jennifer |last=Fermino |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/cuomo_soul_mate_settles_into_her_nmWFGoP83fWvz0ReZlU62L |title=Cuomo's gal talks about life as the governor's girlfriend |work=[[New York Post]] |date=January 3, 2011 |accessdate=February 22, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20700565,00.html|title=Sandra Lee and Gov. Andrew Cuomo Have Family Dinners at Home : People.com|work=People}}{{cite news |first=Glenn |last=Blain |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2011-01-02/local/27086115_1_ethics-training-mario-cuomo-state-government |title=On second day in office, Cuomo attends church with daughters and Sandra Lee | location=New York |work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |date=January 2, 2011 |accessdate=February 22, 2012}} On July 4, 2015, Cuomo presided over the wedding ceremony of his long-time friend [[Billy Joel]] to his fourth wife, Alexis Roderick.{{cite web|url=https://ca.celebrity.yahoo.com/post/126526847393/billy-joel-becomes-a-father-again-at-66 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=August 13, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150904042630/https://ca.celebrity.yahoo.com/post/126526847393/billy-joel-becomes-a-father-again-at-66 |archivedate=September 4, 2015 |df=mdy }} == Published works == * Cuomo, Andrew. {{Rewrite|date=July 2018}} {{Original research|date=October 2007}} {{Anti-consumerism|Movements}}
'''Anti-corporate activism''' holds that the influence of [[big business]] [[corporation]]s is a detriment to the [[public good]] and to the [[democratic process]].
==Disagreements with corporations== {{confusing|section|date=June 2018}} {{refimprove|date=June 2018}} [[Activists]]{{Who|date=March 2012}} argue that corporate globalization corresponds to a displacement in the transition from a highly industrial-based economy to one where trade development is connected with the [[financial deregulation]] on the basis of circulation of capital. An increasing number of diverse societies have been changed to [[free market|free-market]] structure, leading to displacement. As this expansion has occurred, market-governed regulation has outrun the grasps of the state. Opponents of corporate globalization hold that the government needs greater power to control the markets, that income inequality is increasing, and that corporations have gained too much power.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Abeles |first=Marc |title=Globalization, Power, and Survival: an Anthropological Perspective |pages=484–486 |journal=[[Anthropological Quarterly]] |volume=79 |issue=3 |publisher=Institute for Ethnographic Research |year=2006}}</ref> As part of the [[political left]], activists against [[corporate power]] and influence support a decreased [[income gap]] and improved [[Equity (economics)|economical equity]].
==Counter-arguments== {{Section OR|date=March 2012}} The defenders of corporations such as [[Ron Arnold]] highlight that governments do legislate<ref>{{cite web|title=DiscoverTheNetwork|url=http://www.discoverthenetworks.org/printgroupProfile.asp?grpid=6898|website=DiscoverTheNetwork.org|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref> in ways that restrict the actions of corporations (see [[Sarbanes-Oxley Act]]) and that lawbreaking companies and executives are routinely caught and punished, usually in the form of monetary fines.
In addition, from the perspective of [[business ethics]] it might be argued{{By whom|date=March 2012}} that chief executives are not inherently more evil than anyone else and so are no more likely to attempt unethical or illegal activity than the general population. Large multi-national corporations do continue to attempt to erode governmental regulations through in-house or contracted lobbyists who work closely with State and Federal legislators. So as corporate laws continue to lean in their favor, corporate members have improved portals to drive up company profits.
==Alliances== Anti-corporate activists may often ally themselves with other activists, such as [[environmental activist]]s or [[animal-rights|animal-rights activist]]s in their condemnation of the practices of modern organizations such as the [[McDonald's Corporation]] (see [[McLibel]]) and forestry company Gunns Limited (see [[Gunns 20]]).
In recent years, there have been an increasing number of books (Naomi Klein's 2000 ''[[No Logo]]'' being a well-known example) and films such as ''The Corporation''<ref>[http://www.thecorporation.com/index.php ''The Corporation''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050609023424/http://www.thecorporation.com/index.php |date=June 9, 2005 }}</ref> which have to a certain extent supported anti-corporate politics.
==Art activism== {{Unsourced|section|date=July 2018}} An artist critical of [[sociopolitical]] agendas in business is conceptualist [[Hans Haacke]].{{citation needed|date=July 2018}}
==Anti-corporate web sites== In June 2008, [[Condé Nast Publications]] released an article entitled "The Secret Seven" which it listed the top seven anti-corporate web sites which include: [[WikiLeaks]], [[Mini-Microsoft]], [[Wal-Mart Watch]], [http://www.hobb.org/ HomeOwners for Better Building], Brenda Priddy and Company (automotive spy photos) and finally Apple Rumor Sites [[AppleInsider]] and [[MacRumors]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.portfolio.com/news-markets/national-news/portfolio/2008/06/13/Anti-Corporate-Websites |title=The Secret Seven |publisher=Condé Nast Publications |first=Kim |last=Zetter |date=2008-06-13 |accessdate=2008-09-03 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080730011448/http://www.portfolio.com/news-markets/national-news/portfolio/2008/06/13/Anti-Corporate-Websites |archivedate=2008-07-30 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.portfolio.com/news-markets/national-news/portfolio/2008/06/13/Dotcom-Confidential|title=Dotcom Confidential|publisher=Condé Nast Publications|first=Kim|last=Zetter|date=2008-06-13|accessdate=2008-09-03}}</ref>
==New digital media== {{Advert|section|date=July 2018}} Media and digital networking have become important features of modern anti-corporate movements. The speed, flexibility, and ability to reach a massive potential audience has provided a technological foundation for contemporary network social movement structure. As a result, communities and interpersonal connections have transformed. The [[internet]] supports and strengthens local ties, but also facilitates new patterns for political activity. Activists have used this medium to operate between both the online and offline political spectrums.<ref name="Juris, Jeffrey S. pg 191-199">{{cite journal |last=Juris |first=Jeffrey S. |title=The New Digital Media and Activist Networking |pages=191–199 |journal=The Annals of the [[American Academy of Political and Social Science]] |volume=599 |publisher=[[SAGE Publications|Sage Publications, Inc.]]}}</ref>
Email lists, web pages, and open editing software have allowed for changes in organization. Now, actions are planned, information is shared, documents are produced by multiple people, and all of this can be done despite differences in distance. This has led to increased growth in digital collaboration. Activists can presently build ties between diverse topics, open the distribution of information, decentralize and increase collaboration, and self-direct networks.<ref name="Juris, Jeffrey S. pg 191-199" />
==Rise of anti-corporate globalization==
Close to fifty thousand people [[1999 Seattle WTO protests|protested]] the WTO meetings in Seattle on November 30, 1999. Labor, economic, and environmental activists succeeded in disrupting and closing the meetings due to their disapproval of corporate globalization. This event became a symbol as anti-globalization networks emerged and became strengthened.<ref name="Juris, Jeffrey S. pg 191-199" /> The experiences from the protests were distributed throughout the internet via emails and websites. Anti-corporate globalization movements have also expanded through the organization of mass mobilizations, including the anti-WTO protests, which were remarkably successful. In the United States, these movements reemerged after less attention was given to the war in Iraq, resulting in an increase in mass mobilizations.<ref name="Juris, Jeffrey S. pg 191-199" />

{{unreferenced|date=November 2016}} The '''Business Journalist of the Year Awards''' are widely recognised{{whom|date=November 2016}} as the most important global awards for business writers and [[broadcasting|broadcaster]]s. They are the only awards for business writers that are open to [[journalist]]s of all nationalities, and the only awards to cover the entire spectrum of business and financial reporting.
The Business Journalist of the Year Awards (first presented in 1999) were created because [[business information]] had become a global commodity paying little heed to national borders. In a world where goods, services, money and knowledge move ever more freely from one domain to another, the source of business information is no longer relevant - only its quality matters. That's the spirit these awards were created in, and the spirit in which they have grown.
The Business Journalist of the Year Awards are judged exclusively by journalists and governed by the World's leading business editors. The Editors' Committee comprises Martin Dickson, Deputy Editor of the ''[[Financial Times]]''; [[Robert Peston]], business editor at [[BBC|the BBC]]; [[Hugo Dixon]], [[editing|editor-in-chief]] and chairman of [[Breakingviews]]; Jesse Lewis, [[managing editor]] of ''[[The Wall Street Journal Europe]]''; and Rik Kirkland, former managing editor of ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]''.
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070406083731/http://www.bjoya.org/home.vc Business Journalist of the Year Awards] * [https://www.independent.co.uk/incoming/article2262619.ece/ The Independent, Media Awards: We are going for a gong]

{{Globalize/UK|date=December 2010}} A '''cohabitation agreement''' is a form of legal agreement reached between a couple who have chosen to live together (whether they are [[heterosexual]] or [[homosexual]]). In some ways, such a couple may be treated like a [[marriage|married]] couple, such as when applying for a [[Mortgage loan|mortgage]] or working out [[child support]]. However, in some other areas, such as property rights, [[pension]]s and [[inheritance]], they are treated differently.
A cohabitation agreement contains documentation for a couple who want to live together in order to protect themselves from unnecessary cost and litigation should their cohabitation break down. They can clearly regulate their property rights and what arrangements might be made for mutual financial support, dealing with [[debt]], caring for [[child]]ren, etc.
The agreement also, much like a [[prenuptial agreement]], allows the individuals concerned to determine in advance who will keep specific assets and what will happen to assets that have been purchased jointly if they separate. This agreement is intended to bind both parties.
== Advantages ==
In the United States, about 15 million couples qualify as cohabiting. A cohabitation agreement can give each party an idea of the expectations of the relationship with the legal enforceability to protect against financial ruin or the loss of support that was promised.<ref name="minellalawgroup.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.minellalawgroup.com/dont-wait-to-protect-your-assets-with-an-enforceable-cohabitation-agreement/|title=Enforceable Cohabitation Agreements – Minella Law Group|date=27 February 2013|website=minellalawgroup.com}}</ref> It is a good idea in that if the couple does break up, an altercation about who receives what may be less likely. {{Citation needed|date=April 2008}} However, the courts may occasionally change or ignore provisions set out in a cohabitation agreement if they feel that they are inadequate under the circumstances.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.lawdepot.com/wiki/Cohabitation_Agreement_FAQ_-_United_States#Will_my_cohabitation_agreement_be_accepted_by_the_courts.3F|title=Cohabitation Agreement FAQ – United States|website=wiki.lawdepot.com}}</ref>
== Disadvantages and limitations == Cohabitation agreements are not considered to be legally binding in the [[United Kingdom]].
A cohabitation agreement will usually not be adequate to settle all legal issues that might arise, so a [[trust deed (real estate)|trust deed]] setting out property rights and a [[will (law)|will]] are also recommended.
== Common law marriage == It is a common misconception that there is a doctrine of "Common Law marriage" in English law. That is to say that without having married, there is no automatic right to home ownership, even if the home is shared for a long time. Instead, the only way in which ownership can be obtained is through ordinary trust law. Even if the parties are legally married, there is still no automatic right to home ownership. Instead, any transfer of ownership will be at the discretion of the court when exercising their power under the Matrimonial Causes Act 1973.
In Canada, each province has legislation which governs the creation of cohabitation agreements. In the Province of Ontario there are restrictions on what can be included in such agreements. For example, clauses requiring chastity are unenforceable. Provisions which pre-determine issues of child custody and access as well as child support may be disregarded by a court<ref>{{cite web|title=Peires Law LLP|url=http://www.peireslaw.com/marriage-contracts.html}}</ref> As well, in Canada, for a cohabitation agreement to be valid, it must be signed, witnessed, and accompanied by financial disclosure.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cohabitation Agreement|url=http://www.cohabitationagreement.ca/validity/}}</ref>
== Same sex couples == Some gay activists have been campaigning for legal recognition of their partnerships. Their campaigning for the right to take over a partner's tenancy of the family home on bereavement have been gained, regardless of any cohabitation agreement existing, but if a couple share a home their chances of buying the rights are much more limited.
In December 2005, the British government offered gay couples equal rights with married couples if they register a civil partnership legally. The government-backed scheme – which enables same-sex couples to qualify for next-of-kin entitlements on inheritance tax, pensions and property – is likely to attract many more couples.
There will still be large legal differences between civil partnership and marriage. For example, a couple can get married and have all the legal rights and benefits after knowing each other for only a few days, but a same-sex couple will almost certainly be required to show a lengthy commitment to each other before they are allowed to register their partnership. Currently, for immigration purposes, a same-sex couple must show they have a relationship of two years' standing, and it is likely that a similar term will be imposed for registering a partnership. Consequently, same-sex couples will need to make wills and a cohabitation agreement, to provide security in the event of break-up.
In the United States, a cohabitation agreement offers fewer legal protections than a registered domestic partnership.<ref name="minellalawgroup.com" /> == Prenuptial agreements == As afore mentioned, the term is also sometimes used loosely to refer to prenuptial agreements. These are often designed when one intends to protect his or her wealth in the event of the marriage ending in divorce. The contract aims to achieve a measure of certainty about what the financial "damage" would be if the marriage came to an end. However ''K v K'' (2003) has heightened the importance of prenuptial agreements by deciding that the wife had to stick by the terms of a prenuptial agreement she signed. The courts still keep their discretion about whether or not a prenuptial agreement will be upheld but this new case shows that the courts are in favour of couples making private agreements between themselves.
== See also == * [[Samenlevingscontract]]

[[File:English 1956 Westminster Bank cheque of Doris Ogilvie.jpg|thumb|A '''crossed cheque''' – the oblique or vertical lines in the centre form the crossing. Like most modern cheques in the UK, the cheque is pre-crossed as printed by the Bank.]]
A '''crossed cheque''' is a [[cheque]] that has been marked specifying an instruction on the way it is to be redeemed. A common instruction is for the cheque to be deposited directly to an [[Transactional account|account]] with a bank and not to be immediately cashed by the holder over the bank counter. The format and wording varies between countries, but generally, two parallel lines may be placed either vertically across the cheque or on the top left hand corner of the cheque. By using crossed cheques, cheque writers can effectively protect the instrument from being stolen or cashed by unauthorized persons.<ref>http://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/crossedcheck.asp</ref>
Cheques can be open (uncrossed) or crossed.
==Open cheque== An open [[cheque]] is a cheque that is not crossed on the left corner and payable at the counter of the drawee [[bank]] on presentation of the cheque.
==Crossed cheque== A crossed cheque is a cheque that is payable only through a collecting [[bank]]er and not directly at the counter of the bank.
When two parallel [[wikt:transverse|transverse]] lines, with or without any words, are drawn generally, on the left hand top corner of the cheque.
==Types of crossing==
===General crossing=== A crossed cheque generally is a cheque that only bears two parallel transverse lines, optionally with the words 'and company' or '& Co.' (or any abbreviation of them) on the face of the cheque, between the lines, usually at the top left corner or at any place in the approximate half (in width) of the cheque.<ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/45-46/61/section/76 Bills of Exchange Act 1882 section 76]</ref> In the UK, the crossing is across the cheque by the person who originally wrote the cheque (the drawer), or it can legitimately be added by the person the cheque is payable to (the payee), or even by the bank that the cheque is being paid into.<ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/45-46/61/section/77 Bills of Exchange Act 1882 section 77]</ref>
Generally-crossed cheques can only be paid into a bank account,<ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/45-46/61/section/79 Bills of Exchange Act 1882 section 79(2)]</ref> so that the beneficiary can be traced.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Goosen|first1=W|last2=Pampallis|first2=A|last3=Amelia Van|first3=Der Merwe|last4=Mdluli|first4=L|title=Banking in the New Millennium|publisher=f Juta and Company Ltd|pages=54}}</ref>{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}
A crossed cheque on its own does not affect the negotiability of the instrument.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}
====Account payee====
Adding a crossing to a cheque increases its security in that it cannot be cashed at a bank counter but must be paid into an account in exactly the same name as that which appears on the ‘payee’ line of the cheque (i.e. the person who has received the cheque, who is legally the “payee” and “holder” of the cheque).
====Not negotiable====
The words 'not negotiable' can be added to a crossing.
The effect of such a crossing is that it removes the most important characteristic of a negotiable instrument: the transferee of such a crossed cheque cannot get a better title than that of the transferor (cannot become a holder in due course) and cannot convey a better title to his own transferee, but the instrument remains transferable.
===Restrictive or special crossings=== Where some customary instruction is written between the two parallel transverse lines (constituting crossing of cheque) that may result in imposing certain restrictions on the collecting or paying banker, it is called restrictive crossing. The example is "State Bank of India". In these cases, the respective restrictions mandate to pay the cheque through State Bank of India (acting as collecting banker) only.
====Specific bank====
A crossing may have the name of a specific banker added between the lines. A cheque with a such a crossing can only be paid into an account at that bank.
The beneficiary bank can add an additional crossing to allow another bank, who are acting as their agent in collecting payment on cheques, to be paid the cheque on their behalf.
==Consequence of a bank not complying with the crossing== A bank's failure to comply with the crossings amounts to a breach of contract with its customer. The bank may not be able to debit the drawer's account and may be liable to the true owner for his loss.
==External links== * http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1992/32/section/4 * http://www.chequeandcredit.co.uk/information-hub/faqs/crossed-cheques

Roth is the only producer of seven [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning plays: Bruce Norris’ [[Clybourne Park]] (Tony Award); Tracy Letts’ [[August: Osage County]] (Tony Award); Nilo Cruz’s [[Anna in the Tropics]]; David Auburn’s [[Proof (play)|Proof]] (Tony Award); Margaret Edson’s [[Wit (play)|Wit]]; Paula Vogel’s [[How I Learned to Drive]]; and Edward Albee’s [[Three Tall Women]].<ref name=nota3rdpartysite>[http://www.darylrothproductions.com/ Roth's web site], Better reference would be a 3rd party site</ref>

== Filmography == Roth's film credits include: * [[James Lapine]]'s film [[Custody (2007 film)|Custody]] starring [[Viola Davis]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/04/viola-davis-custody-james-lapines-tribeca-film-festival-q-and-a-1201737756/|title=Even With Oscar Nominee Viola Davis, James Lapine’s Superb Drama ‘Custody’ Was A Hard Sell – Tribeca Film Festival Q&A|first=Jeremy|last=Gerard|date=16 April 2016|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Albert Nobbs]] starring [[Glenn Close]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://irishamerica.com/2012/01/glenn-closes-irish-odyssey-albert-nobbs/|title=Glenn Close's Irish Odyssey: Albert Nobbs - Irish America|website=irishamerica.com}}</ref> * the Emmy-nominated HBO feature, [[Dinner with Friends]], based on [[Donald Margulies]]’ Pulitzer Prize-winning play<ref name="womanaroundtown.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.womanaroundtown.com/sections/woman-around-town/woman-around-town-daryl-roth-for-the-love-of-theatre|title=Daryl Roth—For the Love of Theatre - Woman Around Town|date=21 February 2010|publisher=}}</ref> * [[The Lady in Question]], a documentary based on the career of [[Charles Busch]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2005/film/markets-festivals/the-lady-in-question-is-charles-busch-1200526078/|title=The Lady in Question is Charles Busch|first=John|last=Anderson|date=5 May 2005|publisher=}}</ref> * [[A Very Serious Person]] written by Charles Busch, starring [[Polly Bergen]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charlesbusch.com/a_very_serious_person2.htm|title=A Very Serious Person|website=www.charlesbusch.com}}</ref> * [[Don't Ask Don't Tell (film)|Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell]] starring Marc Wolf<ref name=nota3rdpartysite/> * My Dog: An Unconditional Love Story a documentary exploring the relationships of well known New Yorkers and their dogs<ref name="womanaroundtown.com"/>
== Daryl Roth Theatre == The former Union Square Savings Bank building was acquired by Roth in 1996 and has undergone renovation and additions in order to create three venues. The [[Daryl Roth Theatre]], the DR2 Theatre and the cabaret bar: The D-Lounge.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.darylroththeatre.com/about/|title=The Daryl Roth Theatres|date=2013-08-21|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-23}}</ref>{{better source|independent source needed|date=February 2017}}
== Philanthropy and awards == Roth is a Member of the Mayor’s Theater Subdistrict Council,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.nyc.gov/office-of-the-mayor/news/255-15/mayor-de-blasio-appoints-members-theater-subdistrict-council|title=Mayor de Blasio Appoints Members of Theater Subdistrict Council|date=21 April 2015|publisher=}}</ref> an Honorary Trustee for [[Lincoln Center Theatre]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lct.org/about/board-directors/|title=Board of Directors - Lincoln Center Theater|first=Lincoln Center|last=Theater|website=Lincoln Center Theater}}</ref> and served on the Board of Directors of the [[Albert Einstein College of Medicine]] and [[New York State Council on the Arts]].
Her other awards and honors include: The 2016 Order of the Golden Sphinx Award from The Hasty Pudding Institute of 1770;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-hasty-pudding-institute-of-1770-to-honor-acclaimed-broadway-producer-daryl-roth-with-the-order-of-the-golden-sphinx-300203760.html|title=The Hasty Pudding Institute of 1770 to Honor Acclaimed Broadway Producer Daryl Roth with the Order of the Golden Sphinx|first=The Hasty Pudding Institute of|last=1770|website=www.prnewswire.com}}</ref> The 2014 New York Living Landmarks award;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/daryl-roth-and-jordan-roth-honored-as-living-landmarks-com-334775|title=Daryl Roth and Jordan Roth Honored As Living Landmarks - Playbill|website=Playbill}}</ref> The 2013 Einstein Humanitarian Award from The Women's Division and Albert Einstein College of Medicine;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forward.com/the-assimilator/tag/albert-einstein-college-of-medicine/|title=Albert Einstein College of Medicine – The Schmooze|publisher=}}</ref> The 2013 Broadway Association Visionary Leader Award;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Photo-Flash-Daryl-Roth-and-More-Honored-at-Broadway-Associations-2013-Awards-Luncheon-20130506|title=Photo Flash: Daryl Roth and More Honored at Broadway Association's 2013 Awards Luncheon|first=BWW News|last=Desk|publisher=}}</ref> The Stella Adler 2012 Harold Clurman Spirit Award;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stellaadler.com/stellapress/wp-content/uploads/2010/04/Stella-by-Starlight-Honoree-History.pdf |title=Stella by Starlight|website=stellaadler.com}}</ref> the 2012 Family Equality Council Hostetter-Habib Family Award; The 2011 Live Out Loud Humanitarian Award,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qOGmWOL2yBY|title=Live Out Loud Gala 2011: Daryl Roth-Humanitarian Award|first=|last=LiveOutLoud Info|date=27 May 2011|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> 2010 Lucille Lortel Lifetime Achievement Award,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/daryl-roth-will-be-given-lortel-award-for-lifetime-achievement-awards-are-may-2-com-164893|title=Daryl Roth Will Be Given Lortel Award for Lifetime Achievement; Awards Are May 2 - Playbill|website=Playbill}}</ref> Primary Stages 2007 Honoree,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americantheaterweb.com/index.php/originals/2008/07/30/primary-stages-gala-honors-lupone-and-th-27|title=Primary Stages Gala Honors LuPone and The Baruch-Routh-Frankel-Viertel Team Oct 27.|website=www.americantheaterweb.com}}</ref> The National Foundation for Jewish Culture’s Patron of the Arts Award,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forward.com/culture/5783/the-jewish-cultural-achievement-awards/|title=The Jewish Cultural Achievement Awards|publisher=}}</ref> The Jewish Theological Seminary’s Louis Marshall Award,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hadassahmagazine.org/2006/03/11/profile-daryl-roth/|title=Profile: Daryl Roth - Hadassah Magazine|date=11 March 2006|publisher=}}</ref> The Albert Einstein College of Medicine Spirit of Achievement Award,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://thescenenewyork.com/2015/05/25/the-61st-annual-spirit-of-achievement-luncheon/# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-06-13 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160330131450/http://thescenenewyork.com/2015/05/25/the-61st-annual-spirit-of-achievement-luncheon/# |archive-date=2016-03-30 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The National Corporate Theatre Fund’s Chairman Award, and The Tisch School of the Arts Award for Artistic Leadership.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/tisch-school-honors-alumni-inaugural-tisch-award-goes-to-bomb-itty-com-88614|title=Tisch School Honors Alumni: Inaugural Tisch Award Goes to Bomb-itty - Playbill|website=Playbill}}</ref> Roth has twice been included in Crain’s “100 Most Influential Women in Business.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crainsnewyork.com/gallery/20070916/FEATURES/309169999/84|title=Daryl Roth - Most Powerful Women in New York 2007 - Crain's New York Business|publisher=}}</ref>”
The Daryl Roth Creative Spirit Award annually honors a gifted theatre artist or organization, providing them with financial support as they develop new works in an artistic residency.<ref name=nota3rdpartysite/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.callmeadam.com/interviews/2013/1/24/daryl-roth-tedxbroadway-interview.html#.V18PNzUrK1s|title=Daryl Roth: TEDxBroadway Interview|publisher=}}</ref>
== Personal life == Roth is married to real estate investor [[Steven Roth]]. She has two children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jewishstandard.timesofisrael.com/from-wayne-to-broadway/|title=From Wayne to Broadway|publisher=}}</ref> Her son, [[Jordan Roth]], is president of Jujamcyn Theaters.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/09/theater/09theater.html|title=Jujamcyn Names Jordan Roth President, Signaling a Broadway Youth Trend|first=Patricia|last=Cohen|date=8 September 2009|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref>
