{{coord|37|40|24.66|N|122|4|52.72|W|region:US|display=title}} [[File:Downtownhaywardcitycenter.jpg|thumb|Downtown Hayward, looking south on Foothill Boulevard, with the [[City Center Building]] (left)]] '''Downtown Hayward''' is the original and current [[central business district]] of [[Hayward, California]], [[United States]], and is home to the current [[Hayward City Hall]], along with the two previous city halls, [[Alex Giualini Plaza]] and the [[City Center Building]]. The [[Hayward Fault]] runs through the area, and is the cause of the two previous city halls being taken out of use.
The boundaries are Third Street to the east, Grand Street and [[Hayward (BART station)|Hayward BART]] to the west, [[California State Route 92|Jackson Street]] and E Street to the south, and City Center Drive/Hazel Avenue to the north.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hayward-ca.gov/CITY-GOVERNMENT/SPECIAL-PROJECTS-&-STUDIES/dpu/img/plan_area.JPG |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-03-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130907122147/http://www.hayward-ca.gov/CITY-GOVERNMENT/SPECIAL-PROJECTS-%26-STUDIES/dpu/img/plan_area.JPG |archivedate=2013-09-07 |df= }}</ref> Foothill Boulevard was known as "The Golden Strip", a retail business corridor that was built in the 1950s, and housed [[The Emporium, San Francisco|Capwell's]] and [[I. Magnin]] department stores. The street lost businesses after the opening of [[Southland Mall (Hayward, California)|Southland Mall]] in 1964.<ref name="insidebayarea1">{{cite web|url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/oaklandtribune/localnews/ci_19616418 |title=Foothill Boulevard gateway getting face-lift in Hayward |publisher=Inside Bay Area |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref> Parks include Newman Park and The Julio Bras Portuguese Park. [[San Lorenzo Creek]] runs through downtown. The Hayward Public Library is located there. "Hayward City Center" a mall and building complex located at the northern end of downtown, contains the [[City Center Building]], which served as the city's second city hall from 1969 to 1991, and is now an abandoned 11 story building, Hayward's tallest building, formerly the second tallest prior to [[California State University, East Bay]]'s [[Warren Hall]] demolition in 2013. The City Center complex previously contained the now demolished [[Centennial Hall Convention Center]]. The bankrupt [[Mervyns]] department store chain's large [[Mervyns Building|former headquarters]] is across the street from the City Center mall. The [[Hayward Area Historical Society]] operates a museum downtown, which relocated and re-opened June 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haywardareahistory.org/ |title=Hayward Area Historical Society|publisher=Haywardareahistory.org|accessdate=2010-12-25}}</ref> The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] operates a resident agency in downtown Hayward.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/contact-us/field/resident-agencies/hayward-resident-agency|title=FBI — Hayward Resident Agency|publisher=Fbi.gov|accessdate=2010-12-25|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015031801/http://www.fbi.gov/contact-us/field/resident-agencies/hayward-resident-agency|archivedate=2011-10-15|df=}}</ref> The Hayward Art Council, founded in 1975, operates the Sun Gallery downtown.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sungallery.org/about.html |title=About Sun Gallery |publisher=Sungallery.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623010709/http://www.sungallery.org/about.html |archivedate=2012-06-23 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sungallery.org/contact.html |title=Contact Information and Gallery Location |publisher=Sungallery.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623001725/http://www.sungallery.org/contact.html |archivedate=2012-06-23 |df= }}</ref> The [[Independent Order of Odd Fellows]] building on B Street is one of Hayward's oldest buildings, and was built in 1868.<ref>{{cite web|last=Parr |first=Rebecca |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/news/ci_21142759/hometown-hero-mr-hayward-frank-goulart-historian-and |title=Hometown Hero: 'Mr. Hayward' Frank Goulart, a historian and activist - San Jose Mercury News |publisher=Mercurynews.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref> The Hayward [[Memorials and services for the September 11 attacks|9/11 Memorial]] was dedicated May 30, 2016, to the first responders who died in 9/11, and to the city's own fallen first responders, and the city's fallen soldiers.<ref>[http://www.eastbaytimes.com/breaking-news/ci_29913348/hayward-9-11-memorial-nears-completion]</ref>
==Cinema Place== Cinema Place is a {{convert|12000|sqft|m2}} entertainment and shopping center, comprising a single structure, which opened October 24, 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blakehunt.com/cinema_place.php |title=Blake Hunt Ventures, Inc |publisher=Blakehunt.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120723064035/http://www.blakehunt.com/cinema_place.php |archivedate=2012-07-23 |df= }}</ref> Directly adjacent to the center is a large city run parking garage. The City of Hayward has commissioned 3 large murals, designed by Hayward artist Andrew Kong Knight, decorating the exterior of the garage, featuring scenes from Hollywood and Hayward, which are being executed in 2011.<ref name="andrewkongknight1">{{cite web|url=http://www.andrewkongknight.com/art/murals/index.html|title=Public Art Mural Projects|publisher=Andrewkongknight.com|accessdate=2012-10-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320154900/http://www.andrewkongknight.com/art/murals/index.html|archivedate=2012-03-20|df=}}</ref> An additional mural by Knight is found at the northern end of The Hayward Strip.<ref name="andrewkongknight1"/><ref>{{cite web|author=: Andrew 380 friends |url=http://sanfrancisco.tribe.net/event/Hayward-Gateway-Mural-by-Andrew-Kong-Knight-Celebration-Party-Saturday-May-1-2010/san-francisco-ca/d62ae6c5-d941-4c35-809b-77227d15483e |title=Hayward Gateway Mural by Andrew Kong Knight ~ Celebration Party Saturday, May 1, 2010 - Hayward / Castro Valley - tribe.net |publisher=Sanfrancisco.tribe.net |date=2010-05-01 |accessdate=2012-10-24}}</ref> Hayward's Public Mural Art Program has won a Helen Putnam Award of Excellence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helenputnam.org/winners_2011.php |title=Helen Putnam Award of Excellence |publisher=Helenputnam.org |date=2012-04-12 |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
The [[Anchor store|main tenant]] is a [[Century Theatres|Century Theatre]] multiplex, which is Hayward's lone movie theater since [[Mann Theatres|Mann]]'s Festival Cinemas closed in 2003. In 2011, the Hayward Art Council opened a gallery on the ground floor of the center, in a storefront that has remained unused since the center's opening.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haywardarts.org/pages/events.html |title=About Hayward Arts Council |publisher=Haywardarts.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibabuzz.com/hayword/2011/01/19/cinema-place-gallery-opening-downtown/ |title=Cinema Place Gallery opening downtown - The HayWord |publisher=Ibabuzz.com |date=2011-01-19 |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
[[File:Allsaintscatholicchurchhayward.jpg|thumb|All Saints Catholic Church]]
==Other businesses== The Total Package Salon, under new ownership and new management, is located at 1122 B St. The salon is ran by celebrity stylists and women who have worked in the movie beauty industry. Truly a staple of Downtown Hayward. The [[Green Shutter Hotel]], a [[California Historical Landmark]], is located downtown. [[Buffalo Bill's Brewery]], founded in 1983 by photographer [[Bill Owens (photographer)|Bill Owens]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gregkucera.com/owens.htm |title=Bill Owens | Greg Kucera Gallery | Seattle |publisher=Gregkucera.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref><ref>[http://www.buffalobillsbrewery.com/bbb_about.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100801070813/http://www.buffalobillsbrewery.com/bbb_about.htm |date=August 1, 2010 }}</ref> is one of the first [[brewpub]]s to open in California since [[Prohibition in the United States|Prohibition]], after legislation passed in 1982 legalizing brewpubs again.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eastbayexpress.com/92510/archives/2007/09/13/tom-bates-beer-savior|title= ''Tom Bates: Beer Savior''|publisher= East Bay Express|date= September 13, 2007|accessdate=2012-10-24}}</ref> The ''[[Daily Review]]'' newspaper operated from downtown, until its closure in 2016.
==Services== The All Saints Catholic Church is located downtown.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sean |first=Michael |url=http://ncronline.org/news/faith-parish/pastor-dynamic-parish-shows-benefits-viable-alternative-structure |title=Dynamic California parish shows benefits of an alternative structure | National Catholic Reporter |publisher=Ncronline.org |date=2014-01-02 |accessdate=2014-03-01}}</ref> It operates the [[Mount Saint Joseph Cemetery (Hayward, California)|Mount Saint Joseph Cemetery]]. The Hayward Veterans' Memorial Building, built in 1932, is adjacent to the old City Hall building, and is available for public events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acgov.org/veterans/hayward/ |title=Hayward - Veterans' Memorial Building - Alameda County |publisher=Acgov.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref> The Hayward Area Historical Society opened a new museum, galleries, and an events venue in June 2014.<ref name="mercurynews.com">{{cite web|author=Rebecca ParrThe Daily Review |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_22410916/foothill-boulevard-hayward-undergoing-transformation |title=Foothill Boulevard in Hayward undergoing transformation - San Jose Mercury News |publisher=Mercurynews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-01}}</ref>
==Road improvements== [[File:Hayward 9 11 memorial 1.jpg|thumb|left|Hayward 9/11 Memorial]] The [[Hayward, California#Transportation|Route 238 Corridor Improvement Project]] broke ground July 2010, with an expected completion date in 2013. It will include undergrounding of telephone wires, and extensive landscaping, bringing parks and improved traffic flow to the downtown region. A one-way traffic loop for sections of A Street, Foothill Boulevard and Mission Boulevard went into effect March 15, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|author=Rebecca ParrThe Daily Review |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_22623941/hayward-begin-one-way-downtown-traffic-loop-march |title=Hayward to begin one-way downtown traffic loop March 15 - San Jose Mercury News |publisher=Mercurynews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-01}}</ref> The Foothill Boulevard business district is also scheduled to receive a $2.85 million face-lift, partly through $1.1 million in loans, improving the storefront facades and other amenities. New businesses opening include a [[microdistillery]] to be operated by Buffalo Bill's Brewery.<ref name="insidebayarea1"/><ref name="mercurynews.com"/>
[[File:Big Mike, Muffler Man, Hayward, California.jpg|thumb|"Big Mike", [[Muffler Men|"Muffler Man"]], long term fixture on Mission Boulevard (removed in 2011, moved to south Hayward in 2013)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/tip/3208 |title=Hayward, CA - Muffler Man - Sold, Moved |publisher=Roadsideamerica.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bellplastics.com/ |title=Custom Plastic Fabrication |publisher=Bell Plastics |date= |accessdate=2014-03-01}}</ref>]]

'''Electronic News Production System '''(ENPS) is a [[software]] application developed by the [[Associated Press]]'s Broadcast Technology division for producing, editing, timing, organizing and running news broadcasts. The system is scalable and flexible enough to handle anything from the local news at a small-market station to large organizations spanning remote [[News bureau|bureau]]s in multiple countries.
The basic organization of each news broadcast is called a "rundown" (US) or "running order" (UK). The run-down is a grid listing scripts, [[video]], [[Sound|audio]], [[character generator]] data, [[teleprompter]] control, director notations, camera operator cues, and timing estimates for each section of the broadcast.
ENPS integrates scripts, [[wire feed]]s, [[device control]], and production information in a [[Server (computing)|server]]/client environment. On the server side, ENPS runs an identical [[backup server]] (called a "buddy") at all times as a fail-safe. If the primary server fails, all users are redirected to the buddy server until such time as the primary comes back on-line. All document changes are queued on the buddy and copied back to the primary automatically when it returns to production. Note that this is not a [[mirror website|mirror server]] as the changed data is copied to the buddy, but there is no direct replication inherent within the intercommunications between the servers, so if the data is corrupted due to hardware failure on one server, this corruption will not be replicated to the "buddy".
Device control can be managed either through a [[serial interface]], or the MOS ([[Media Object Server]]) protocol. MOS functionality is included in the base ENPS license, but may be an extra add-on for the device that needs to interface with ENPS. MOS items such as video or audio clips can be added directly to scripts, and then used by third party software and devices during the broadcast. Many broadcast media systems support the MOS protocol to a greater or lesser degree by implementing any of the seven MOS Protocol 'profiles'. An example of a MOS System which fully supports all seven MOS Profiles is SIENNA [http://www.enps.com/partner_systems/51/gallery_sienna] [http://sienna.tv], used by ENPS customers including the BBC.
The ENPS client utilizes the .NET framework and other Windows-only technologies. The client, therefore, will only run in the [[Microsoft Windows]] [[operating system]].
ENPS was originally developed by the Associated Press for use at the [[BBC]] in the [[United Kingdom]] as a replacement for the [[text mode]] system [[BASYS]] (which developed into [[Avid iNEWS]]), and the Corporation has the largest installation of the system with over 12,000 users in 300 different locations [http://www.enps.com/files/marketing/ENPS%20and%20BBC.pdf].
On December 15, 2011 [[Synaptic Digital]] announced a partnership with ENPS to deliver their content on [[thenewsmarket.com]] directly to subscribers of their feed.[http://www.synapticdigital.com/2011/12/15/synaptic-digital-teams-up-with-the-associated-press-to-distribute-video-content-from-thenewsmarket-com-via-enps-system/]

'''Emil Corsillo Inc.''' was a company that manufactured [[hairpiece]]s; primarily for the [[entertainment industry]].
==History== Emil was an Italian immigrant. Together with his wife, Elsie Koch, he founded Emil Corsillo Inc., the famous [[Hollywood]] company that for close to 50 years supplied the entertainment industry in with [[toupee]]s, headpieces, [[wig]]s, and manufactured [[mannequin]] wigs.
Emil was the originator of the mannequin wig in the 1940s. The wigs were made from [[nylon]].<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1368&dat=19440109&id=7fgZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7g0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6154,4190241 The Milwaukee Sentinel - Jan 9, 1944] "This pretty young woman is wearing Nylon wig...."</ref> On September 6, 1950, Corsillo filed a [[patent]] for his wigs, in particular, the reinforced wig foundation frames (where the fake hair was attached). He was issued with Patent number: 2661749 in December 1953.<ref>[https://books.google.com/patents/about?id=8mFSAAAAEBAJ Patent details]</ref>
Most of the Hollywood actors that required a hairpiece were clients of the company. Among them were [[Bozo the Clown]], [[Harpo Marx]], [[Brian Donlevy]], [[Hal Fishman]], and many more.
Emil died in 1967, but the company continued on into the 1980s when it was closed. The decline in demand was attributed to new technologies and imports.

__NOTOC__ The '''Empowerment Experiment''' (formerly called the '''Ebony Experiment'''<ref name=APMar122009>Couple's 'buy black' experiment becomes a movement, Associated Press, May 12, 2009</ref> as of March 12, 2009), was co-founded by John and Maggie Anderson of Oak Park, Illinois. [[Steven S. Rogers]], director of the Kellogg Entrepreneurial Practice Center at [[Northwestern University]]'s Graduate School of Management, serves as an Executive Advisor to the experiment, which is a year-long study designed to find out what happens when people buy things only from black-owned businesses.<ref>[http://www.suntimes.com/business/1341775,CST-FIN-buyblack21.article Their year of buying black], Chicago Sun Times, December 20, 2008.</ref>
Some participants who are committed to this movement have been willing to drive substantially longer distances than what they had driven before the movement started, in order to purchase goods from black-owned businesses.<ref name=trib>[http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/chi-buying-black-09-mar09,0,1956992.story Oak Park couple travel far and wide to buy only from black-owned businesses], The Chicago Tribune, March 9, 2009</ref>
By May 12, 2009, 4,000 people had signed up on the Andersons' website to participate in their experiment.<ref name=APMar122009/>
The [[United States]] has one million black-owned businesses, which account for more than $100 billion in annual sales. Blacks have more than $800 billion in expendable income each year.<ref name=APMar122009/>
==Praise== Lawrence Hamer, associate professor of marketing at [[DePaul University]], praised the experiment as being "brave and courageous," and said the rationale for it was "exactly right."<ref name=trib/>
James E. Clingman, who writes frequently about [[African-American]] economic empowerment, and also teaches a class on black entrepreneurship at the [[University of Cincinnati]], said, "I'd rather have more black businesses than black politicians."<ref name=trib/>
Gregory Price, chairman of the economics department at [[Morehouse College]], said the ideas behind the movement were similar to the ideas expressed by black visionaries like [[Booker T. Washington]] and [[Marcus Garvey]]. Price also said, "The idea is a sound one, given that black Americans are still underrepresented in the ranks of the self-employed and that entrepreneurship is a key component to wealth."<ref name=APMar122009/>
==See also== *[[Black capitalism]] * The [[WhereU]] app and online directory of black-owned businesses *[[African-American businesses]] *[[The Black Wall Street (disambiguation)|The Black Wall Street]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website}}

{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{advert|date=April 2015}} {{lowercase title}} {{Infobox company | name = i54 South Staffordshire | type = Not Classified | image = I54 and M54.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = The i54 plant with the M54 motorway in the foreground. This is at Junction 2 of the motorway looking south-eastwards. | foundation = 2005 | founder = [[Advantage West Midlands]], [[Staffordshire County Council]], [[Wolverhampton City Council]] | location_city = [[South Staffordshire]] | location_country = England | industry = Manufacturing, [[Offices]], Research, [[Hotels]], [[Information technology|IT]] and Technology | homepage = [http://www.i54online.com/ i54 Official Website] }}
'''i54 South Staffordshire''' is a 239-acre (98 hectare) UK technology-based business park strategically located at Junction 2 on the [[M54 Motorway]] in the [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands]], on the boundary of [[South Staffordshire]] and [[Wolverhampton]].
i54 South Staffordshire is a £50 million pound joint venture partnership between [[Staffordshire County Council]], [[Wolverhampton City Council]] and [[South Staffordshire Council]] and has attracted global business occupants, which have in turn warranted visits from the UK Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] and [[Her Majesty The Queen]]. It benefits from Enterprise Zone Status and falls within the [[Black Country Enterprise Zone]].
The site entrance is at Junction 2 of the [[M54 Motorway]], just to the west of the [[Staffordshire and Worcestershire Canal]]. The site is home to several global high-tech and advanced manufacturing companies including [[Moog Inc|MOOG]] Aerospace, [[Eurofins]] Laboratories, International Security Printers (ISP) and the home of the £500 million UK advance engine manufacturing facility of [[Jaguar Land Rover]].
== The aim == The aim of this strategically location business site is to deliver major employment opportunities and maximise job creation potential in key industries. It will also play a key role in the diversification and growth of the regional economy. It is also believed that i54 South Staffordshire will achieve high standards of sustainability.
The regeneration project is a joint venture between [[Wolverhampton City Council]], [[Staffordshire County Council]] and [[South Staffordshire Council]].
== Project costs and details == The cost of the project to the 98 hectare site is estimated to be costing £67 million [[GBP]] and was granted crucial planning approvals from two local authorities in September 2006.
In August 2006 contractors to the site started the second major phase of the scheme, a £5 million [[GBP]] 12-month programme of infrastructure and reclamation work.
On Tuesday 3 July 2007 key partners for the project toasted the substantial completion of a £10 million [[GBP]] programme of remediation and site preparation works on the i54 site. The site preparation work ran over a 16-month period and has been carried out by Blackwell and supervised by [[Mouchel Parkman]] engineering consultancy. During this time the following was achieved:
* Produced level development plots * Installation of primary infrastructure including a spine road * Drainage Systems * Site fencing * Creation of new wetland and ecological habitats
Other statistics include:
* 152,000 cubic metres of topsoil has been excavated but retained on site. * 190,000 cubic metres of sub-soil and rock excavated and reused on site. * 1 kilometre spine road constructed * 4.5 kilometres of fencing erected ''(3 kilometres still to be erected)'' * Total of 6,500 cubic metres of ponds and [[Swale (landform)|swales]] created as part of the landscaping
== Jaguar Land Rover == {{Update|section|date=September 2017}} {{main|Engine Manufacturing Centre}} On 25 April 2011, [[Jaguar Land Rover]] expressed an interest in the i54 site as a possible location for a new advanced engine plant.<ref name=autogenerated1>[https://www.expressandstar.com/business/midlands-business/2011/04/25/jlr-plans-i54-wolverhampton-engine-plant-and-1000-jobs/ JLR plans i54 Wolverhampton engine plant and 1,000 jobs « Express & Star]</ref> On 19 September 2011 Deputy Prime Minister [[Nick Clegg]] announced at the engine factory in Solihull the proposals for Jaguar Land Rover's decision to build their new engine plant in [[South Staffordshire]] creating around 1400 additional jobs within the company and more within the supply chain which will be created by a £500 million investment by Jaguar Land Rover and £10m by the Government.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-14973720 BBC News – JLR investment 'vote of confidence']</ref> The new plant in Wolverhampton will join other Midlands-based plants in Solihull and Castle Bromwich as well as the birthplace of the new [[Evoque]] in Halewood, Liverpool.<ref>[https://www.expressandstar.com/lifestyle/motors/2011/03/14/jaguar-land-rover-eyes-record-sales-year/ Jaguar Land Rover eyes record sales year « Express & Star]</ref>
It is understood that Jaguar Land Rover are taking on the investments to meet the demands of high sales in Asia.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> The new engine plant will be home to the new family of 4-cylinder petrol and diesel engines for the luxury [[Land Rover]] brand,<ref>[http://www.engineeringcapacity.com/news101/business-news/jlr-plant-is-good-news-for-all Engineering Capacity – JLR plant is good news for all]</ref> originally brought to help boost technology in [[Tata Motors]] vehicle range.<ref>[http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/features/jlrs-em-foray-gamechanger-for-tata-motors_588248.html JLR's EM foray: Gamechanger for Tata Motors? – Moneycontrol.com]</ref> JLR chief executive Dr [[Ralf Speth]] announced that £1.5 billion is to be invested into the company and the new engine plant each year for the next 5 years on product development and the engine range. JLR engines are currently being supplied by [[Ford Motors]]<ref>[http://www.autocar.co.uk/News/NewsArticle/AllCars/259222/ JLR's new UK engine plant | Autocar]</ref>
== Usage potential == * Around {{convert|2000000|sqft|m2|-3}} of industrial space * {{convert|376000|sqft|m2|-2}} of commercial/retail and leisure.
==Construction== Construction started on site in 2011, with MOOG fully operational on site by the start of 2012. The Aerospace company makes flight controls and spent £15 million to move from its current location, to the i54 South Staffordshire development. The company hopes to safeguard 400 jobs with its relocation. Laboratory firm [[Eurofins Scientific|Eurofins]] also moved into the development and was fully operational by 2012.
==Enterprise zone== The i54 South Staffordshire site is the largest of the 19 sites which make up the Black Country Enterprise Zone, which has 5 sites in Wolverhampton and 14 in [[Darlaston]], Walsall.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.expressandstar.com/news/2013/06/16/more-than-350-jobs-to-be-created-at-site/ |title=More than 350 jobs to be created at site |publisher=[[Express & Star]] |date=16 June 2013 |accessdate=11 March 2015}}</ref> The creation of the zone for the Black Country was announced on 23 March 2011 by Chancellor George Osborne. [[Enterprise zone]] status speeds up the process of allowing companies to re-locate to the site and encourages it with tax breaks.<ref>[https://www.expressandstar.com/news/2011/03/24/tax-breaks-boost-for-local-businesses/ Tax breaks boost for local businesses « Express & Star]</ref>
==Companies at i54 South Staffordshire== *MOOG (2011) *Eurofins (2011) *Jaguar Land Rover (2014) *International Security Printers (ISP) (2014) *ERA (Home Security Company) (2018) *Atlas Copco (2018)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.i54online.com/ i54 Official Web Site] *[http://www.staffordshire.gov.uk/business/Land-and-Premises/i54SouthStaffordshire/home.aspx Staffordshire County Council- i54 home] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071006142720/http://www.advantagewm.co.uk/what-we-do/improving-places/land-and-property/occupier-opportunities/i54.aspx Advantage West Midlands – i54] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071024080812/http://www.advantagewm.co.uk/news-media-events/news/2007/07/i54-development-a-giant-step-closer-to-reality.aspx i54 development a giant step closer to reality] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071022091144/http://www.advantagewm.co.uk/news-media-events/news/2006/08/5-million-scheme-brings-i54-one-step-closer-to-reality.aspx £5 million scheme brings i54 one step closer to reality] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070830123014/http://www.sstaffs.gov.uk/Default.aspx?page=13311 South Staff Council – i54]

'''Jan Baan''' (Born in [[Rijssen]], 9 March 1946) is a Dutch [[entrepreneur]] and [[venture capitalist]], known as the founder of the [[Baan Corporation|Baan Company]], a software company providing [[Enterprise Resource Planning]] (ERP) software. After selling the company, he founded Cordys, a company to provide web-related ERP products.<ref>{{cite web|last=Abrahams |first=Peter |title=Jan Baan the software man |publisher=[[The Register]] |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2004/06/25/jan_baan_cordys/ |accessdate=12 February 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6NKM2jlKQ?url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2004/06/25/jan_baan_cordys/ |archivedate=12 February 2014 |date=25 June 2004 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Biography == Baan was born and raised in [[Rijssen]] as eldest son in a family of ten. His father was a [[carpenter]], and his grandfather on his mother's side was cofounder of a regional bus company.<ref name="HM 2004">Henk Post "[https://books.google.com/books?id=SHub0hNZSEQC&pg=PA229 De snelle groei van de Baan Company: de rol van Jan Baan] in: ''Ondernemen in netwerken.'' Wim Hulsink, Dick Manuel (eds.), 2004. p. 291</ref>
At the age of 16, Baan started working at a [[Slaughterhouse|meatworks]], leaving secondary school without a degree. After serving in the military, Baan got a job at an accounting firm. In 1970, he started working for a wholesale firm, where after two years he became head of the accounting department. When the company bought their first computer, Baan got acquainted with automation. Mid 1970s Baan started working as a consultant, and shortly managed the financial department of a large company.<ref name="HM 2004"/>
In 1978, Jan founded The Baan Company, a software company providing ERP solutions, which became a major player in the ERP software industry. Jan Baan left the Baan Company in 1998. After his efforts with the Baan Company, Baan became a venture capitalist<ref name="HM 2004"/> and invested in companies like Top Tier and [[WebEx]]; both were eventually valued above $1billion. Top Tier was later sold to [[SAP AG|SAP]], while WebEx was sold to [[Cisco]]. In an interview, Baan said that "... with [[WebEx]] and Top Tier I was an investor. [[Baan Corporation|Baan]], and [[Cordys]], I do for life. I am not a serial entrepreneur at all." <ref>CBR Online's Q&A: Jan Baan on the demise of Baan and the birth of Cordys Part 1, 20 April 2010</ref>
In 2005, Baan wrote a book on his life as an entrepreneur, called The Way to Market Leadership.<ref>The Way To Market Leadership [https://www.amazon.com/Way-Market-Leadership-Life-Entrepreneur/dp/B00289ZRZO], 21 April 2010</ref>
== Work ==
=== Baan Company === The Baan Company was founded in 1978. With the development of his first software package in 1979, he commenced his career in the ERP industry. His brother [[Paul Baan]] joined him in the management of the company. Under Jan's stewardship, the company made good market in the field of [[Enterprise Resource Planning]] (ERP) software and grew from a $35 million company in the early 1990s to $680 million in 1998.
The Baan Company competed successfully with large companies like [[SAP AG|SAP]] and [[PeopleSoft]] and became the number 2 ERP player in the software industry.<ref>Cordys Executive Team: Jan Baan, Executive Chairman and CEO [http://www.cordys.com/ufc/file2/cordyscms_sites/download/dad8a85a9d49e6fa99ced341d1fe535d/pu/bio_jan_baan.pdf], 21 April 2010</ref> However, the company's fall started in 1998 as the stocks started to dip and eventually in 2000 it was sold to the British company [[Invensys]].<ref>The Baan Company [http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/Baan-Company-Company-History.html], 21 April 2010</ref>
=== Cordys === In 2001, Baan started a new company, Cordys, along with Theodoor van Donge. The intention was to produce products serving to bridge the traditional [[Enterprise Resource Planning]] products with the internet, using the internet as the front end.<ref>Cordys Background [http://www.cordys.com/cordyscms_com/cordys_history_mission.php], 21 April 2010</ref><ref>ERP pioneer Jan Baan on impact of BPM [http://searchsoa.techtarget.com/news/article/0,289142,sid26_gci1378738,00.html], 21 April 2010</ref> In 2010 Cordys Switzerland AG was founded as an independent legal entity according to Swiss law. The Swiss company was not part of the later M&A deal between Jan Baan and OpenText.
In August 2013, Jan Baan sold Cordys to [[OpenText]] for 33M USD.

{{no footnotes|date= July 2016}} {{Infobox military person |name = John Mercer Brockenbrough |birth_date = {{birth date|1830|8|1}} |death_date = {{death date and age|1892|8|24|1830|8|1}} |nickname = |birth_place = [[Richmond County, Virginia]] |death_place = |placeofburial= [[Hollywood Cemetery (Richmond, Virginia)]] |spouse = Austina ''Brockenbrough'' (cousin)
Kate Cornelia ''Mallory'' |allegiance = {{flag|Confederate States of America|1861}} |branch = {{army|CSA}} |serviceyears = 1861–1864 (CSA) |rank = [[File:Confederate States of America Colonel.png|35px]] [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] (CSA) |unit = |commands = {{flagicon|Virginia|1861}} [[40th Virginia Infantry]] (CSA) |battles = [[American Civil War]] |awards = |relations = |laterwork = }} '''John Mercer Brockenbrough''' (August 1, 1830 – August 24, 1892) was a farmer and a [[Confederate States Army|Confederate]] [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]] in the [[American Civil War]]. ==Early life== Brockenbrough, the son of Moore Fauntleroy Brockenbrough and his wife Sarah Waller Smith was born August 1, 1830 in [[Richmond County, Virginia]]. He is a 2nd cousin of [[John White Brockenbrough]] and his sister, Civil War diarist, Judith White (Brockenbrough) McGuire. He graduated from the [[Virginia Military Institute]] in 1850. ==Civil War== At the start of the Civil War, Brockenbrough was appointed [[colonel]] of the [[40th Virginia Infantry]], which served attached to Brig. Gen. [[Charles W. Field]]'s Virginia [[brigade]] in [[Major General|Maj. Gen.]] [[A.P. Hill]]'s Light Division and later Maj. Gen. [[Henry Heth]]'s division in the Third Corps, [[Army of Northern Virginia]]. Brockenbrough led his [[regiment]] through the [[Seven Days Battles]], a punishing series of battles that caused 50% casualties in his regiment. Brockenbrough assumed command of the brigade after Field was wounded at the [[Second Battle of Bull Run]] and led it two days later at [[Battle of Chantilly|Chantilly]]. During the [[Maryland Campaign]], he took part in the capture of [[Battle of Harpers Ferry|Harpers Ferry]], and then marched with the rest of the Light Division to the rescue of Gen. [[Robert E. Lee]]'s army at [[Battle of Antietam|Sharpsburg]]; his brigade was deployed on the far right of A.P. Hill's line and did not see any direct action there. At [[Battle of Fredericksburg|Fredericksburg]], his brigade was ordered to plug a hole in the Confederate line that was being exploited by [[Union Army|Union]] troops under Maj. Gen. [[George G. Meade]]. Brockenbrough lost control of his brigade during this action and two of his regiments split off with him and never reached the fighting. Lee apparently was not impressed with Brockenbrough's leadership qualities. Even though months had passed, the unit was still called Field's Brigade and Brockenbrough was still considered its temporary commander. Lee did not recommend him for promotion. In early 1863, Lee brought Brig. Gen. [[Henry Heth]] from assignment in [[Tennessee]] to replace Brockenbrough in command of the brigade (soon called "Heth's Brigade"), hoping to restore it to fighting shape. During the [[Battle of Chancellorsville]], Heth took over command of the division when Hill was wounded on May 2, 1863, which meant that Brockenbrough was back in command of the brigade on May 3, when it lost around 300 men storming the enemy line. After the battle, Brockenbrough was given a rare commendation for leading the attack by General Heth. He remained in brigade command when Heth was promoted to command a new division. At the [[Battle of Gettysburg]], Brockenbrough's brigade was in the rear of Heth's column during the march on the Chambersburg Pike, July 1, 1863, and thus missed the morning attacks against the [[Union Army|Union]] cavalry and the [[I Corps (ACW)|I Corps]]. In the afternoon attacks, his men advanced on a line with [[J. Johnston Pettigrew]]'s North Carolina brigade, and although the latter brigade fought fiercely, suffering over a thousand casualties, Brockenbrough's brigade was hesitant and fought ineffectively against the Pennsylvanians of Col. [[Roy Stone]] and a portion of the [[Iron Brigade]], as may be inferred from their casualty rate of 100. The brigade rested on July 2, but on July 3 participated in the bloody assault known as [[Pickett's Charge]]. There is no record that Brockenbrough marched with his men toward [[Cemetery Ridge]] that day, however, and Col. [[Robert M. Mayo]] of the [[47th Virginia Infantry]] was in temporary command. It is possible that the death of Brockenbrough's brother during the battle on July 1 left him distraught and unable to step up to his responsibilities. Assigned to the far left flank of Pettigrew's divisional line, the brigade was subjected to heavy shelling from Union artillery on [[Cemetery Hill]] and when the [[8th Ohio Infantry]] came up on their left flank, the Virginians turned and ran. During the Confederate retreat back to Virginia, Brockenbrough attempted to reclaim some of his damaged reputation by making a reckless advance against Union troops at [[Battle of Williamsport|Falling Waters]] on July 14, suffering numerous casualties. Five days later, Brockenbrough's former regimental lieutenant colonel, Brig. Gen. [[Henry Harrison Walker]], was given command of the brigade, returning Brockenbrough to the 40th Virginia, which he led at [[Bristoe Campaign|Bristoe]] and [[Battle of Mine Run|Mine Run]]. On January 21, 1864, Brockenbrough resigned from the Confederate States Army. He retained his rank of colonel in the reserves until late 1864. ==Postbellum life== After the war, Brockenbrough lived in [[Norfolk, Virginia|Norfolk]] and [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]]. He died in Richmond and is buried there in [[Hollywood Cemetery (Richmond, Virginia)|Hollywood Cemetery]]. ==Notes== {{reflist|2|refs= {{cite web|title=John Mercer Brockenbrough|url=https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=7014760|publisher=Find A Grave|accessdate=30 July 2017}} {{cite web|title=John Mercer Brockenbrough|url=https://archivesweb.vmi.edu/rosters/record.php?ID=121|publisher=Virginia Military Institute|accessdate=30 November 2017}} }} ==References== * Allardice, Bruce S. ''Confederate Colonels: A Biographical Register''. Columbia: University of Missouri Press, 2008. {{ISBN|978-0-8262-1809-4}}. * Eicher, John H., and [[David J. Eicher]]. ''Civil War High Commands''. Stanford, CA: Stanford University Press, 2001. {{ISBN|0-8047-3641-3}}. * Tagg, Larry. [http://www.rocemabra.com/~roger/tagg/generals/ ''The Generals of Gettysburg'']. Campbell, CA: Savas Publishing, 1998. {{ISBN|1-882810-30-9}}. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051028172103/http://aphillcsa.com/brockenbrough.html Online biography] {{Gettysburg figures|state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brockenbrough, John Mercer}} [[Category:1830 births]] [[Category:1892 deaths]] [[Category:People from Richmond County, Virginia]] [[Category:Confederate States Army officers]] [[Category:People of Virginia in the American Civil War]] [[Category:Virginia Military Institute alumni]] [[Category:Burials at Hollywood Cemetery (Richmond, Virginia)]] [[Category:Military personnel from Norfolk, Virginia]] [[Category:Military personnel from Richmond, Virginia]] [[Category:Brockenbrough family of Virginia]]

'''Lisa Hickey''' is an [[Americans|American]] author, advertising consultant, and social media consultant. She is the CEO of Good Men Media, Inc. and the Publisher of Good Men Magazine as part of the [[Good Men Project]].<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://goodmenproject.com/about/| title=About Us - The Good Men Project |publisher=Good Men Magazine | accessdate=2010-01-16}}</ref>
==Education== Hickey received a Bachelor of Arts in Psychology and Sociology from the [[University of Rochester]] in 1979 where she graduated Cum Laude. Hickey went onto acquire a Certificate in Graphic Design from the Massachusetts College of Art in Boston, Massachusetts. {{Cite web|url=http://www.lisahickeycreative.com/LisaResume100108.pdf |title=Lisa Hickey Resume |publisher=Lisa Hickey Creative |accessdate=2010-01-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306155629/http://www.lisahickeycreative.com/LisaResume100108.pdf |archivedate=2009-03-06 |df= }}
==Career== In 1999, Hickey opened her own agency, Velocity Advertising. The agency was known for offering full-service capabilities to clients regardless of their geographic location. Prior to Velocity, Hickey worked for companies such as Boston's Heater Advertising (Renamed Red), Arnold Worldwide and [[Holland Mark]] Advertising. One advertisement she helped create while at Hill Holiday, a spot for [[Lotus Notes]], has a permanent home in the Museum of [[Modern Art]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.allbusiness.com/marketing-advertising/4188303-1.html |publisher=AdWeek |title=Hickey Spurs Creative Velocity |first=David |last=Gianatasio |date=December 4, 2000}}</ref>
Hickey has also helped to resurrect Holland Mark, an agency that she had worked for in the late nineties. In 2007, Hickey was part of a team assembled by Chris Colbert to help re-open the previously troubled company.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/stories/2007/05/14/story15.html |publisher=Boston Business Journal |title='One-time highflier' Holland Mark back in business |first=Lisa |last=van der Pool |date=May 14, 2007}}</ref>
In 2009, Hickey teamed up with media critic Steve Hall and Edward Boches,<ref>[[Edward Boches]]</ref> Mullen’s chief creative officer to live tweet [[Super Bowl XLIII]] advertising. Hickey, Hall, and [[Edward Boches|Boches]] were looking to explore how pre-game advertising exposure online and real-time reactions to Super Bowl television advertising may begin to change the nature of the “Water Cooler” chatter and how consumers interact with brands.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.amaboston.net/2009/02/03/move-over-football-theres-a-new-super-bowl-spectator-sport-ad-tweets-2/ |publisher=AMA Boston |title=Move over football, there’s a new Super Bowl spectator sport: Ad Tweets |first=Sarah |last=Montague |date=February 3, 2009}}</ref>
==Good Men Media, Inc.== Good Men Media, Inc. is a multi-platform, multi-media company that aims to spark a national discussion around the question of “What does it mean to be a good man?” Good Men Media publishes ''The Good Men Project magazine'', which has received mainstream media accolades for heralding “a new era of men’s magazines.”<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.thesmokingpoet.net/id7.html |publisher=The Smoking Poet |title=A Good Cause: The Good Men Project | accessdate=January 16, 2010}}</ref>
The for-profit arm of the [[Good Men Project]], Good Men Media, Inc., was founded in March 2010 by Hickey, an advertising veteran and social media consultant. Hickey is also the CEO. Good Men Media gives back a portion of proceeds to the Foundation in return for licensing the Good Men Project name.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.necn.com/03/19/10/BBJ-Focusing-on-Good-Men-issues/landing.html?blockID=200453&feedID=4215 |title=Focusing on "good men" issues | publisher=NECN | date=March 19, 2010}}</ref> Hickey was responsible for creating a plan, figuring out an operational structure, and raising investor funding.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://boston.featuredbiz.com/2010/12/12/“i’m-a-fan-of-good-men”-an-interview-with-lisa-hickey-ceo-of-good-men-media-inc-and-publisher-of-the-good-men-project-magazine/ |publisher=Featured Biz Boston |title="I'm a Fan of Good Men": an interview with Lisa Hickey | last=editorl |date=December 12, 2010}}</ref>
Good Men Media is responsible for publishing the online magazine, The Good Men Project, and is also developing book, film and technological applications that all focus on men’s issues.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/news/2010/11/16/good-men-media-nabs-funding.html |publisher=Boston Business Journal |title=Good Men Media nabs funding |first=Lisa |last=van der Pool |date=November 16, 2010}}</ref>
In November 2010, Good Men Media received a round of angel funding for $500,000. The Boston company plans to use the funding to expand distribution of men's related content and to support revenue growth. Investors in Good Men Media include project founder Tom Matlack and private angel investors Grant Gund, managing partner of Coppermine Capital; Jack Roberts, CEO and president of Consert Inc.; Mike Jackson, former partner at Lehman Brothers and founding partner of Ironwood and Housatonic Partners; and Michael Margolis, founder of the investment management firm Maric LS, LLC, and others.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://bostinnovation.com/2010/11/16/female-ceo-focuses-on-community-of-good-men-secures-500k/ | publisher=Boston Innovation | title=Female CEO focuses on community of ‘Good Men,’ secures $500k | first=Cheryl | last=Morris | date=November 16, 2010}}</ref>
==Publications== Hickey has published three books on the subject of advertising and graphic design. Her first book, ''Design Secrets: Advertising: 50 Real-Life Projects Uncovered'', was released in 2002 as part of the Design Secrets Series published by Rockport Publishers. The book showcases 50 real-life design projects, including original plans, sketches, interim drawings, and presentations each accompanied by informative captions that show how designers present their ideas, and solve problems.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://grapheast.com/mall/book_details.php?book_id=91&cat_id=22&cn=Design|title=Design Secrets: Advertising | publisher=Rockport Publishers | year=2002}}</ref>
Her second book, also published by Rockport Publishers, was released in 2004 and is titled ''Designs That Stand Up, Speak Out, and Can't Be Ignored: Promotions''. According to the description, the book includes the A-list of projects that have found a way to grab the attention of their audiences, despite all the stimuli that can get in the way.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/1592531040|title= Designs That Stand Up, Speak Out, and Can't Be Ignored | publisher=Rockport Publishers | year=2004}}</ref>
Her most recent book was published in 2007 by Quarry Books and is titled ''Little Book of Big Promotions'' which she co-authored with Lisa Cyr and Cheryl Dangle Cullen. The book contains design ideas, insight into the creative process and execution, and tools and information to help make the right production decisions.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/1592533558|title= Little Book of Big Promotions | publisher=Quarry Books | year=2007}}</ref>
Hickey is also a published poet. Her latest poem, ''Mail Order Tadpoles'', was featured in ''Rattle'', an online poetry magazine.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://rattle.com/blog/2008/07/mail-order-tadpoles-by-lisa-hickey/ | publisher=Rattle | title=Mail Order Tadpoles | first=Lisa | last=Hickey | date=July 4, 2008}}</ref>

The [[Donald J. Trump Foundation]] is a New York-based charitable foundation founded by [[Donald Trump]], [[President of the United States]]. The following is a partial list of grants made by the foundation from 2006 through 2009.
== Partial List of grants reported by the Foundation Center == The foundation's annual [[IRS]] [[IRS Form 990|Form 990]] filing would normally contain the full list of grants made by the foundation.<ref name="Solnik">{{cite web |last=Solnik |first=Claude |url=http://libn.com/2016/09/15/taking-a-peek-at-trumps-foundation-tax-returns/ |title=Taking a peek at Trump’s (foundation) tax returns |work=[[Long Island Business News]] |date=September 15, 2016 |quote="charitable giving to conservative political groups, healthcare and sports-related charities"}}</ref><ref>Qiu, Linda (August 28, 2016). [http://www.politifact.com/punditfact/statements/2016/aug/28/david-plouffe/yes-donald-trump-donated-100000-clinton-foundation/ Yes, Donald Trump donated $100,000 to the Clinton Foundation.] ''Politifact.'' Retrieved: September 16, 2016.</ref><ref name="WaPoMissing">{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/a-portrait-of-trump-the-donor-free-rounds-of-golf-but-no-personal-cash/2016/04/10/373b9b92-fb40-11e5-9140-e61d062438bb_story.html |title=Missing from Trump's list of charitable giving: His own personal cash |date=April 10, 2016 |last2=Helderman |first2=Rosalind S. |newspaper=The Washington Post |first1=David A. |last1=Fahrenthold}}</ref> The following lists are incomplete.
The following were reported to the [[Foundation Center]] during the year 2006:<ref name=":8">''The Foundation Directory, 2009 Edition'', p. 7170 (David G. Jacobs, Senior Editor).</ref>
*[[United Way of America|United Way]] of New York City — $250,000 *[[Operation Smile]] — $117,000 *[[Dana Farber Cancer Institute]] — $60,000 *[[Police Athletic League]] of New York — $60,000 *[[Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum|Intrepid Museum Foundation]] — $50,000 *[[Visiting Nurse Service of New York|Visiting Nurse and Hospice Care]] — $25,000 *[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] — $15,000
The following grants were reported to the Foundation Center during the year 2007:<ref name=":9">''The Foundation Directory, 2010 Edition'', p. 7129 (David G. Jacobs, Senior Editor).</ref>
*[[Police Athletic League of New York City|Police Athletic League of New York]] — $110,000 *[[Fisher House Foundation]] of Maryland — $100,000 *[[New York-Presbyterian Hospital]] — $100,000 *[[Metropolitan Amateur|Metropolitan Golf Association Foundation]] — $50,000 *[[Dana Farber Cancer Institute]] — $25,000 *[[American Veterans Disabled for Life Memorial|Disabled Veterans LIFE Memorial Foundation]] of Florida — $25,000 *[[Joe Torre#Joe Torre Foundation|Joe Torre Safe at Home Foundation]] of New York — $25,000 *[[New York City Police Foundation]] — $25,000 *Palm Beach Police Department of Florida — $25,000
The ''[[Palm Beach Post]]'' has listed some additional recipients, as "a few of the larger donations made by the foundation through the years":<ref>Lord, Debbie. [http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/national/trump-foundation-works-little-differently-most/nsYDn/ "What you need to know about the Trump Foundation"], ''[[Palm Beach Post]]'' (September 14, 2016).</ref>
*[[Billy Graham Evangelistic Association]] and [[Samaritan’s Purse]] — $135,000 *[[Leukemia and Lymphoma Society]] — $50,000 *[[Drumthwacket]] Foundation — $40,000 *[[Citizens United Foundation]] — $100,000
According to a review by the ''[[International Business Times]]'', the Trump Foundation did not give to [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]] causes until 2010, when donations to conservative organizations were first reported.<ref name="Resnikoff">Ned Resnikoff, [http://www.ibtimes.com/political-capital/donald-trumps-charity-didnt-give-conservative-groups-until-2010-citizens-united Donald Trump's Charity Didn't Give To Conservative Groups Until 2010; Citizens United Supporters and Anti-Vaxxers Got Donations], ''International Business Times'' (April 11, 2016).</ref> Among these organizations, the Foundation gave:<ref name="Resnikoff" />
*[[Liberty Central Inc.]] — $10,000 in 2010 *[[Citizens Against Government Waste]] — $10,000 in 2010 *[[Billy Graham Evangelistic Association]] — $50,000 in 2012 *[[American Conservative Union]] — $50,00 in 2013 *[[Family Leader Foundation]] — $20,000 in 2013 and 2014 *[[Citizens United Foundation]] — $100,000 in 2014
In 2010, the Trump Foundation made a $10,000 contribution to [[Jenny McCarthy]]'s [[Generation Rescue]], an organization that promotes [[anti-vaccine movement|vaccine scientific research]].<ref name="Resnikoff" />

'''Matthias Bartgis''' (1759 – 1825) was a pioneer German-American printer in Western Maryland, Virginia, and Pennsylvania.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://msa.maryland.gov/megafile/msa/speccol/sc3500/sc3520/014900/014987/html/14987bio.html|title=Matthias Bartgis, MSA SC 3520-14987|website=msa.maryland.gov|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref>
Matthias Bartgis was born June 3, 1759 in [[Lancaster, Pennsylvania]] to a German immigrant, Matthias Bartgis. He learned the art of printing from William Bradford in Philadelphia and initially established a print office in [[York, Pennsylvania]]. In 1778 he expanded his business to [[Frederick, Maryland]] and later to [[Winchester, Virginia]] as well. In 1788 Bartgis established a regular bi-weekly private mail system which stretched from York to Winchester to facilitate the delivery of his paper.
Until his retirement in 1820 Bartgis published various newspapers, pamphlets, forms, and books for the rapidly growing population of the Shenandoah, bringing printed culture to the area and including the large German minority.
His newspaper publications include: :*1785-1789. Bartgis’s Marylandische Zeitung, Fredericktown, Md. :*''1786-1788. Maryland Chronicle, Fredericktown, Md. :*''1787-1788. Pennsylvania Chronicle, York, Pa. :*''1787-1791. Virginia Gazette, Winchester, Va. :*''1789. Maryland Gazette, Fredericktown, Md. :*''1790. Staunton Gazette, Staunton, Va. :*''1792-1794. Bartgis’s Maryland Gazette, Fredericktown, Md. :*''1793. General Staats-Bothe, Fredericktown, Md. :*''1794-1800. Bartgis’s Federal Gazette, Fredericktown, Md. :*''1800-1820+. Bartgis’s Republican Gazette, Fredericktown, Md. :*''1802-1806, 1809-1810, 1813-1814. Hornet, Fredericktown, Md. :*''1808. Independent American Volunteer, Fredericktown, Md. :*''1810-1813. General Staatsbothe, Fredericktown, Md.
==References== <references /> *Brigham, Clarence S. History and Bibliography of American Newspapers, 1690-1820. Vol. 2. Worcester, MA: American Antiquarian Society, 1947. *Dolmetsch, Christopher, "The German Literature of Virginia's Shenandoah Valley, 1789-1854: A Historical, Linguistic and Literary Study" (Ph.D. diss., U. of Wisconsin-Madison, 1979). *Wust, Klaus G. "Matthias Bartgis' Newspapers in Virginia," ''American-German Review, Vol. XVIII, NO. 1, (October 1951).
==External links== *[http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/speccol/sc3500/sc3520/014900/014987/html/msa14987.html The Maryland State Archives page on Matthias Bartgis]

[[Image:MediaTechnologyMonitorLogo.jpg|frame|50px|alt=Logo of the Media Technology Monitor (MTM).|Logo ]]The '''Media Technology Monitor''' (MTM) is an annual telephone survey and research product designed to monitor Canadians' use and adoption of new and existing technologies. The first MTM questionnaire was distributed in 2005 and now consists of two annual surveys conducted in the spring and fall of each year.<ref>CRTC Communications Monitoring Report (2011) - {{cite web |url=http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/publications/reports/policymonitoring/2011/cmr2011.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005120457/http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/publications/reports/PolicyMonitoring/2011/cmr2011.pdf |archivedate=2011-10-05 |df= }}</ref>
The survey features questions that focus on current and emerging media activities and technologies such as, television across multiple platforms, radio use social media, and online audio. The results of the Media Technology Monitor are published through a series of syndicated reports and multiple short, targeted theme reports. The Media Technology Monitor reports are distributed to government agencies, broadcasters, and other media stakeholders across Canada who subscribe to the service.
The MTM is designed, implemented and analyzed by the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] (CBC/Radio-Canada).<ref>Broadcaster Magazine - http://www.broadcastermagazine.com/news/bbm-analytics-to-market-cbc-radio-canada-media-technology-monitor/1000045568/</ref> In 2011, the MTM coordinated with [[Carleton University]] in Ottawa, Ontario to provide learning materials to the Communications Department.
==History== The Media Technology Monitor has evolved from the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's]] Quality Ratings Survey (QRS) that began in 1997 to measure Canadians' use and perception of Canada's conventional and specialty television channels as well as some media technology behaviours. In 2005, the MTM was launched with a specific focus on media technology adoption and use among Canadians. In 2010, an online MTM portal ([http://www.mtm-otm.ca www.mtm-otm.ca]) was created to provide a more interactive experience for users. The portal allows users a quick and easy way to download MTM reports and trending data, as well as conduct custom analysis of the data with a proprietary data analysis tool.
MTM-OTM Video on YouTube : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oGlObksktTU&feature=youtu.be
Since then the technology has become less and less used due to the rise of the internet and the easier, quicker and cheaper way to send our surveys to users which using certain methods is also further available for free.
==Survey Methodology and Design== The Media Technology Monitor is released in the fall and spring of each year and collects a total of 12,000 responses through telephone interviews with 6,000 Anglophones and 6,000 Francophones aged 18+. The response rate for both surveys is 30%.<ref>Official MTM Website - {{cite web |url=http://www.mtm-otm.ca/quest.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329110546/http://www.mtm-otm.ca/quest.asp |archivedate=2012-03-29 |df= }}</ref>
* Fall Survey - 8,000 Respondents (4,000 Anglophones and 4,000 Francophones)<ref>Official MTM Website - {{cite web |url=http://www.mtm-otm.ca/quest.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329110546/http://www.mtm-otm.ca/quest.asp |archivedate=2012-03-29 |df= }}</ref> * Spring Survey - 4,000 Respondents (2,000 Anglophones and 2,000 Francophones)<ref>Official MTM Website - {{cite web |url=http://www.mtm-otm.ca/quest.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329110546/http://www.mtm-otm.ca/quest.asp |archivedate=2012-03-29 |df= }}</ref>
MTM survey households are selected by [[Random digit dialing|Random Digit Dialing]] (RDD) and the respondent within each household is randomly selected based on the most recent birthday method. The MTM uses telephone surveys to ensure that the respondents are representative of all Canadians by eliminating bias due to geographic location and connection to the Internet.
==Current Topics==
The Media Technology Monitor is revised every year to include emerging media trends and technologies. Recent MTM surveys have asked respondents about their behavior and consumption of:
* Conventional TV Use<ref>Globe and Mail - https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/technology/tech-news/bye-bye-analog-hello-bidding-war-for-digital-airwaves/article2147741/</ref><ref>Playback Online - http://playbackonline.ca/2011/06/06/one-in-10-canadians-have-tried-netflix-mtm-study/</ref><ref>Genius Marketing - {{cite web |url=http://www.geniusmarketinginc.com/?p=835 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329110546/http://www.geniusmarketinginc.com/?p=835 |archivedate=2012-03-29 |df= }}</ref> ** PVRs / DVRs ** VOD ** Video streaming ** Market share of TV service providers ** Service provider * Personal Audio<ref>Mediacaster Magazine - http://www.mediacastermagazine.com/news/the-media-that-matters-most-hdtv-podcasts-mp3s/1000093251/</ref> ** Satellite radio ** Streaming radio ** Podcasts ** Traditional AM/FM radio use ** Subscription radio ** Online music downloads * Internet Usage ** Home Internet usage ** Connection speed ** Internet connected television *High Definition Television<ref>TVB - http://www.tvb.ca/pages/BBM_MediaTechnologyTrends_htm</ref> ** Number of HD TV sets ** HD Receivers ** Portable Media ** Tablets, Laptops, MP3 Players ** Audio/video content ** Consumption frequency and location * Wireless ** Smartphone usage ** Apps *Social Media ** Social networking behaviours
==Results Featured in Published Works==
* Digital Radio in Canada: From DAB to Multi-Platform Approaches, Brian O'Neill, [[Dublin Institute of Technology]], 2007<ref>Digital Radio in Canada: From DAB to Multi-Platform Approaches - http://arrow.dit.ie/aaschmedcon/9/</ref> * Broadcasting Policy in Canada, Robert Armstrong, [[University of Toronto]], 2010<ref>Broadcasting Policy in Canada - https://books.google.com/books?id=v8uRPaM_VoAC&lpg=PP1&dq=Canadian%20Media&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=true dia-2011-09-09.doc</ref> * CRTC Communications Monitoring Report, [[Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission]], 2011<ref>CRTC Communications Monitoring Report (2011) - {{cite web |url=http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/publications/reports/policymonitoring/2011/cmr2011.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005120457/http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/publications/reports/PolicyMonitoring/2011/cmr2011.pdf |archivedate=2011-10-05 |df= }}</ref> * [https://books.google.com/books?id=vjuJiRkx33oC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Political+Economies+of+Media:+The+Transformation+of+The+Global+Media++Industries&hl=en#v=onepage&q&f=false The Political Economies of Media: The Transformation of the Global Media Industries], Dwayne Winseck & Dal Jong Jin, 2011<ref>The Political Economies of Media: The Transformation of the Global Media Industries, Google Books - https://books.google.com/books?id=vjuJiRkx33oC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Political+Economies+of+Media:+The+Transformation+of+The+Global+Media++Industries&hl=en#v=onepage&q&f=false</ref>

'''Michael Bickford''' is an [[United States|American]] businessman. He is the founder of [[Round Hill Capital]], a real estate investment firm.
==Biography== ===Early life=== Michael Bickford was born in [[Greenwich, Connecticut]].<ref name="laindiana">[http://laindianapolo.com/concept/players/ La Indiana Polo Club: Management]</ref> His father, who was a [[polo]] player, owns a farm in [[Vermont]].<ref name="pololine">[http://www.pololine.com/?lang=1&sec=3&note=2639 Michael Bickford: Interview in St. Moritz], ''Polo Line'', February 10, 2013</ref> He graduated from [[Vanderbilt University]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name="roundhill">[http://roundhillcapital.com/our-team/uk/ Round Hill Capital: UK Team] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130918064836/http://roundhillcapital.com/our-team/uk/ |date=2013-09-18 }}</ref>
===Career=== Michael has over 18 years experience in private equity real estate. From 1995 to 2002, he worked as an acquisition professional for the [[Morgan Stanley]] Real Estate Funds.<ref name="roundhill"/> In 2002, he founded [[Round Hill Capital]], a real estate investment firm which has invested approximately $6 billion of capital in European real estate since its inception.<ref name="laindiana"/><ref name="roundhill"/><ref name="roundhillhistory">[http://roundhillcapital.com/about-us/history/ Round Hill Capital: History]</ref>
===Personal life=== Michael plays high goal polo competitively in England, Spain, France and the United States. He started playing polo at a young age with his father in Vermont and today plays against the top players in the world by competing in the Queens Cup, British Open, Gold Cup in Spain, and the high goal tournaments in Wellington, FL. La Indiana is the team name and is considered one of the most competitive teams in the world today. Michael was ranked the best polo Amateur in the world last year.

Some of his works are published under the [[pen name]] '''Gabriel Malika'''. ==Biography== Olivier Auroy is a graduate from [[Science-Po]] Paris, class of 1991.[https://www.thenational.ae/business/the-colourful-life-of-olivier-auroy-a-modern-man-of-letters-1.389519 The colourful life of Olivier Auroy, a modern man of letters], ''The National''. May 27, 2011 He holds a [[master degree]] in advertising and marketing from [[CELSA Paris|CELSA]] (Paris, [[La Sorbonne]]).{{fr}} [http://www.lesbiographies.com/Biographie/AUROY-Olivier,126017 Fiche de M. Olivier AUROY], ''lesbiographies.com''. June 13, 2017 He worked as product manager for [[Renault]] Italia until 1995 before moving on to a variety of [[Product naming|naming]], [[Branding agency|branding]] and [[design]] agencies. He is appointed [[Managing Director]] of [[Landor Associates|Landor]] Dubai in 2006 and becomes [[CEO]] of FITCH Middle East ([[WPP plc|WPP]]) in 2009.{{fr}} [http://www.strategies.fr/guides-annuaires/nominations/124360W/olivier-auroy-directeur-general-de-fitch-moyen-orient.html Olivier Auroy, directeur général de Fitch Moyen-Orien], ''Stratégies''. October 1, 2009 Around that time, he launches BQ, a brand of sunglasses inspired by the Emirati burka.{{fr}} [http://blog.lefigaro.fr/iran/2009/11/dubai-quand-mode-et-burqa-font.html Dubaï : Quand mode et burqa font bon ménage], ''Le Figaro''. November 25, 2009[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/11/united-arab-emirates-new-line-of-burka-sunglasses-hits-the-market.html DUBAI: Now, she can look pious in hijab and cool in her shades], ''LA Times''. November 24, 2009 In 2014, after having spent the better part of a decade in the [[Middle East]], he is recruited by the French agency CBA as head of Corporate Branding.{{fr}} [http://www.strategies.fr/actualites/agences/1005682W/de-dubai-a-levallois.html De Dubaï à Levallois], ''Stratégies''. February 18, 2015 In June 2017, he becomes Joint Managing Director of [[Kantar]] Consulting.{{fr}} [http://www.cbnews.fr/mouvements/kantar-added-value-france-reorganise-son-management-a1035931 Kantar Added Value France réorganise son management], ''CBNews''. June 12, 2017{{fr}} [http://www.cbnews.fr/conseils/kantar-lance-kantar-consulting-a1039714 Kantar lance Kantar Consulting], ''CBNews''. January 8, 2018 His views are regularly reported in the press, especially in ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' and ''Marketing Society''.{{fr}} [http://www.huffingtonpost.fr/olivier-auroy/pourquoi-la-generation-x-veut-vivre-plusieurs-vies-a-tout-prix_a_23241385/ Pourquoi la Génération X veut vivre plusieurs vies à tout prix], ''Huffing Post''. October 14, 2017[https://www.marketingsociety.com/the-library/airbnb-puts-village-back-map#sffD3wVedOtgGDv9.97 Airbnb puts the village back on the map], ''Marketing society''. October 3, 2017[https://www.marketingsociety.com/the-gym/design-thinking-30#WXRsfH1ThWSlm78j.97 Design Thinking 3.0], ''Marketing society''. December 6, 2017{{fr}} [http://www.huffingtonpost.fr/olivier-auroy/si-vous-pensiez-qua-lheure-dinternet-la-culture-generale-est-inutile-ces-3-histoires-vont-vous-prouver-le-contraire_a_23334430/ Si vous pensiez qu'à l'heure d'internet, la culture générale est inutile, ces 3 histoires vont vous prouver le contraire], ''Huffing Post''. January 16, 2018[https://www.marketingsociety.com/the-gym/what-has-changed-or-not-about-business-creating-names#eXHMp4DAke1TKh8P.97 What has changed (or not) about the business of creating names], ''Marketing society'', January 23, 2018 == Writing career == While in the Middle East, he publishes his first two novels under the pen name Gabriel Malika, so as to separate his identity as writer and as a businessman.{{fr}} [http://www.rts.ch/play/radio/detours/audio/entre-qatar-et-arabie?id=6679623#?station=a9e7621504c6959e35c3ecbe7f6bed0446cdf8da Entre Qatar et Arabie], ''Détours'', ''Radio télévision suisse''. April 20, 2015 His first book, ''Les Meilleures intentions du monde'' (''The Best Intentions in the World''), published in 2011, tells the stories of men and women from all walks of life embarked on a journey off the coast of [[Dubai]]. This the first ever French novel to use Dubai as backdrop for its intrigue, which has been called a "literary milestone" in and of itself.{{fr}} [http://loriental.blog.lemonde.fr/2011/09/21/rentree-litteraire-le-premier-roman-en-francais-sur-dubai/ Rentrée littéraire : le premier roman en français sur Dubaï], ''l'oriental''. September 21, 2011{{fr}} [http://pages.rts.ch/la-1ere/programmes/monumental/6925243-monumental-du-22-07-2015.html Dubaï], ''Monumental'', ''Radio télévision suisse''. July 22, 2015 In December 2017 this book was edited in an English digital version. The second book, ''Qatarina'', is published in 2014. In 2022, US teacher John Summerbe flies to Quarabia, where the Football World Cup is being held.{{fr}} [http://www.aufeminin.com/livres-a-lire/qatarina-un-roman-ensoleille-ou-une-bombe-a-retardement-s291654.html Qatarina, un roman ensoleillé ou une bombe à retardement ?], ''aufeminin''. February 12, 2014 With this work of fiction, Oliver Auroy openly criticizes [[Qatar]]'s bid to host the [[2022 FIFA World Cup]].{{fr}} [http://www.dubaimadame.com/sortir/films-et-livres/988-a-lire-qatarina-de-gabriel-malika-le-qatar-saura-t-il-relever-le-defi-de-la-coupe-du-monde-de-foot-2022 "Qatarina" de Gabriel Malika, le Qatar saura-t-il relever le défi de la coupe du monde de foot 2022 ?], ''Dubaimadame''. February 26, 2014{{fr}} [http://profondeurdechamps.com/2014/01/30/qatarina-de-gabriel-malika-ou-la-tragedie-annoncee-de-qatar-2022/ “Qatarina” de Gabriel Malika, ou la tragédie annoncée de Qatar 2022], ''Profondeurchamps''. January 30, 2014{{fr}} [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bgt9CYXY97s Qatar : une plongée dans l'avenir avec "Qatarina"], ''TV5 Monde''. June 2, 2014 His third novel, ''Au nom d’Alexandre'' (''In the name of Alexander''), is published under his real name in 2016.{{fr}} [http://www.aufeminin.com/livres-a-lire/olivier-auroy-roman-s1798693.html "Au nom d'Alexandre", pourquoi on aime ce roman d'un dingo des mots ?], ''[[aufeminin]]''. April 4, 2016 Alexandre works in [[Product naming|brand naming]]. He opens up to a young journalist and reflects on his professional life. Inspired by his own career,{{fr}} [https://perrinfrancois.files.wordpress.com/2016/12/auroy.png Au nom d'Alexandre], ''Le vif''. March 4, 2016 Oliver Auroy "presents us with a delightful novel about an excentric scholar".{{fr}} [http://www.lexpress.fr/culture/livre/olivier-auroy-rend-un-bel-hommage-a-littre-et-consorts_1764721.html Olivier Auroy rend un bel hommage à Littré et consorts], ''l'express''. February 21, 2016 His fourth novel, ''L'amour propre'' is published in April 2018 by « éditions Intervalles ».[https://www.decitre.fr/livres/l-amour-propre-9782369560630.html L'Amour propre], ''Decitre'' == Other activities == Between 2012 and 2014, Oliver Auroy hosts debates and interviews other writers such as [[Jérôme Ferrari]], Maxime Chattam, Dominique de Saint-Mars and [[Katherine Pancol]] during the Dubai's Literary Festival.{{fr}} [http://institutfrancais-uae.com/2014/04/13/la-foire-internationale-du-livre-dabou-dabi-ouvre-ses-portes-2/ La Foire Internationale du Livre d’Abou Dabi ouvre ses portes !], ''institut francais uae''. April 13, 2014{{fr}} [http://www.dubaimadame.com/business/1971-interview-exclusive-katherine-pancol-au-festival-de-litterature-de-dubai Interview exclusive- Katherine Pancol au festival de littérature de Dubai], ''Dubaimadame''. March 12, 2014 Olivier Auroy is often featured on the [[RTL (French radio)|RTL radio]] talk show ''La Curiosité est un vilain défaut''.{{fr}} [http://www.rtl.fr/culture/medias-people/les-verts-patrimoine-et-dubai-dans-la-curiosite-7781434316 Les Verts, patrimoine et Dubaï dans La Curiosité], ''RTL''. January 18, 2016{{fr}} [http://www.rtl.fr/culture/arts-spectacles/mammouths-dans-la-curiosite-7783319393 Mammouths dans La Curiosité], ''RTL''. May 20, 2016 He was a frequent panelist on ''Talking of Books'', a [[Dubai Eye 103.8|Dubai Eye]] radio program. While in Dubai, he also worked as literary critique for ''Le Mag du Moyen-Orient'' magazine. == Personal life == Olivier Auroy is married to an Italian native. Together, they have two daughters.[https://www.thenational.ae/lifestyle/style-file-olivier-auroy-1.419309 Style file: Olivier Auroy], ''The National''. August 31, 2011 == Works == * {{fr}} Jean-Marie Albertini et Olivier Auroy, {{cite book|title=L'aventure de l'automobile|publisher=Gallimard|year=1995|isbn=978-2070587452}} * {{fr}} Gabriel Malika, {{cite book|title=Les meilleures intentions du monde|publisher=Editions Intervalles|year=2011|isbn=978-2916355597|bnf=|url=}} ** {{en icon}} Gabriel Malika, {{cite book|title=The Best Intentions in the World|publisher=Editions Intervalles|year=2017|asin=B077Y3D284|bnf=|url=}} * {{fr}} Gabriel Malika, {{cite book|title=Qatarina|publisher=Editions Intervalles|year=2014|isbn=978-2916355986 |bnf=|url=}} * {{fr}} Olivier Auroy, {{cite book|title=Au nom d'Alexandre|publisher=Editions Intervalles|year=2016|isbn=978-2369560319 |bnf=|url=}} * {{fr}} Olivier Auroy, {{cite book|title=L’amour propre|publisher=Editions Intervalles|year=2018|isbn=978-2-36956-063-0}} == External links == * [https://olivierauroy-auteur.com/ Official website] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Auroy, Olivier}} [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:21st-century French novelists]] [[Category:Sciences Po alumni]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]]
